pos_items.definition: used when you are emphasizing what is really true or what really happened
dictionary_examples: I don't actually like seafood.
So what actually happened?
learner_examples: Last night I w[as] at your house and I think I have left my purse there. It's actually quite important because my Identi[ty] Card is inside. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used when you are emphasizing something surprising
dictionary_examples: A friend of mine from university was actually at the same concert - I hadn't seen her for years!
Don't tell me he actually paid for you? You are honoured!
learner_examples: It was so cool, man! They had actually built a good skate park with a pool, a halfpipe, a funbox, several rails and of course many ramps. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used when you are correcting someone, disagreeing with someone, or saying no to a request
dictionary_examples: Actually, Gavin, it was Tuesday of last week, not Wednesday.
"You didn't tell me about needing the car." "Actually, I did."
"Do you mind if I smoke?" "Actually, I'd rather you didn't."
learner_examples: Actually, TORRENTS was [the] second group [at the festival]. I think you probably missed the first performance [in] which KING CUP sang. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not acceptable or of good quality
dictionary_examples: They played very badly in the first half of the match.
The event was badly organized.
Their children are extremely badly-behaved.
He did badly in his exams.
learner_examples: I had done badly in my last exam and my teacher said she would talk to my mother. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: very much
dictionary_examples: He needs the money very badly.
They are badly in need of help.
learner_examples: I need that very badly because I need my five-thousand rupees urgently. (Key English Test; A2; Assamese)

pos_items.definition: very seriously
dictionary_examples: badly damaged/hurt/injured
learner_examples: My brother told me that he crashed into the tree with his car and he [was] badly injured. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: in an unpleasant way
dictionary_examples: I thought he was treated very badly.
learner_examples: In the past, zoos treated animals quite badly. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize something and show that there is no doubt about it
dictionary_examples: I'll certainly be there.
They certainly deserved to win.
She certainly knew him but I don't know how close they were.
"Do you think more money should be given to education?" "Certainly!"
learner_examples: Don't wear new clothes, you will certainly get dirty. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to agree politely to a request
dictionary_examples: "Could you pass the salt, please?" "Certainly."

pos_items.definition: used after an adverb in short, negative replies
dictionary_examples: "She's not exactly poor, is she?" "Certainly not."
"Will you be taking her there?" "Certainly not!"
learner_examples: Are all young people lazy and unable to participate in any form of sport? Certainly not!!! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize something and show that there is no doubt about it

learner_examples: Are all young people lazy and unable to participate in any form of sport? Certainly not!!! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is easy to see, hear, read or understand
dictionary_examples: He spoke very clearly.
learner_examples: I can't see clearly without them. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not confused
dictionary_examples: I'd had two hours' sleep and wasn't thinking clearly.
learner_examples: But I don't remember clearly. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you think something is obvious or certain
dictionary_examples: The accident was clearly the lorry driver's fault.
Clearly, he's very talented.
learner_examples: It was clearly not for me, because it came from a girl called Carol who wanted to talk to some guy named John. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: completely
dictionary_examples: The food was absolutely delicious.
It's absolutely ridiculous.
I have absolutely no idea what she's talking about.
We've achieved absolutely nothing today.
I absolutely hate it.
learner_examples: I've heard the film is absolutely fantastic. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to strongly agree with someone
dictionary_examples: "Do you think it helped his career?" "Absolutely."
"It was an excellent film, though." "Absolutely!"
learner_examples: So have the Swedish grandparents got funkier? Absolutely! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to strongly disagree with someone or to agree with something negative
dictionary_examples: "Are you suggesting that we should just ignore the problem?" "No, absolutely not."
learner_examples: Does it mean the parents will allow them to eat anything they please? Absolutely not. You have to give the children some options, instead of imposing things on them. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used when you are agreeing that something is true although you do not want to
dictionary_examples: Admittedly, I could have tried harder but I still don't think all this criticism is fair.
learner_examples: Admittedly, using your car is more convenient and easier [than] using public transport but in my opinion, the advantages of using public transport outweigh the disadvantages it can cause. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to suggest another possibility
dictionary_examples: We could go to the Indian restaurant, or alternatively, we could try that new Italian place.
learner_examples: Alternatively, I suggest that you should invite a famous writer. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to say you have read or been told something although you are not certain it is true
dictionary_examples: Apparently it's going to rain today.
Apparently he's had enough of England and is going back to Australia.
learner_examples: Apparently he was planning to visit me and su[r]prise me for my birthday, w[h]ich was the following day. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something seems to be true, although it is not certain
dictionary_examples: There were two apparently unrelated deaths.
An eighty-year-old woman was badly hurt in what the police describe as an apparently random attack.
learner_examples: People found it important and still do but apparently, today, we don't appreciate reading as much as our ancestors. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say you have read or been told something although you are not certain it is true
dictionary_examples: Apparently it's going to rain today.

learner_examples: Apparently he was planning to visit me and su[r]prise me for my birthday, w[h]ich was the following day. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in the most important ways
dictionary_examples: These two machines are basically the same, but you get a few extra features in the more expensive one.
The car's basically sound, but the paintwork needs a bit of attention.
learner_examples: Although they will offer some hot meals at any time, most of the food provided is basically fast food and snacks. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce a short explanation about something
dictionary_examples: Basically, what he's saying is that we need more time.
learner_examples: Basically, we spend half our leisure time being stuck to a screen and leading [a] so-called co[u]ch potato lifestyle. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in an unpleasant way

learner_examples: In the past, zoos treated animals quite badly. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: close to a particular number or time although not exactly that number or time
dictionary_examples: The job will take approximately two weeks, and cost around £1000.
The college has approximately 700 students.
learner_examples: From the airport of Larnaka you need approximately forty-five minutes by taxi, to Agia Napa. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in an adequate way
dictionary_examples: While some patients can be adequately cared for at home, others are best served by care in a hospital.

pos_items.definition: in an unpleasant way
dictionary_examples: I thought he was treated very badly.
learner_examples: In the past, zoos treated animals quite badly. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: only just
dictionary_examples: They have barely enough to pay the rent this month.
She was barely fifteen when she won her first championship.
learner_examples: His father replied in a voice barely above a whisper. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: with a lot of strong colour or light
dictionary_examples: brightly coloured clothes
a brightly lit room
learner_examples: The sun was shining brightly over the white mountain tops. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is beautiful
dictionary_examples: She dresses beautifully.
Their house is beautifully decorated.
learner_examples: My room is big and beautifully decora[t]ed. (Preliminary English Test; B1; )

pos_items.definition: in an amazing way
dictionary_examples: The food was amazingly good.
Amazingly enough, no one else has applied for the job.
learner_examples: Amazingly, he didn't come back until midnight. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in an angry way
dictionary_examples: "Don't do that!" she shouted angrily.
Demonstrators protested angrily following the jury's verdict.
The Prime Minister reacted angrily to claims that he had lied to the House of Commons.
learner_examples: "How dare she do that [to] me?" I thought, angrily. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a brave way
dictionary_examples: She faced the consequences bravely.

pos_items.definition: in an aggressive way
dictionary_examples: Small children often behave aggressively.
They played more aggressively in the second half.

pos_items.definition: in an anxious way
dictionary_examples: We waited anxiously by the phone.
learner_examples: I am waiting for your reply anxiously. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is brave or very confident
dictionary_examples: The President had already boldly declared victory.
learner_examples: One boldly ventures where none of their family members have been before in search of a better lifestyle, good weather... (International English Language Testing System; C1; Samoan)

pos_items.definition: in a very skillful way
dictionary_examples: He seems to do everything brilliantly - piano playing, skiing, sailing.
learner_examples: Although they are not very famous like JULIE BLOOM, they sang brilliantly. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: in a quiet or relaxed way
dictionary_examples: She reacted surprisingly calmly to the news of his death.
learner_examples: Very calmly, I closed my book and put it on the table which was on my left. (First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: in a careless way
dictionary_examples: He told me off for driving carelessly.
learner_examples: I broke your beautiful vase carelessly while I ran to answer the door. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a cheerful way
dictionary_examples: She walked down the road, whistling cheerfully.
learner_examples: But Mr Robertson recognised Jane and greeted her very cheerfully. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is directly connected or has a strong relationship
dictionary_examples: English and German are closely related.
Both politicians have been closely associated with the movement for some time.
We are working closely with the police.
learner_examples: The main reason I am applying for this job is that this job would be very rewarding on [a] personal level and would give me useful experience closely related to my field of study. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is very near in distance, time, or position
dictionary_examples: Elke came into the room, closely followed by her children.
learner_examples: According to statistical figures, Germany is better off as compared to [the] USA and closely followed by Spain in the management of Government spending. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Marathi)

pos_items.definition: carefully and paying attention to details
dictionary_examples: Pollution levels are closely monitored.
If you look closely, you can see where he painted over his signature.
learner_examples: I think that working for High Travel as its inte[r]preter would be a great experience if the company decides to look closely at the co[n]ditions of its employees and of its travellers. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If a machine does something automatically, it does it independently, without human control.
dictionary_examples: The camera adjusts the shutter speed automatically.
learner_examples: [The] television will be automatically switched on in time for [the] breakfast news. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If you do something automatically, you do it without thinking about it.
dictionary_examples: I automatically put my hand out to catch it.
learner_examples: There was a strange envelope between the others, so automatically, she picked it up and [looked at] the stamp. The letter came from Australia. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: despite that
dictionary_examples: Her parents were opposed to her giving up her course, but she did it anyway.
learner_examples: Dear Jo, You can call me for th[is] information but I will write it [here] anyway. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are returning to an earlier subject or changing the subject
dictionary_examples: Anyway, I'll be away next week.
Anyway, in the end I didn't wear your jacket.
learner_examples: I hope everything [will] be O.K... anyway you have my phone number. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: used to give a more important reason for something that you are saying
dictionary_examples: I don't have time to go and anyway it's too expensive.
Of course I don't mind taking you home - I'm going that way anyway.
learner_examples: I'm going to buy a new bed, because the old one has broken, [and] anyway it wasn't very comfortable. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: despite that
dictionary_examples: Her parents were opposed to her giving up her course, but she did it anyway.
learner_examples: Dear Jo, You can call me for th[is] information but I will write it [here] anyway. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are returning to an earlier subject or changing the subject
dictionary_examples: Anyway, I'll be away next week.
Anyway, in the end I didn't wear your jacket.
learner_examples: I hope everything [will] be O.K... anyway you have my phone number. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: used to give a more important reason for something that you are saying
dictionary_examples: I don't have time to go and anyway it's too expensive.
Of course I don't mind taking you home - I'm going that way anyway.
learner_examples: I'm going to buy a new bed, because the old one has broken, [and] anyway it wasn't very comfortable. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: where someone or something was before
dictionary_examples: When do you go back to college?
I put the tin back in the cupboard.
learner_examples: She [went] back home at once. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: as a reply or reaction to something
dictionary_examples: I'm busy at the moment - can I call you back?
I waved to her and she waved back.
learner_examples: Write back to me soon. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a direction behind you
dictionary_examples: He sat back on the sofa.
Anna stepped back.
learner_examples: I cried [out], stepping back and falling down. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to the state something or someone was in before
dictionary_examples: It's not badly broken - I'm sure we can put it back together again.
Hopefully things will get back to normal soon.
I was woken by a thunderstorm, and I couldn't get back to sleep.
learner_examples: My life was back to normal. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: at or to an earlier time
dictionary_examples: We first met back in 1971.
This tradition dates back to the 16th century.
learner_examples: All in all, it is difficult to get bored in Moscow, where you can see buildings which date back to centur[i]es ago. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a direction away from something
dictionary_examples: He pulled back the curtain.
The house is set back from the road.
learner_examples: The action of the book takes place in a lonely inn standing back from the road. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in one direction, then the opposite way, then in the original direction again many times
dictionary_examples: He has to travel back and forth between London and Paris every week.
learner_examples: Finally, after much walking back and forth, we found a road which we followed till we got to the town. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the part of something that is furthest from the front or in the opposite direction to the front
dictionary_examples: He wrote her email address down on the back of an envelope.
Our seats were right at the back of the theatre.
learner_examples: My cousins love mermaids, so each sweater has one on the back. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the part of your body from your shoulders to your bottom
dictionary_examples: back injuries/pain
I've got a bad back.
He lay on his back, staring at the ceiling.
learner_examples: The look on his face stopped me cold, as if someone had just poured freezing water down my back. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: with the back part of something where the front should be
dictionary_examples: You've got your trousers on back to front.
learner_examples: Therefore, the government needs to cut expenditure and as a result of this, health faciliti[es] will only be accessible for rich people. Then we are back to front. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: If you do something behind someone's back, you do it without them knowing, often in an unfair way.
dictionary_examples: Have they been saying things about me behind my back?
learner_examples: The food must be perfect, too, or else her mother-in-law and my father's sisters will think that she's not a proper wife, and will probably say insulting things about her behind her back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to decide to stop having contact with someone or something, or to refuse to help someone
dictionary_examples: She turned her back on Hollywood and went to live in Florida.
learner_examples: She gets to learn that Olivia turned her back on her past and merged totally with India through her attraction to and sympathy for the Nawab. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: be (like) water off a duck's back
pos_items.definition: If criticisms, insults, etc. are like water off a duck's back to you, they do not affect you at all.
dictionary_examples: She calls him lazy and useless, but it's like water off a duck's back.
learner_examples: The main lesson I have learned is by looking at some people who have lived alone for most of their life and faced with neither contradiction nor argument, they stay in their ivory tower, so sure of their opinions that whatever you say is like water off a duck's back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: at or near the back of something
dictionary_examples: a back door/garden
the back page/seat
I put it in the back pocket of my jeans.
learner_examples: There are two movies, but one is for adults so we will see "The back garden". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: a very small road or street that goes behind or between buildings
dictionary_examples: We wandered through the back streets, looking for Tommy.
learner_examples: From the museum you have to walk across a pedestrian street, through an unspoiled district, where a jumble of narrow back streets retain old-world characters. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: to move backwards or drive backwards
dictionary_examples: She saw he had a gun and backed away.
He backed into a wall when he was trying to park.
learner_examples: When he backed out of the [car park] he almost crashed into another car. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to give support or help to a person, plan, or idea
dictionary_examples: He backed Mr Clark in the recent election.
Parents backed the idea by more than two to one.
learner_examples: Of course, without [the] people wh[o] are backing the leader in his fight, he could not achieve his success. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: despite that
dictionary_examples: Her parents were opposed to her giving up her course, but she did it anyway.
learner_examples: Dear Jo, You can call me for th[is] information but I will write it [here] anyway. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are returning to an earlier subject or changing the subject
dictionary_examples: Anyway, I'll be away next week.
Anyway, in the end I didn't wear your jacket.
learner_examples: I hope everything [will] be O.K... anyway you have my phone number. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: used to give a more important reason for something that you are saying
dictionary_examples: I don't have time to go and anyway it's too expensive.
Of course I don't mind taking you home - I'm going that way anyway.
learner_examples: I'm going to buy a new bed, because the old one has broken, [and] anyway it wasn't very comfortable. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: in addition to something or someone
dictionary_examples: Do you play any other sports besides football and basketball?
learner_examples: It's a Chinese food buffet but besides Chinese food they also have Italian food like pizza. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to give another reason for something
dictionary_examples: She won't mind your being late - besides, it's hardly your fault.
learner_examples: I think that I'm going to buy "Troy" because it looks to me [to be] a great movie - besides, it reminds me of your vacations in Mexico. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to
dictionary_examples: Besides looking after the children, she runs a successful business.
learner_examples: But besides playing, you can also sit [i]n the "club lounge", where you can drink something with your friends or just play cards. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: despite that
dictionary_examples: He hates carrots but he ate them anyhow.
learner_examples: It wasn't a great support, but anyhow I consider my choice to be the best I could have [made]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used when you are returning to an earlier subject
dictionary_examples: Anyhow, as I said, I'll be away next week.
learner_examples: After that we drove for about one hour before we had to take a lunch break. It was still very hot when we continued our trip and we had to stop once more. Anyhow, we [got] to Munich the same day, where we stayed for two days. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to give a more important reason for something that you are saying
dictionary_examples: I don't need a car and I can't afford one anyhow.
learner_examples: We both thought that it was a good idea to have that stop-over at your place as it was on our route to Norway anyhow. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used when you want to slightly change something that you have just said
dictionary_examples: Boys aren't horrible - not all of them anyhow!

pos_items.definition: despite that
dictionary_examples: He hates carrots but he ate them anyhow.
learner_examples: It wasn't a great support, but anyhow I consider my choice to be the best I could have [made]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used when you want to slightly change something that you have just said
dictionary_examples: Boys aren't horrible - not all of them anyhow!

pos_items.definition: in or to a higher position than something else
dictionary_examples: There's a mirror above the washbasin.
Her name comes above mine on the list.
learner_examples: I think I have [put] it above the bookshelf. (Key English Test; A2; Assamese)

pos_items.definition: more than an amount or level
dictionary_examples: It says on the box it's for children aged three and above.
Rates of pay are above average.
learner_examples: The weather is too hot in Beijing. Every day [it] is above 30 degrees. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: most importantly
dictionary_examples: Above all, I'd like to thank my family.
He is known above all for his film roles.
learner_examples: She is a very nice person and above all, she is really cheerful. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: too good or important for something
dictionary_examples: No one is above suspicion in this matter.

dictionary_examples: the above diagram

Please send the articles to the address given/shown above.
learner_examples: I can be contacted at the above address and I would be free to attend an interview at any time from Monday to Saturday. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: where someone or something was before
dictionary_examples: When do you go back to college?
I put the tin back in the cupboard.
learner_examples: She [went] back home at once. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: as a reply or reaction to something
dictionary_examples: I'm busy at the moment - can I call you back?
I waved to her and she waved back.
learner_examples: Write back to me soon. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a direction behind you
dictionary_examples: He sat back on the sofa.
Anna stepped back.
learner_examples: I cried [out], stepping back and falling down. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to the state something or someone was in before
dictionary_examples: It's not badly broken - I'm sure we can put it back together again.
Hopefully things will get back to normal soon.
I was woken by a thunderstorm, and I couldn't get back to sleep.
learner_examples: My life was back to normal. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: at or to an earlier time
dictionary_examples: We first met back in 1971.
This tradition dates back to the 16th century.
learner_examples: All in all, it is difficult to get bored in Moscow, where you can see buildings which date back to centur[i]es ago. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a direction away from something
dictionary_examples: He pulled back the curtain.
The house is set back from the road.
learner_examples: The action of the book takes place in a lonely inn standing back from the road. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in one direction, then the opposite way, then in the original direction again many times
dictionary_examples: He has to travel back and forth between London and Paris every week.
learner_examples: Finally, after much walking back and forth, we found a road which we followed till we got to the town. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the part of something that is furthest from the front or in the opposite direction to the front
dictionary_examples: He wrote her email address down on the back of an envelope.
Our seats were right at the back of the theatre.
learner_examples: My cousins love mermaids, so each sweater has one on the back. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the part of your body from your shoulders to your bottom
dictionary_examples: back injuries/pain
I've got a bad back.
He lay on his back, staring at the ceiling.
learner_examples: The look on his face stopped me cold, as if someone had just poured freezing water down my back. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: with the back part of something where the front should be
dictionary_examples: You've got your trousers on back to front.
learner_examples: Therefore, the government needs to cut expenditure and as a result of this, health faciliti[es] will only be accessible for rich people. Then we are back to front. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: If you do something behind someone's back, you do it without them knowing, often in an unfair way.
dictionary_examples: Have they been saying things about me behind my back?
learner_examples: The food must be perfect, too, or else her mother-in-law and my father's sisters will think that she's not a proper wife, and will probably say insulting things about her behind her back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to decide to stop having contact with someone or something, or to refuse to help someone
dictionary_examples: She turned her back on Hollywood and went to live in Florida.
learner_examples: She gets to learn that Olivia turned her back on her past and merged totally with India through her attraction to and sympathy for the Nawab. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: be (like) water off a duck's back
pos_items.definition: If criticisms, insults, etc. are like water off a duck's back to you, they do not affect you at all.
dictionary_examples: She calls him lazy and useless, but it's like water off a duck's back.
learner_examples: The main lesson I have learned is by looking at some people who have lived alone for most of their life and faced with neither contradiction nor argument, they stay in their ivory tower, so sure of their opinions that whatever you say is like water off a duck's back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: at or near the back of something
dictionary_examples: a back door/garden
the back page/seat
I put it in the back pocket of my jeans.
learner_examples: There are two movies, but one is for adults so we will see "The back garden". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: a very small road or street that goes behind or between buildings
dictionary_examples: We wandered through the back streets, looking for Tommy.
learner_examples: From the museum you have to walk across a pedestrian street, through an unspoiled district, where a jumble of narrow back streets retain old-world characters. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: to move backwards or drive backwards
dictionary_examples: She saw he had a gun and backed away.
He backed into a wall when he was trying to park.
learner_examples: When he backed out of the [car park] he almost crashed into another car. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to give support or help to a person, plan, or idea
dictionary_examples: He backed Mr Clark in the recent election.
Parents backed the idea by more than two to one.
learner_examples: Of course, without [the] people wh[o] are backing the leader in his fight, he could not achieve his success. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a lower position than someone or something else
dictionary_examples: From the top of the skyscraper the cars below us looked like insects.
Send your answers to the address below.
learner_examples: I think it's a nice place, because you have a great view of the other mountains and the country below you. (Key English Test; A2; German)

pos_items.definition: less than a particular amount or level
dictionary_examples: His marks in English have been below average for some time now.
The temperature has fallen below zero/freezing recently.
learner_examples: We have to learn that [it] is not natural for a lion [to be] living in a country where, in winter, [the] temperature can fall below zero. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: lower in rank
dictionary_examples: Monica is a grade below me.
learner_examples: [With] him being only 37 years old and [having] been promoted to the second level below the board of directors of a well-known international company, he seems like a good example [of] a successful person, at least in this area of success. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

learner_examples: I think I have [put] it above the bookshelf. (Key English Test; A2; Assamese)

pos_items.definition: more than an amount or level
dictionary_examples: It says on the box it's for children aged three and above.

dictionary_examples: No one is above suspicion in this matter.

learner_examples: I can be contacted at the above address and I would be free to attend an interview at any time from Monday to Saturday. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: from one side of something to the other
dictionary_examples: She walked across the field/road.
They're building a new bridge across the river.
When I reached the river, I simply swam across.
learner_examples: My new phone is great. It is black with white lines going across it. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: happening or having an effect on people at every level and in every area
dictionary_examples: The improvement has been across the board, with all divisions reporting increased profits.
learner_examples: Children in separate schools get on with things regardless of it being work for boys or girls, which can be quite positive especially in today's lifestyles where chores are done across the board. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Afrikaans)

pos_items.definition: on the opposite side of
dictionary_examples: The library is just across the road.
learner_examples: I think you will enjoy it, so let's meet at 6:00 pm at London Bridge Station next to Pret a Manger, because the cinema is just across the road. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in or to any place
dictionary_examples: Did you go anywhere interesting this summer?
Go anywhere in the world and you'll find some sort of hamburger restaurant.
learner_examples: I like that bicycle because I can go anywhere with it without anyone's help. (Key English Test; A2; Bengali)

pos_items.definition: used in questions and negatives to mean 'a place'
dictionary_examples: Is there anywhere in particular you wanted to go to eat tonight?
I can't find my keys anywhere.
Is there anywhere else you'd like to visit?
learner_examples: Do you know anywhere interesting and how can I get there? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to not make any progress
dictionary_examples: I tried discussing the problem with her but I didn't get anywhere.
learner_examples: If we think about making an effort and changing our daily routine at once, we will never get anywhere because a drastic change usually does not last. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used in questions and negatives to mean 'close to being or doing something'
dictionary_examples: The house isn't anywhere near ready.
learner_examples: We could not have gone anywhere near 5000 miles because all our minibuses were broken down - we even stayed in one place for 8 days. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to surround or be on all sides of something, or in a circular movement
dictionary_examples: We sat around the table.
He put his arm around her.
The moon goes around the Earth.
I walked around the building.
learner_examples: You can go around the lake by train. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to or in different parts of a place
dictionary_examples: I spent a year travelling around Australia.
I used to live around here.
learner_examples: After that, we will walk around the shopping mall. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: about or approximately
dictionary_examples: around two months ago
around four o'clock
She earns around forty thousand a year.
learner_examples: I think I'll arrive around 6.00 p.m. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: to or in different parts of a place
dictionary_examples: I'm going to fly to Peru and travel around for six weeks.
She went into town and spent two hours just walking around.
learner_examples: Come and visit, I'll show you around. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: in a circle or with circular movement
dictionary_examples: She passed a plate of biscuits around.
This switch makes the wheels go around.
learner_examples: Hello, everybody. Please gather around. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to the opposite direction
dictionary_examples: Jonny turned around and looked at her.
The pianist spun around on the stool and faced his audience.
learner_examples: As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name. I turned around. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If someone is around, they are present in a place.
dictionary_examples: Will you be around next week?
Roger isn't around at the moment - can I help instead?
learner_examples: It was dark and not a soul was around. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: present or available
dictionary_examples: Mobile phones have been around for years now.
learner_examples: Major sporting competitions have been around for the better part of 2500 years, ever since the original Olympic Games were held in ancient Greece. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a different place, position or situation
dictionary_examples: Just go away and leave me alone!
Would you like your burger to eat in or take away?
She's away on holiday until the end of the week.
Keep/Stay away from him.
learner_examples: I have [an] important exam on your wedding day [in] another city far away from my city. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: at a particular distance from a place
dictionary_examples: The nearest town was ten miles away.
The office is a half-hour drive away.
We live 5 km away from the coast.
learner_examples: I like it because its remote control could control distances [of] 1 or 2 meters away. (Key English Test; A2; Bengali)

pos_items.definition: in or into the usual or a suitable place, especially one that can be closed
dictionary_examples: Could you put the ice-cream away in the freezer?
My grandparents had £800 hidden away in an old shoe box.
learner_examples: I put away my mobile phone. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: at a particular time in the future
dictionary_examples: My English exam's only a week away and I haven't even started to prepare.
learner_examples: Christmas is just a few months away, and I do not inten[d] to spend it all alone like in the past few years, so I am writing to invite you [to] my real Christmas party without my parents. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: gradually disappearing until mostly or completely gone
dictionary_examples: All the snow had melted away.
The music faded away as the procession moved slowly up the street.
learner_examples: I always feel so fatigued at the end of the day but after a mile, the aches of the day seem to fade away. (First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used after a verb to mean 'continuously or repeatedly'
dictionary_examples: Chris was hammering away in the garden all day.
learner_examples: They chatted away for a while as Malcolm had to wait for the airport taxi. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: If a sports team is playing away, the game is at the place where the other team usually plays.
dictionary_examples: They were playing away.

pos_items.definition: except for or in addition to
dictionary_examples: Apart from the low salary, it's a great job!
He works until nine o'clock every evening, and that's quite apart from the work he does over the weekend.
learner_examples: So, when he started to speak, I couldn't understand anything apart from "thanks". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: separated by a space, distance or period of time
dictionary_examples: Stand with your feet wide apart.
How far apart should the speakers be?
We were asked to stand in two lines three metres apart.
I forget the exact age difference between Mark and his brother - they're two or three years apart.
learner_examples: They are situated on the same street, only a hundred metres apart, on each side of the street. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If two people are apart, they are not in the same place together.
dictionary_examples: By this time my parents were living apart.
learner_examples: I'll always remember those two days which we spent together after such a long time living apart. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: into separate, smaller pieces
dictionary_examples: I took the motor apart to see how it worked.
My jacket is so old, it's coming apart.

pos_items.definition: to be complete opposites
dictionary_examples: They are poles apart in their attitudes to religion.
learner_examples: Soho at night seemed to be the nicest place on Earth, poles apart from my home town. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If a sports team is playing away, the game is at the place where the other team usually plays.
dictionary_examples: They were playing away.

pos_items.definition: at or to the back of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Close the door behind you.
Their office is behind the main building.
learner_examples: I think [we should meet] in front of the restaurant, behind the library. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: slower or less successful than someone or something
dictionary_examples: The project is already behind schedule.
Arsenal are six points behind Manchester United with three matches still to play.
learner_examples: Secondly, the show did not start until 20:15 pm. That was almost one hour behind schedule. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: giving your help or support to someone
dictionary_examples: The group is 100 percent behind her.
learner_examples: He is very nice because if you have problems he is always behind you to help you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: in prison
dictionary_examples: He will spend the rest of his life behind bars.
learner_examples: In the darkness, Lew Kuan Yee had sworn revenge against Michael, the detective who had sent him behind bars. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If a bad experience or your own bad behaviour is behind you, it does not exist or affect your life now.
dictionary_examples: He's put his criminal past behind him.
learner_examples: We have got to put the past behind us. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: causing something, or responsible for something
dictionary_examples: What was the reason behind her decision to leave?
learner_examples: Another reason behind this kind of thinking is that some boys feel a[w]kward when they see girls and they think they are being ignored in the class. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: If you do something behind someone's back, you do it without them knowing, often in an unfair way.
dictionary_examples: Have they been saying things about me behind my back?
learner_examples: The food must be perfect, too, or else her mother-in-law and my father's sisters will think that she's not a proper wife, and will probably say insulting things about her behind her back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: privately and not in public
dictionary_examples: Most of the deals were done behind closed doors.
learner_examples: Decisions which affect the whole world are made behind closed doors and are top secret. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If something happens behind the scenes, it happens secretly.
dictionary_examples: A lot of hard work has been going on behind the scenes.
learner_examples: Ms. Bolam knew a lot of things going on behind the scenes, [which were] not [known to] the patients. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: at or to the back of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Somebody grabbed me from behind.
learner_examples: An old man appeared from behind wearing the same clothes [as] the owner of the phone and asked [her] for it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in the place where someone or something was before
dictionary_examples: I was annoyed to discover that I'd left my bag behind.
After the party a few people stayed behind to help clear up.
learner_examples: The bus driver told him that a suitcase was left behind because nobody claimed it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: slower or later than someone else, or than you should be
dictionary_examples: She's behind with the rent.
learner_examples: Those children who do not get this at home are the ones who are behind in their schoolwork. (International English Language Testing System; B2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: not fashionable or modern
dictionary_examples: Dad's a bit behind the times.
learner_examples: We [should] improve our equipment. Otherwise we will be behind the times. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

dictionary_examples: His marks in English have been below average for some time now.
The temperature has fallen below zero/freezing recently.
learner_examples: We have to learn that [it] is not natural for a lion [to be] living in a country where, in winter, [the] temperature can fall below zero. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: lower in rank
dictionary_examples: Monica is a grade below me.
learner_examples: [With] him being only 37 years old and [having] been promoted to the second level below the board of directors of a well-known international company, he seems like a good example [of] a successful person, at least in this area of success. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: next to someone or something
dictionary_examples: A car pulled up alongside ours.
learner_examples: The skyline [is] filled with huge chimneys displacing tons of gases into the air; millions of vehicles [are] moving on a highway alongside a dead river, where life flourished a few decades ago. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: together with someone
dictionary_examples: She enjoyed working alongside such famous actors.
learner_examples: Also he worked alongside me at another travel agency for 6 months. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: on the other side of something
dictionary_examples: In the distance, beyond the river, was a small town.
learner_examples: Suddenly she recognized something red, beyond a tree and covered with some leaves. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: continuing after a particular time or date
dictionary_examples: Few people live beyond the age of a hundred.
We cannot allow the work to continue beyond the end of the year.
learner_examples: You should take a [break] every two hours because, beyond two hours, your mind cannot record what you are learning. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: not able to be changed by me/us, etc.
dictionary_examples: Tonight's performance has been cancelled due to circumstances beyond our control.
learner_examples: This is a story about an event that turned out to be beyond my control. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: too bad, good, difficult, etc. to be real
dictionary_examples: The evil of this man is beyond belief.
learner_examples: It was a piece of luck beyond belief that we could swap our apartments for the six months to come. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: certain or certainly
dictionary_examples: Her skill is beyond dispute.
He is beyond dispute the finest actor in Hollywood today.
learner_examples: It is beyond dispute that we owe a lot to the wise scientists who discovered 'electro-magnetism'. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: involving or affecting other things or people than the ones you have talked about
dictionary_examples: You should try to develop interests beyond the family.
learner_examples: Of course, the process of women['s] liberation isn't viewed with enthusiasm by husbands who would have to wash up and cook if their wives wanted to develop women interests beyond their family circle. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something is beyond you, you cannot understand it.
dictionary_examples: Computer studies is completely beyond me.
It's beyond me why anyone would want to buy that house.
learner_examples: Lastly, touching upon the subject of the money, how you get the figure of 60% is beyond me, as I have a clear chart of the charity day results. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: bigger or better than anything you could imagine or hope for
dictionary_examples: The house was beyond my wildest dreams.
learner_examples: [It] was beyond my wildest dreams. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: not possible for someone to have
dictionary_examples: With all this money we can buy things previously beyond our reach.
learner_examples: She was always yearning for things beyond her reach. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: past a place
dictionary_examples: From the top of the hill we could see our house and the woods beyond.
learner_examples: The airport-bus will take you to the centre of Ostersund where I live and even beyond. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: continuing after a particular time or date
dictionary_examples: The strike looks set to continue into March and beyond.
learner_examples: The fact of living longer allow[s] people to share part of their lives with their children, their grandchildren and sometimes even one generation beyond. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: in a different place, position or situation
dictionary_examples: Just go away and leave me alone!
Would you like your burger to eat in or take away?
She's away on holiday until the end of the week.
Keep/Stay away from him.
learner_examples: I have [an] important exam on your wedding day [in] another city far away from my city. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: at a particular distance from a place
dictionary_examples: The nearest town was ten miles away.
The office is a half-hour drive away.
We live 5 km away from the coast.
learner_examples: I like it because its remote control could control distances [of] 1 or 2 meters away. (Key English Test; A2; Bengali)

pos_items.definition: in or into the usual or a suitable place, especially one that can be closed
dictionary_examples: Could you put the ice-cream away in the freezer?
My grandparents had £800 hidden away in an old shoe box.
learner_examples: I put away my mobile phone. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: at a particular time in the future
dictionary_examples: My English exam's only a week away and I haven't even started to prepare.
learner_examples: Christmas is just a few months away, and I do not inten[d] to spend it all alone like in the past few years, so I am writing to invite you [to] my real Christmas party without my parents. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: gradually disappearing until mostly or completely gone
dictionary_examples: All the snow had melted away.
The music faded away as the procession moved slowly up the street.
learner_examples: I always feel so fatigued at the end of the day but after a mile, the aches of the day seem to fade away. (First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used after a verb to mean 'continuously or repeatedly'
dictionary_examples: Chris was hammering away in the garden all day.
learner_examples: They chatted away for a while as Malcolm had to wait for the airport taxi. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: If a sports team is playing away, the game is at the place where the other team usually plays.
dictionary_examples: They were playing away.

pos_items.definition: in or to a foreign country
dictionary_examples: He's currently abroad on business.
We always go abroad in the summer.
learner_examples: I have never been abroad. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: on or onto a plane, ship, bus, or train
dictionary_examples: Welcome aboard flight BA109 to Paris.
learner_examples: Competition entry "Welcome aboard on the flight to ancient Rome..." Please fasten your seatbelts... (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: (comparative of good) of a higher quality, more effective, or more enjoyable than something or someone else
dictionary_examples: She's found a better job.
The film was better than I expected.
She is much better at tennis than I am.
If you cook it this way it's far better.
Relations between the two countries have never been better.
He stood near the front to get a better view.
The situation is getting better all the time.
The longer you keep this wine, the better it tastes.
The bed was hard, but it was better than nothing.
learner_examples: It is a better pen than others. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: healthy, or less ill than before
dictionary_examples: Are you better now?
Is your stomach ache better?
I hope you get better soon.
learner_examples: I visited my cousin last night in hospital. He is better now. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: (comparative ofwell) to a greater degree, or in a more successful or more effective way
dictionary_examples: I'd like to get to know him better.
Helen did much better than I did in the exam.
learner_examples: But she expl[ained everything] very clear[ly], so I understood better. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.sense_title: I/you/he, etc. had better do sth ()
pos_items.definition: used to say what someone should do
dictionary_examples: You'd better hurry or you'll miss the train.
He'd better not be late.
learner_examples: You'd better bring a notebook. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to have enough experience not to do something stupid or something that will not achieve anything
dictionary_examples: I thought she'd listen to me - I should have known better.
learner_examples: Surely two grown-ups should have known better than to shout at each other at the top of their lungs. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: with great attention
dictionary_examples: She carefully folded the letter and put it in her pocket.
Drive carefully on those icy roads.
It was a carefully prepared speech.
learner_examples: Look at it carefully. (Key English Test; A2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is easy to see, hear, read or understand
dictionary_examples: He spoke very clearly.
learner_examples: I can't see clearly without them. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not confused
dictionary_examples: I'd had two hours' sleep and wasn't thinking clearly.
learner_examples: But I don't remember clearly. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you think something is obvious or certain
dictionary_examples: The accident was clearly the lorry driver's fault.
Clearly, he's very talented.
learner_examples: It was clearly not for me, because it came from a girl called Carol who wanted to talk to some guy named John. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in an accurate way
dictionary_examples: The plans should be drawn as accurately as possible, showing all the measurements.
learner_examples: It's necessary to consider a lot of aspects to answer this question accurately, but in general I would prefer to go to work by bicycle. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: for a short time
dictionary_examples: We chatted briefly about the weather.
learner_examples: In this essay, I shall briefly look at the advantages and disadvantages of ow[n]ing a car. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: by chance or by mistake
dictionary_examples: She accidentally knocked over a glass of water.
learner_examples: I accidentally broke one of your vases - the most beautiful one. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a way that involves positive action
dictionary_examples: He's very actively involved in the local Labour Party.
I've been actively looking for a job for six months.
learner_examples: There's statistic[al] evidence that maths can train a brain to study actively. (First Certificate in English; B2; Mongolian)

pos_items.definition: in addition
dictionary_examples: Additionally, we request a deposit of $200 in advance.
learner_examples: Additionally, I am very interested in helping an organization that's trying to protect [the] environment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Mongolian)

pos_items.definition: once every year
dictionary_examples: Your starting salary is £28,000 per year and will be reviewed annually.
learner_examples: Dear Mr Benson, I am writing with regard to your letter, in which you asked me to give you some pieces of advice for the special events which take place in the College annually. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is appropriate
dictionary_examples: She didn't think we were appropriately dressed for a wedding.
learner_examples: I enjoyed reading it and I think it appropriately describes the atmosphere of that lovely town. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in an artificial way
dictionary_examples: Most mushrooms sold in supermarkets have been grown artificially in manure.
learner_examples: Zoos are part of nature, despite the fact that they are created artificially. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: If a machine does something automatically, it does it independently, without human control.
dictionary_examples: The camera adjusts the shutter speed automatically.
learner_examples: [The] television will be automatically switched on in time for [the] breakfast news. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If you do something automatically, you do it without thinking about it.
dictionary_examples: I automatically put my hand out to catch it.
learner_examples: There was a strange envelope between the others, so automatically, she picked it up and [looked at] the stamp. The letter came from Australia. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: in the most important ways
dictionary_examples: These two machines are basically the same, but you get a few extra features in the more expensive one.
The car's basically sound, but the paintwork needs a bit of attention.
learner_examples: Although they will offer some hot meals at any time, most of the food provided is basically fast food and snacks. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce a short explanation about something
dictionary_examples: Basically, what he's saying is that we need more time.
learner_examples: Basically, we spend half our leisure time being stuck to a screen and leading [a] so-called co[u]ch potato lifestyle. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a casual way
dictionary_examples: She was dressed casually in shorts and a T-shirt.
learner_examples: I suggest that you and your group go dressed casually. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a general way and not including everything or everyone
dictionary_examples: The plans have been broadly accepted.
Broadly speaking, don't you think women make better drivers than men?
learner_examples: The car is a marvellous means of transport as far as mobility, freedom, speed and comfort are concerned but it is now broadly acknowledged that it is inappropriate for the [short journeys] in our big cities. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is directly connected or has a strong relationship
dictionary_examples: English and German are closely related.
Both politicians have been closely associated with the movement for some time.
We are working closely with the police.
learner_examples: The main reason I am applying for this job is that this job would be very rewarding on [a] personal level and would give me useful experience closely related to my field of study. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is very near in distance, time, or position
dictionary_examples: Elke came into the room, closely followed by her children.
learner_examples: According to statistical figures, Germany is better off as compared to [the] USA and closely followed by Spain in the management of Government spending. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Marathi)

pos_items.definition: carefully and paying attention to details
dictionary_examples: Pollution levels are closely monitored.
If you look closely, you can see where he painted over his signature.
learner_examples: I think that working for High Travel as its inte[r]preter would be a great experience if the company decides to look closely at the co[n]ditions of its employees and of its travellers. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is directly connected or has a strong relationship
dictionary_examples: English and German are closely related.
Both politicians have been closely associated with the movement for some time.
We are working closely with the police.
learner_examples: The main reason I am applying for this job is that this job would be very rewarding on [a] personal level and would give me useful experience closely related to my field of study. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is very near in distance, time, or position
dictionary_examples: Elke came into the room, closely followed by her children.
learner_examples: According to statistical figures, Germany is better off as compared to [the] USA and closely followed by Spain in the management of Government spending. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Marathi)

pos_items.definition: carefully and paying attention to details
dictionary_examples: Pollution levels are closely monitored.
If you look closely, you can see where he painted over his signature.
learner_examples: I think that working for High Travel as its inte[r]preter would be a great experience if the company decides to look closely at the co[n]ditions of its employees and of its travellers. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: relating to a particular subject or person
dictionary_examples: What's she talking about?
I've got a book about Jung.
learner_examples: I like my IT course becaus[e] I want to learn about computers. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used when suggesting or offering something to someone
dictionary_examples: How about a trip to the zoo this afternoon?
"Coffee, Sarah?" "No, thanks." "What about you, Kate?"
How about cycling there?
learner_examples: What about going on Saturday? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to ask for someone's opinion on a particular subject
dictionary_examples: What about Ava - is she nice?
So the town was nice - how about the food?
learner_examples: I also enjoy shopping for shoes, what about you? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: a little more or less than the stated number or amount
dictionary_examples: It happened about two months ago.
"What time are you leaving work today?" "About five."
learner_examples: It's not far [from] my home, about 20 minut[es'] walk, [or] 5 minut[es] by bus. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: to or in different parts of a place, often without purpose or order
dictionary_examples: They heard someone moving/walking about outside.

pos_items.definition: to be going to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: I was about to leave when Mark arrived.
learner_examples: When I was just about to cross the road, I realised that I was going to faint [at] any moment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: once more
dictionary_examples: Could you spell your name again, please?
Throw it away and start again.
learner_examples: Thank you again. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: as before
dictionary_examples: Get some rest and you'll soon be well again.
learner_examples: Unfortunately, it started to rain when we were leaving the town, but five minutes later the weather became warm again. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: many times
dictionary_examples: He played the same song again and again.
learner_examples: I read it again and again and was more and more surprised. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: again
dictionary_examples: Once again I'm left with all the washing-up!
learner_examples: Once again I'm sorry. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: repeated from the beginning
dictionary_examples: We had to start all over again.
learner_examples: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: again after something has happened or been done many times before
dictionary_examples: The bus was late yet again.
learner_examples: Tom, thank you so much yet again for your interest. This talk is very important to me and to count on you is an honour for our college. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when adding a fact to something you have just said
dictionary_examples: I failed my history test - but then again, I didn't do much studying for it.
learner_examples: The fact that people live longer nowadays does have some advantages, but then again it also causes a lot of problems. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: in addition
dictionary_examples: She's a photographer and also writes books.
I'm cold, and I'm also hungry and tired.
learner_examples: I also have a dog and I like to go for a walk with [him]. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: every time, or at all times
dictionary_examples: I always walk to work.
learner_examples: I always tr[y] to do [my] best, bec[a]use I want to be a good student. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: at all times in the past
dictionary_examples: We've always lived here.
learner_examples: The best present was a mobile phone. I've always wanted it!!! (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: forever
dictionary_examples: I'll always remember you.
learner_examples: That was the best weekend [of] my life. I'll always remember it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian)

pos_items.definition: used to suggest something
dictionary_examples: You can always stay with us if you miss your train.
learner_examples: Watching them painting is better than seeing their art in any museum, and you can always do some sightseeing through our historical ruins, our mountains or villages. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: again and again, often in an annoying way
dictionary_examples: He's always losing his keys.
learner_examples: I am always trying to convince my friend Maria of these dangers. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a time between twelve o'clock at night and twelve o'clock in the middle of the day
dictionary_examples: We're open between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. daily.
The first election results are expected around 1 a.m.
learner_examples: I go to college [from] 9.15 a.m. to 12.15 p.m. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Panjabi)

pos_items.definition: (superlative of good) better than any other
dictionary_examples: She was my best friend.
This is the best meal I've ever had.
He's one of our best students.
Are you sure this is the best way of doing it?
Your parents only want what is best for you.
learner_examples: She likes [to] meet me every day because we are best friend[s]. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali)

pos_items.definition: something that you write at the end of a letter
dictionary_examples: With best wishes, Anna
learner_examples: With best wishes, (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: the thing that is best, if you cannot have or do the thing you really want
dictionary_examples: Coaching football is the next best thing to playing.
learner_examples: For many working people, there is hardly time to cook and prepare your dinner, so the next best thing is to rush into a Macdonalds' or Burger King. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Yapese)

pos_items.definition: Someone’s best bet is the action most likely to be successful.
dictionary_examples: If you want to get to the theater on time, your best bet is to get a cab.
learner_examples: The international cuisine chef can whip up some delicious creations from time to time; but your best bet is to go for one of the delicious steaks served. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: (superlative ofwell) most, or more than any other
dictionary_examples: Which of the songs did you like best?
They were the best-dressed couple at the party.
learner_examples: I like Australia best. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: (superlative ofwell) in the most suitable or satisfactory way
dictionary_examples: I sleep best with the window open.
The Grand Canyon is best seen at sunset when it seems to change colour.
learner_examples: It would be best if you c[a]me on Wednesday 27th. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: to be the most suitable person to have responsibility and make important decisions
dictionary_examples: When it comes to dealing with my own son, I think I know best.
learner_examples: How true is that expression "Father knows best". If my father [was alive] today he would probably be laughing his head off. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you hope someone will be happy, healthy, successful, etc., often when saying goodbye
dictionary_examples: All the best, then - it was nice to meet you!
Please wish him all the best for his new job.
learner_examples: I want to wish you all the best! (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: someone or something that is better than any other
dictionary_examples: I like all of Hitchcock's films, but I think 'Notorious' is the best.
Chris and I are the best of friends.
learner_examples: The trip was the best I have ever been [on] in my life. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: at the highest level of achievement or quality
dictionary_examples: The article is an example of journalism at its best.
learner_examples: I enjoyed this trip because we got to stay in the countryside and [see] nature at its very best. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to make the greatest effort possible
dictionary_examples: I did my best to persuade him.
learner_examples: And the police said that they will try their best. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: to try to be positive about a situation you do not like but cannot change
dictionary_examples: Our hotel room is rather small, but we'll just have to make the best of it.
learner_examples: Unfortunately I don't have very much spare time so we will have to arrange it carefully in order to make the best of your time in London. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to have the advantages of two different situations
dictionary_examples: Living in the country and working in the city you have the best of both worlds.
learner_examples: Only those that can afford to live in the suburban areas can combine the best of both worlds and they tend to be rather affluent. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to show that the most positive way of considering something is still not good
dictionary_examples: At best, only 50 per cent of babies born at 24 weeks will survive.
learner_examples: Then, due to the social standards, the old find themselves being abandoned and helpless. At best, such people are hospitalized. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something is for the best, it seems unpleasant now, but will improve a situation in the future.
dictionary_examples: Divorce is always painful, but it really was for the best.
learner_examples: It's a kind of sad thing to think about but maybe it's for the best. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.sense_title: bring out the best in sb
pos_items.definition: to cause someone's best qualities to show
dictionary_examples: This chance to work with young people has really brought out the best in him.
learner_examples: TV can be a baby-sitter, but such a relationship is not going to bring out the best in a child. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that something is not good when it is the best it can be
dictionary_examples: He's not exactly patient at the best of times.
learner_examples: They knew that even at the best of times he looked unpleasant but now he was of [a] completely different [appearance]. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: when a time or event has happened
dictionary_examples: Shall we go for a walk after breakfast?
We had a chat after the meeting.
Let's get the shopping. After that, we can stop for a coffee.
After a while, I began to like him.
His birthday is exactly a week after mine.
It was so boring, I left after ten minutes.
learner_examples: You can go shopping, eat [a tasty] meal and after that you can go to the disco and dance all night. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: when you have gone past a particular place
dictionary_examples: Turn left after the hotel.
You want the turning on the right just after the police station.
learner_examples: You can go to a wonderful place near here, The Great Falls. This is a very good place because you can [do] extreme sports. It is just after the town, on Main Road. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: following in order
dictionary_examples: H comes after G in the alphabet.

pos_items.definition: following someone or something
dictionary_examples: We ran after him but he escaped.
learner_examples: I ran after the bus and shouted to her 'hurry up!' (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to add information that shows that what you have just said is true
dictionary_examples: You can't expect to be perfect - after all, it was only your first lesson.
learner_examples: I stopped talking with my friends, but not [for long] - after all, we are friends. Anyway, I'm planning nice things for the next April 1st. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.sense_title: day after day/year after year, etc.
pos_items.definition: happening every day/year, etc. over a long period
dictionary_examples: We went to the same part of France for our holidays year after year.
learner_examples: And there she was, day after day, walking in the rain... (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: because of something that happened
dictionary_examples: I'll never trust her again after what she did to me.
learner_examples: I really needed those days after what I've been through this spring. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: despite
dictionary_examples: I can't believe he was so rude to you after all the help you've given him!
learner_examples: But, even after earning more in 2001, the women still do not earn as much [as] men on average earned (£20,363) in 1997. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Gujarati)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something happened or was true although you did not expect it to happen or be true
dictionary_examples: Helen couldn't come to the party after all.
learner_examples: Cars still enter the city so there will be pollution after all. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: used when giving someone or something the same name as another person or thing
dictionary_examples: It was called the Biko building, after the famous South African.
learner_examples: I called her Lena after my sister. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: later than someone or something else
dictionary_examples: Hilary got here at midday and Nicholas arrived soon after.
I can't go next week - how about the week after?
learner_examples: Hi Joe, I would love to see the film with you. We must have dinner after. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: at a later time than something else happens
