pos_items.definition: at a later time, after something else has happened
dictionary_examples: We had tea, and afterwards we sat in the garden for a while.
They separated, and soon/shortly afterwards Jane left the country.
learner_examples: Why don't we go for a pizza afterwards? (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: once more
dictionary_examples: Could you spell your name again, please?
Throw it away and start again.
learner_examples: Thank you again. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: as before
dictionary_examples: Get some rest and you'll soon be well again.
learner_examples: Unfortunately, it started to rain when we were leaving the town, but five minutes later the weather became warm again. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: many times
dictionary_examples: He played the same song again and again.
learner_examples: I read it again and again and was more and more surprised. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: again
dictionary_examples: Once again I'm left with all the washing-up!
learner_examples: Once again I'm sorry. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: repeated from the beginning
dictionary_examples: We had to start all over again.
learner_examples: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: again after something has happened or been done many times before
dictionary_examples: The bus was late yet again.
learner_examples: Tom, thank you so much yet again for your interest. This talk is very important to me and to count on you is an honour for our college. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when adding a fact to something you have just said
dictionary_examples: I failed my history test - but then again, I didn't do much studying for it.
learner_examples: The fact that people live longer nowadays does have some advantages, but then again it also causes a lot of problems. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a time in the past
dictionary_examples: He left the house over an hour ago.
We left London ten years ago.
About five months ago, I got a letter from him.
The dinosaurs died out 65 million years ago.
learner_examples: Two months ago I booked a trip to Malta. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If something happened long ago, it happened a great amount of time ago.
dictionary_examples: I think we met once, long ago.
It was not long ago that I last saw him.
learner_examples: Not so long ago, you could ring each Dutch doorbell of your choice at 6 pm and you'd f[i]nd the whole family gathered around the kitchen table, having their supper. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: every person or thing in a group
dictionary_examples: I've seen all of his films.
All of us had left by midnight.
She's got four children, all under the age of five.
"Which of his books did you like best?" "I loved them all."
learner_examples: I hope you are all well. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: the whole of a period of time

learner_examples: I spent all day [at the] beach. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: the whole amount of something

pos_items.definition: many different types of something
dictionary_examples: They had all sorts of jewellery for sale.

learner_examples: I like all sorts of music but I prefer urban music! (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you hope someone will be happy, healthy, successful, etc., often when saying goodbye
dictionary_examples: All the best, then - it was nice to meet you!

pos_items.definition: the only thing

pos_items.definition: used for emphasis in questions or negative statements, to mean in any way or of any type

dictionary_examples: Above all, I'd like to thank my family.

learner_examples: She is a very nice person and above all, she is really cheerful. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to add information that shows that what you have just said is true
dictionary_examples: You can't expect to be perfect - after all, it was only your first lesson.
learner_examples: I stopped talking with my friends, but not [for long] - after all, we are friends. Anyway, I'm planning nice things for the next April 1st. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: everything is in a good or acceptable state
dictionary_examples: I hope all is well with Jack.
learner_examples: I hope all's well. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show the total amount of something
dictionary_examples: Some of the children came, so there were 15 of us in all.

pos_items.definition: suddenly and unexpectedly

learner_examples: All of a sudden, a weird creature popped into his dream. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: repeated from the beginning
dictionary_examples: We had to start all over again.
learner_examples: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used for saying that other similar things are included or that the whole of a situation is considered
dictionary_examples: He told us about his school and all that.

pos_items.definition: many different types of people or things

pos_items.definition: completely or very

You're all wet!

pos_items.definition: everywhere in a particular place

pos_items.definition: used to say that two players or teams have the same number of points in a game
dictionary_examples: It was 3 all at half time.

learner_examples: Since I have already reserved a room for myself, I am now sitting [o]n the balcony, watching the beautiful views of the beach and tall pine trees. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: in total
dictionary_examples: There were twenty people there altogether.
That'll be £52.50 altogether, please.
learner_examples: They cost 1700 baht altogether. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: completely
dictionary_examples: She wrote less and less often, and eventually she stopped altogether.
I'm not altogether sure about the idea.
learner_examples: I don't altogether agree with this fact. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: when you consider everything
dictionary_examples: Altogether, I'd say the party was a great success.
learner_examples: Altogether, I believe that the most cruel creature on earth is the human being. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used in questions and negatives to mean some
dictionary_examples: "Is there any more soup?" "No, I'm afraid there isn't any left."
I haven't seen any of his films.
I asked Andrew for some change but he hasn't got any.
learner_examples: She doesn't [want] any more children. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali)

pos_items.definition: one of or each of a particular kind of person or thing when it is not important which
dictionary_examples: "Which of these cakes may I eat?" "Any."
Any of you should be able to answer this question.
Any advice that you can give me would be greatly appreciated.
We should hear from him any minute/day/time now.
There were a lot of computers at the exhibition, any (one) of which would have suited me perfectly.
learner_examples: When I [was a] child, I like[d] reading any cartoon book, so my parents bought many books for me. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Mandarin)

pos_items.definition: If you do not do something or something does not happen any more, you have stopped doing it or it does not now happen.
dictionary_examples: I don't do yoga any more.
learner_examples: I don't need it any more because I have a new one. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used in questions and negatives to emphasize a comparative adjective or adverb
dictionary_examples: Do you feel any better?
I can't walk any faster.
Those trousers don't look any different from the others.
Houses in this area used to be a real bargain, but they're not cheap any more.
This radio isn't any good - I'll have to buy another.
She couldn't wait any longer.
learner_examples: I couldn't wait any longer - I had to see Sami. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to surround or be on all sides of something, or in a circular movement
dictionary_examples: We sat around the table.
He put his arm around her.
The moon goes around the Earth.
I walked around the building.
learner_examples: You can go around the lake by train. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to or in different parts of a place
dictionary_examples: I spent a year travelling around Australia.
I used to live around here.
learner_examples: After that, we will walk around the shopping mall. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: about or approximately
dictionary_examples: around two months ago
around four o'clock
She earns around forty thousand a year.
learner_examples: I think I'll arrive around 6.00 p.m. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: to or in different parts of a place
dictionary_examples: I'm going to fly to Peru and travel around for six weeks.
She went into town and spent two hours just walking around.
learner_examples: Come and visit, I'll show you around. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: in a circle or with circular movement
dictionary_examples: She passed a plate of biscuits around.
This switch makes the wheels go around.
learner_examples: Hello, everybody. Please gather around. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to the opposite direction
dictionary_examples: Jonny turned around and looked at her.
The pianist spun around on the stool and faced his audience.
learner_examples: As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name. I turned around. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If someone is around, they are present in a place.
dictionary_examples: Will you be around next week?
Roger isn't around at the moment - can I help instead?
learner_examples: It was dark and not a soul was around. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: present or available
dictionary_examples: Mobile phones have been around for years now.
learner_examples: Major sporting competitions have been around for the better part of 2500 years, ever since the original Olympic Games were held in ancient Greece. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: where someone or something was before
dictionary_examples: When do you go back to college?
I put the tin back in the cupboard.
learner_examples: She [went] back home at once. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: as a reply or reaction to something
dictionary_examples: I'm busy at the moment - can I call you back?
I waved to her and she waved back.
learner_examples: Write back to me soon. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a direction behind you
dictionary_examples: He sat back on the sofa.
Anna stepped back.
learner_examples: I cried [out], stepping back and falling down. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to the state something or someone was in before
dictionary_examples: It's not badly broken - I'm sure we can put it back together again.
Hopefully things will get back to normal soon.
I was woken by a thunderstorm, and I couldn't get back to sleep.
learner_examples: My life was back to normal. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: at or to an earlier time
dictionary_examples: We first met back in 1971.
This tradition dates back to the 16th century.
learner_examples: All in all, it is difficult to get bored in Moscow, where you can see buildings which date back to centur[i]es ago. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a direction away from something
dictionary_examples: He pulled back the curtain.
The house is set back from the road.
learner_examples: The action of the book takes place in a lonely inn standing back from the road. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in one direction, then the opposite way, then in the original direction again many times
dictionary_examples: He has to travel back and forth between London and Paris every week.
learner_examples: Finally, after much walking back and forth, we found a road which we followed till we got to the town. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the part of something that is furthest from the front or in the opposite direction to the front
dictionary_examples: He wrote her email address down on the back of an envelope.
Our seats were right at the back of the theatre.
learner_examples: My cousins love mermaids, so each sweater has one on the back. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the part of your body from your shoulders to your bottom
dictionary_examples: back injuries/pain
I've got a bad back.
He lay on his back, staring at the ceiling.
learner_examples: The look on his face stopped me cold, as if someone had just poured freezing water down my back. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: with the back part of something where the front should be
dictionary_examples: You've got your trousers on back to front.
learner_examples: Therefore, the government needs to cut expenditure and as a result of this, health faciliti[es] will only be accessible for rich people. Then we are back to front. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: If you do something behind someone's back, you do it without them knowing, often in an unfair way.
dictionary_examples: Have they been saying things about me behind my back?
learner_examples: The food must be perfect, too, or else her mother-in-law and my father's sisters will think that she's not a proper wife, and will probably say insulting things about her behind her back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to decide to stop having contact with someone or something, or to refuse to help someone
dictionary_examples: She turned her back on Hollywood and went to live in Florida.
learner_examples: She gets to learn that Olivia turned her back on her past and merged totally with India through her attraction to and sympathy for the Nawab. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: be (like) water off a duck's back
pos_items.definition: If criticisms, insults, etc. are like water off a duck's back to you, they do not affect you at all.
dictionary_examples: She calls him lazy and useless, but it's like water off a duck's back.
learner_examples: The main lesson I have learned is by looking at some people who have lived alone for most of their life and faced with neither contradiction nor argument, they stay in their ivory tower, so sure of their opinions that whatever you say is like water off a duck's back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: at or near the back of something
dictionary_examples: a back door/garden
the back page/seat
I put it in the back pocket of my jeans.
learner_examples: There are two movies, but one is for adults so we will see "The back garden". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: a very small road or street that goes behind or between buildings
dictionary_examples: We wandered through the back streets, looking for Tommy.
learner_examples: From the museum you have to walk across a pedestrian street, through an unspoiled district, where a jumble of narrow back streets retain old-world characters. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: to move backwards or drive backwards
dictionary_examples: She saw he had a gun and backed away.
He backed into a wall when he was trying to park.
learner_examples: When he backed out of the [car park] he almost crashed into another car. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to give support or help to a person, plan, or idea
dictionary_examples: He backed Mr Clark in the recent election.
Parents backed the idea by more than two to one.
learner_examples: Of course, without [the] people wh[o] are backing the leader in his fight, he could not achieve his success. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: towards the direction behind you
dictionary_examples: I walked backwards towards the door.
He took a step backwards to allow her to pass.
learner_examples: Very often, for example on Friday afternoon or Saturday, there are so many people in a shopping centre that you can't move forwards or backwards. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: at or to the back of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Close the door behind you.
Their office is behind the main building.
learner_examples: I think [we should meet] in front of the restaurant, behind the library. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: slower or less successful than someone or something
dictionary_examples: The project is already behind schedule.
Arsenal are six points behind Manchester United with three matches still to play.
learner_examples: Secondly, the show did not start until 20:15 pm. That was almost one hour behind schedule. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: giving your help or support to someone
dictionary_examples: The group is 100 percent behind her.
learner_examples: He is very nice because if you have problems he is always behind you to help you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: in prison
dictionary_examples: He will spend the rest of his life behind bars.
learner_examples: In the darkness, Lew Kuan Yee had sworn revenge against Michael, the detective who had sent him behind bars. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If a bad experience or your own bad behaviour is behind you, it does not exist or affect your life now.
dictionary_examples: He's put his criminal past behind him.
learner_examples: We have got to put the past behind us. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: causing something, or responsible for something
dictionary_examples: What was the reason behind her decision to leave?
learner_examples: Another reason behind this kind of thinking is that some boys feel a[w]kward when they see girls and they think they are being ignored in the class. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: If you do something behind someone's back, you do it without them knowing, often in an unfair way.
dictionary_examples: Have they been saying things about me behind my back?
learner_examples: The food must be perfect, too, or else her mother-in-law and my father's sisters will think that she's not a proper wife, and will probably say insulting things about her behind her back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: privately and not in public
dictionary_examples: Most of the deals were done behind closed doors.
learner_examples: Decisions which affect the whole world are made behind closed doors and are top secret. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If something happens behind the scenes, it happens secretly.
dictionary_examples: A lot of hard work has been going on behind the scenes.
learner_examples: Ms. Bolam knew a lot of things going on behind the scenes, [which were] not [known to] the patients. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: at or to the back of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Somebody grabbed me from behind.
learner_examples: An old man appeared from behind wearing the same clothes [as] the owner of the phone and asked [her] for it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in the place where someone or something was before
dictionary_examples: I was annoyed to discover that I'd left my bag behind.
After the party a few people stayed behind to help clear up.
learner_examples: The bus driver told him that a suitcase was left behind because nobody claimed it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: slower or later than someone else, or than you should be
dictionary_examples: She's behind with the rent.
learner_examples: Those children who do not get this at home are the ones who are behind in their schoolwork. (International English Language Testing System; B2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: not fashionable or modern
dictionary_examples: Dad's a bit behind the times.
learner_examples: We [should] improve our equipment. Otherwise we will be behind the times. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to something or someone
dictionary_examples: Do you play any other sports besides football and basketball?
learner_examples: It's a Chinese food buffet but besides Chinese food they also have Italian food like pizza. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to give another reason for something
dictionary_examples: She won't mind your being late - besides, it's hardly your fault.
learner_examples: I think that I'm going to buy "Troy" because it looks to me [to be] a great movie - besides, it reminds me of your vacations in Mexico. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to
dictionary_examples: Besides looking after the children, she runs a successful business.
learner_examples: But besides playing, you can also sit [i]n the "club lounge", where you can drink something with your friends or just play cards. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: (superlative of good) better than any other
dictionary_examples: She was my best friend.
This is the best meal I've ever had.
He's one of our best students.
Are you sure this is the best way of doing it?
Your parents only want what is best for you.
learner_examples: She likes [to] meet me every day because we are best friend[s]. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali)

pos_items.definition: something that you write at the end of a letter
dictionary_examples: With best wishes, Anna
learner_examples: With best wishes, (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: the thing that is best, if you cannot have or do the thing you really want
dictionary_examples: Coaching football is the next best thing to playing.
learner_examples: For many working people, there is hardly time to cook and prepare your dinner, so the next best thing is to rush into a Macdonalds' or Burger King. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Yapese)

pos_items.definition: Someone’s best bet is the action most likely to be successful.
dictionary_examples: If you want to get to the theater on time, your best bet is to get a cab.
learner_examples: The international cuisine chef can whip up some delicious creations from time to time; but your best bet is to go for one of the delicious steaks served. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: (superlative ofwell) most, or more than any other
dictionary_examples: Which of the songs did you like best?
They were the best-dressed couple at the party.
learner_examples: I like Australia best. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: (superlative ofwell) in the most suitable or satisfactory way
dictionary_examples: I sleep best with the window open.
The Grand Canyon is best seen at sunset when it seems to change colour.
learner_examples: It would be best if you c[a]me on Wednesday 27th. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: to be the most suitable person to have responsibility and make important decisions
dictionary_examples: When it comes to dealing with my own son, I think I know best.
learner_examples: How true is that expression "Father knows best". If my father [was alive] today he would probably be laughing his head off. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you hope someone will be happy, healthy, successful, etc., often when saying goodbye
dictionary_examples: All the best, then - it was nice to meet you!
Please wish him all the best for his new job.
learner_examples: I want to wish you all the best! (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: someone or something that is better than any other
dictionary_examples: I like all of Hitchcock's films, but I think 'Notorious' is the best.
Chris and I are the best of friends.
learner_examples: The trip was the best I have ever been [on] in my life. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: at the highest level of achievement or quality
dictionary_examples: The article is an example of journalism at its best.
learner_examples: I enjoyed this trip because we got to stay in the countryside and [see] nature at its very best. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to make the greatest effort possible
dictionary_examples: I did my best to persuade him.
learner_examples: And the police said that they will try their best. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: to try to be positive about a situation you do not like but cannot change
dictionary_examples: Our hotel room is rather small, but we'll just have to make the best of it.
learner_examples: Unfortunately I don't have very much spare time so we will have to arrange it carefully in order to make the best of your time in London. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to have the advantages of two different situations
dictionary_examples: Living in the country and working in the city you have the best of both worlds.
learner_examples: Only those that can afford to live in the suburban areas can combine the best of both worlds and they tend to be rather affluent. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to show that the most positive way of considering something is still not good
dictionary_examples: At best, only 50 per cent of babies born at 24 weeks will survive.
learner_examples: Then, due to the social standards, the old find themselves being abandoned and helpless. At best, such people are hospitalized. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something is for the best, it seems unpleasant now, but will improve a situation in the future.
dictionary_examples: Divorce is always painful, but it really was for the best.
learner_examples: It's a kind of sad thing to think about but maybe it's for the best. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.sense_title: bring out the best in sb
pos_items.definition: to cause someone's best qualities to show
dictionary_examples: This chance to work with young people has really brought out the best in him.
learner_examples: TV can be a baby-sitter, but such a relationship is not going to bring out the best in a child. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that something is not good when it is the best it can be
dictionary_examples: He's not exactly patient at the best of times.
learner_examples: They knew that even at the best of times he looked unpleasant but now he was of [a] completely different [appearance]. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: relating to a particular subject or person
dictionary_examples: What's she talking about?
I've got a book about Jung.
learner_examples: I like my IT course becaus[e] I want to learn about computers. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used when suggesting or offering something to someone
dictionary_examples: How about a trip to the zoo this afternoon?
"Coffee, Sarah?" "No, thanks." "What about you, Kate?"
How about cycling there?
learner_examples: What about going on Saturday? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to ask for someone's opinion on a particular subject
dictionary_examples: What about Ava - is she nice?
So the town was nice - how about the food?
learner_examples: I also enjoy shopping for shoes, what about you? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: a little more or less than the stated number or amount
dictionary_examples: It happened about two months ago.
"What time are you leaving work today?" "About five."
learner_examples: It's not far [from] my home, about 20 minut[es'] walk, [or] 5 minut[es] by bus. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: to or in different parts of a place, often without purpose or order
dictionary_examples: They heard someone moving/walking about outside.

pos_items.definition: to be going to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: I was about to leave when Mark arrived.
learner_examples: When I was just about to cross the road, I realised that I was going to faint [at] any moment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in front
dictionary_examples: Turn left at the traffic lights, and you'll see the hospital straight ahead.
learner_examples: Behind our school there was a beautiful forest and if you walked 200 meters straight ahead you would reach a clearing . (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in the future
dictionary_examples: She has a difficult time ahead of her.
learner_examples: Even if you're satisfied with your life now, take a look 10 or 20 years ahead. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: having more points than someone else in a competition
dictionary_examples: Barcelona was ahead after ten minutes.

pos_items.definition: making more progress than someone or something else
dictionary_examples: Sue is ahead of everyone else in French.
learner_examples: I have always been a couple of steps ahead of my schoolmates and peers, not only in terms of scholastic pursuits, but in my opinions and desires as well. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: before the time that was planned
dictionary_examples: We finished the project ahead of schedule.
learner_examples: However, a bonus will be given if the project finishes ahead of schedule. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: similar
dictionary_examples: The children all look very alike.
learner_examples: First of all, Jem and Joss Merlyn look alike physically. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in a similar way
dictionary_examples: We think alike.
My father treated us all alike.

pos_items.definition: used after referring to two groups of people or things to show that both groups are included
dictionary_examples: Friends and family alike were shocked by the news of her death.
learner_examples: It was indeed a great treat for old and young alike. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

I'm not altogether sure about the idea.

pos_items.definition: every time, or at all times
dictionary_examples: I always walk to work.
learner_examples: I always tr[y] to do [my] best, bec[a]use I want to be a good student. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: at all times in the past
dictionary_examples: We've always lived here.
learner_examples: The best present was a mobile phone. I've always wanted it!!! (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: forever
dictionary_examples: I'll always remember you.
learner_examples: That was the best weekend [of] my life. I'll always remember it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian)

pos_items.definition: used to suggest something

learner_examples: Watching them painting is better than seeing their art in any museum, and you can always do some sightseeing through our historical ruins, our mountains or villages. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: I took the motor apart to see how it worked.

pos_items.definition: to be complete opposites
dictionary_examples: They are poles apart in their attitudes to religion.
learner_examples: Soho at night seemed to be the nicest place on Earth, poles apart from my home town. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: on or to one side
dictionary_examples: Stand aside, please, and let these people pass.
He pulled the curtain aside.
I gave her a plate of food but she pushed it aside.
She took me aside to tell me the news.
learner_examples: I saw an old man slowly pull it aside and peep out, looking [at] the street with his eyes wide open. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: If you put or set something aside, you do not use it now, but keep it to use later.
dictionary_examples: We've put some money aside for the holiday.
learner_examples: I had put some money aside for a month, thinking about the discount. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: except for
dictionary_examples: This document needs finishing, but aside from that I think everything is done.
learner_examples: Secondly, it is unfair to say the other performers were second-rate aside from the 'Torrents', since they all sang and played very well. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a different place, position or situation
dictionary_examples: Just go away and leave me alone!
Would you like your burger to eat in or take away?
She's away on holiday until the end of the week.
Keep/Stay away from him.
learner_examples: I have [an] important exam on your wedding day [in] another city far away from my city. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: at a particular distance from a place
dictionary_examples: The nearest town was ten miles away.
The office is a half-hour drive away.
We live 5 km away from the coast.
learner_examples: I like it because its remote control could control distances [of] 1 or 2 meters away. (Key English Test; A2; Bengali)

pos_items.definition: in or into the usual or a suitable place, especially one that can be closed
dictionary_examples: Could you put the ice-cream away in the freezer?
My grandparents had £800 hidden away in an old shoe box.
learner_examples: I put away my mobile phone. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: at a particular time in the future
dictionary_examples: My English exam's only a week away and I haven't even started to prepare.
learner_examples: Christmas is just a few months away, and I do not inten[d] to spend it all alone like in the past few years, so I am writing to invite you [to] my real Christmas party without my parents. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: gradually disappearing until mostly or completely gone
dictionary_examples: All the snow had melted away.
The music faded away as the procession moved slowly up the street.
learner_examples: I always feel so fatigued at the end of the day but after a mile, the aches of the day seem to fade away. (First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used after a verb to mean 'continuously or repeatedly'
dictionary_examples: Chris was hammering away in the garden all day.
learner_examples: They chatted away for a while as Malcolm had to wait for the airport taxi. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: If a sports team is playing away, the game is at the place where the other team usually plays.
dictionary_examples: They were playing away.

pos_items.definition: where someone or something was before
dictionary_examples: When do you go back to college?
I put the tin back in the cupboard.
learner_examples: She [went] back home at once. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: as a reply or reaction to something
dictionary_examples: I'm busy at the moment - can I call you back?
I waved to her and she waved back.
learner_examples: Write back to me soon. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a direction behind you
dictionary_examples: He sat back on the sofa.
Anna stepped back.
learner_examples: I cried [out], stepping back and falling down. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to the state something or someone was in before
dictionary_examples: It's not badly broken - I'm sure we can put it back together again.
Hopefully things will get back to normal soon.
I was woken by a thunderstorm, and I couldn't get back to sleep.
learner_examples: My life was back to normal. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: at or to an earlier time
dictionary_examples: We first met back in 1971.
This tradition dates back to the 16th century.
learner_examples: All in all, it is difficult to get bored in Moscow, where you can see buildings which date back to centur[i]es ago. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a direction away from something
dictionary_examples: He pulled back the curtain.
The house is set back from the road.
learner_examples: The action of the book takes place in a lonely inn standing back from the road. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in one direction, then the opposite way, then in the original direction again many times
dictionary_examples: He has to travel back and forth between London and Paris every week.
learner_examples: Finally, after much walking back and forth, we found a road which we followed till we got to the town. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the part of something that is furthest from the front or in the opposite direction to the front
dictionary_examples: He wrote her email address down on the back of an envelope.
Our seats were right at the back of the theatre.
learner_examples: My cousins love mermaids, so each sweater has one on the back. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the part of your body from your shoulders to your bottom
dictionary_examples: back injuries/pain
I've got a bad back.
He lay on his back, staring at the ceiling.
learner_examples: The look on his face stopped me cold, as if someone had just poured freezing water down my back. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: with the back part of something where the front should be
dictionary_examples: You've got your trousers on back to front.
learner_examples: Therefore, the government needs to cut expenditure and as a result of this, health faciliti[es] will only be accessible for rich people. Then we are back to front. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: If you do something behind someone's back, you do it without them knowing, often in an unfair way.
dictionary_examples: Have they been saying things about me behind my back?
learner_examples: The food must be perfect, too, or else her mother-in-law and my father's sisters will think that she's not a proper wife, and will probably say insulting things about her behind her back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to decide to stop having contact with someone or something, or to refuse to help someone
dictionary_examples: She turned her back on Hollywood and went to live in Florida.
learner_examples: She gets to learn that Olivia turned her back on her past and merged totally with India through her attraction to and sympathy for the Nawab. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: be (like) water off a duck's back
pos_items.definition: If criticisms, insults, etc. are like water off a duck's back to you, they do not affect you at all.
dictionary_examples: She calls him lazy and useless, but it's like water off a duck's back.
learner_examples: The main lesson I have learned is by looking at some people who have lived alone for most of their life and faced with neither contradiction nor argument, they stay in their ivory tower, so sure of their opinions that whatever you say is like water off a duck's back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: at or near the back of something
dictionary_examples: a back door/garden
the back page/seat
I put it in the back pocket of my jeans.
learner_examples: There are two movies, but one is for adults so we will see "The back garden". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: a very small road or street that goes behind or between buildings
dictionary_examples: We wandered through the back streets, looking for Tommy.
learner_examples: From the museum you have to walk across a pedestrian street, through an unspoiled district, where a jumble of narrow back streets retain old-world characters. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: to move backwards or drive backwards
dictionary_examples: She saw he had a gun and backed away.
He backed into a wall when he was trying to park.
learner_examples: When he backed out of the [car park] he almost crashed into another car. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to give support or help to a person, plan, or idea
dictionary_examples: He backed Mr Clark in the recent election.
Parents backed the idea by more than two to one.
learner_examples: Of course, without [the] people wh[o] are backing the leader in his fight, he could not achieve his success. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: next to someone or something
dictionary_examples: A car pulled up alongside ours.
learner_examples: The skyline [is] filled with huge chimneys displacing tons of gases into the air; millions of vehicles [are] moving on a highway alongside a dead river, where life flourished a few decades ago. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: together with someone
dictionary_examples: She enjoyed working alongside such famous actors.
learner_examples: Also he worked alongside me at another travel agency for 6 months. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: at or to the back of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Close the door behind you.
Their office is behind the main building.
learner_examples: I think [we should meet] in front of the restaurant, behind the library. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: slower or less successful than someone or something
dictionary_examples: The project is already behind schedule.
Arsenal are six points behind Manchester United with three matches still to play.
learner_examples: Secondly, the show did not start until 20:15 pm. That was almost one hour behind schedule. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: giving your help or support to someone
dictionary_examples: The group is 100 percent behind her.
learner_examples: He is very nice because if you have problems he is always behind you to help you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: in prison
dictionary_examples: He will spend the rest of his life behind bars.
learner_examples: In the darkness, Lew Kuan Yee had sworn revenge against Michael, the detective who had sent him behind bars. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If a bad experience or your own bad behaviour is behind you, it does not exist or affect your life now.
dictionary_examples: He's put his criminal past behind him.
learner_examples: We have got to put the past behind us. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: causing something, or responsible for something
dictionary_examples: What was the reason behind her decision to leave?
learner_examples: Another reason behind this kind of thinking is that some boys feel a[w]kward when they see girls and they think they are being ignored in the class. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: If you do something behind someone's back, you do it without them knowing, often in an unfair way.
dictionary_examples: Have they been saying things about me behind my back?
learner_examples: The food must be perfect, too, or else her mother-in-law and my father's sisters will think that she's not a proper wife, and will probably say insulting things about her behind her back. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: privately and not in public
dictionary_examples: Most of the deals were done behind closed doors.
learner_examples: Decisions which affect the whole world are made behind closed doors and are top secret. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If something happens behind the scenes, it happens secretly.
dictionary_examples: A lot of hard work has been going on behind the scenes.
learner_examples: Ms. Bolam knew a lot of things going on behind the scenes, [which were] not [known to] the patients. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: at or to the back of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Somebody grabbed me from behind.
learner_examples: An old man appeared from behind wearing the same clothes [as] the owner of the phone and asked [her] for it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in the place where someone or something was before
dictionary_examples: I was annoyed to discover that I'd left my bag behind.
After the party a few people stayed behind to help clear up.
learner_examples: The bus driver told him that a suitcase was left behind because nobody claimed it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: slower or later than someone else, or than you should be
dictionary_examples: She's behind with the rent.
learner_examples: Those children who do not get this at home are the ones who are behind in their schoolwork. (International English Language Testing System; B2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: not fashionable or modern
dictionary_examples: Dad's a bit behind the times.
learner_examples: We [should] improve our equipment. Otherwise we will be behind the times. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: in the space that separates two places, people or objects
dictionary_examples: The town lies halfway between Rome and Florence.
Standing between the two adults was a small child.
She squeezed between the parked cars and ran out into the road.
A narrow path ran in between the two houses.
learner_examples: The cinema is between Laura's house and the post office. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in the period of time which separates two different events or times
dictionary_examples: You shouldn't eat between meals.
There is a break of ten minutes between classes.
The shop is closed for lunch between 12.30 and 1.30.
learner_examples: I will arrive between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: involving two or more groups of people
dictionary_examples: Tonight's game is between the New Orleans Saints and the Los Angeles Rams.
learner_examples: I would like to go shopping and then see the football match between Spain and Germany. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to show the largest and smallest amount or level of something
dictionary_examples: She weighs between 55 and 60 kilograms.
The competition is open to children between six and twelve years of age.
learner_examples: It's for young people aged between 18 and 30 years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Somali)

pos_items.definition: connecting two or more places, things or people
dictionary_examples: There is a regular train service between Glasgow and Edinburgh.
learner_examples: We need a motorway link between the motorways 74 and 9. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: separating two places or things
dictionary_examples: The wall between East and West Berlin came down in 1989.
The gap between the rich and the poor has increased dramatically over the past decade.
learner_examples: I think that the most interesting place near my town is [the] mountains [which are] like a wall between my country and China. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: among two or more people or things
dictionary_examples: We drank two bottles of wine between four of us.
learner_examples: I think you'll have to discuss the ideas between you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in the space that separates two people, places, or things
dictionary_examples: The wood is in neat piles with newspaper placed between.
learner_examples: There is a shuttle bus from the airport straight to the main station with only one stop in between. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: in the period of time that separates two events or times
dictionary_examples: There's a train at 6.15 and one at 10.30 but nothing in between.
learner_examples: Besides, there [is] research that prove[s] that people cannot work for more than two hours [at a time]. They can't concentrate that long [and] they need to rest their minds for short periods in between. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at, to or from a great distance in space or time
dictionary_examples: Is the station far away?
She doesn't live far from here.
How far away does your mother live?
How far is it from Australia to New Zealand?
Bournemouth is not far from Poole.
One day, perhaps far in/into the future, you'll regret what you've done.
learner_examples: It isn't so far from my house so we can go [on foot]. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: until now
dictionary_examples: So far we've made thirty-two thousand pounds.
learner_examples: So far I like it here very much. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian)

pos_items.definition: very much
dictionary_examples: This car is far better than our old one.
It cost far more (money) than I could afford.
He loses his temper far too often.
I'd far rather/sooner go to the theatre than watch a DVD.
learner_examples: I think restaurant B is far better than restaurant A. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you think something is true, but cannot be sure
dictionary_examples: As far as I know, he's never been in trouble with the police.
learner_examples: As far as I know, accommodation at Camp California is in tents or log cabins. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sb is concerned ()
pos_items.definition: used to say what someone's opinion is
dictionary_examples: It's all over as far as I'm concerned.
learner_examples: As far as I am concerned, Bernard is similar to him. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sth is concerned ()
pos_items.definition: used to say what you are talking about
dictionary_examples: As far as sport is concerned, I like tennis and football.
learner_examples: As far as studying abroad is concerned, I totally agree with this idea. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: by a great amount
dictionary_examples: They are by far the best students in the class.
learner_examples: I have travelled to many countries, but New Zealand is by far the best. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has gone well until now
dictionary_examples: It's the first time I've done any decorating, but so far so good.
learner_examples: So far so good, only no one told us they held this point of view before the actual christening took place. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: certainly not something
dictionary_examples: The situation is far from clear.
learner_examples: The quality of catering was far from ideal as well, as a meal in a hamburger restaurant can hardly be called a typical English lunch. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to tell someone that something is certainly not true
dictionary_examples: He's not handsome - far from it.
learner_examples: The Hotel Royal cannot be considered as being luxury - far from it - i.e. our rooms were dirty and situated [o]n the 4th floor without a lift. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about how true something is
dictionary_examples: How far do politicians represent the views of ordinary people?
learner_examples: How far and to what extent would the characteristics we are born with influence our future development in life? (International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: certainly not doing something
dictionary_examples: Far from being pleased, he was embarrassed by the praise.
learner_examples: Far from asking you to close the airport, which would be quite an irrational request, I am suggesting that you should take some action to improve the situation. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.sense_title: go so far as to do sth
pos_items.definition: to take the extreme action of doing something
dictionary_examples: He even went so far as to stop her using the telephone.
learner_examples: Our present course of action may go so far as to cause irrevers[i]ble damage not only to our planet but also to the people living upon [it]. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to behave in a way that upsets or annoys other people
dictionary_examples: He's said some stupid things in the past, but this time he's gone too far.
learner_examples: Lucia let her speak and calmly said: "You really have gone too far this time." (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not happening or existing very often
dictionary_examples: Opportunities like this are few and far between.
learner_examples: Jobs in those days were few and far between and for a number of years he was alternating between temporary jobs and unemployment benefit. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to be very different from something
dictionary_examples: The princess's world was far removed from reality.
learner_examples: It is the same problem with planned excursions to street markets in Asia, souks in Arabia or even tribes that are far removed from industrialized life in Papua New Guinea or the rainforest of Brazil. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: describes the part of something that is most distant from the centre or from you
dictionary_examples: His office is at the far end of the corridor.
The children ran to the far side/corner of the room.
learner_examples: The dark spot at the far end of the wall seemed to be coming after her this time. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.sense_title: be a far cry from sth
pos_items.definition: to be very different from something
dictionary_examples: Her luxury mansion is a far cry from the house she grew up in.
learner_examples: The museum was a far cry from what we expected. Not only were the machines really old and should have been replaced a long time ago, but they were boring as well. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to describe political groups whose opinions are very extreme
dictionary_examples: He belongs to a far right group.

pos_items.definition: moving from above and onto a surface
dictionary_examples: Just as I was sitting down to watch TV, the phone rang.
Why don't you lie down on the sofa for a while?
This box is really heavy - can we put it down on the floor for a minute?
Get down off that table immediately, you silly girl!
learner_examples: So I sat down to write the answer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Latvian)

pos_items.definition: towards or in a low or lower position, from a higher one
dictionary_examples: Is this lift going down?
Don't look down! You'll get dizzy.
The sun's going down and it'll be dark soon.
I bent down to look under the bed.
learner_examples: Lunch time in India is about 5 p.m, when the sun [is] going down. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in writing or on paper
dictionary_examples: Do you have it down in writing/on paper, or was it just a verbal agreement?
I've put you down for three tickets each.
learner_examples: You have to bring a pen and paper to write down the teacher's notes. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used, especially with prepositions, to emphasize that a place is far from you or from somewhere considered to be central
dictionary_examples: I'll meet you down at the club after work.
He has a house down by the harbour.
I'm going down to the shop to buy some milk.
learner_examples: As soon as we drove down from the hills, I heard the noise from the town and I didn't like that. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: People or ideas that are down to earth are practical and work well.
dictionary_examples: David's a bit of a dreamer but Ruth's much more down to earth.
learner_examples: He has much practical knowledge, he is down to earth. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to be someone's responsibility or decision
dictionary_examples: I've done all I can now, the rest is down to you.
learner_examples: It is down to us to prevent homelessness. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: Australia, or in Australia
dictionary_examples: She was born in Scotland, but she's been living down under for 22 years.
learner_examples: Last year a good friend of mine and I went to Australia. After a couple of days of doing some sightseeing and sunbathing on bea[u]tiful sandy beaches, we decided that we need[ed] to get something more out of our stay down under. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in or towards a low or lower position, from a higher one
dictionary_examples: I slid down the hill.
Aikiko fell down some stairs and broke her wrist.
learner_examples: I was the first to go down the hill. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: along or further along
dictionary_examples: We drove down the motorway as far as Bristol.
Her office is down the corridor on the right.
They sailed the boat down the river.
learner_examples: Then we went down the Nile by boat. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: If money or work goes down the drain, it is wasted.
dictionary_examples: If you leave the course now, all your hard work will go down the drain.
learner_examples: All those evening conversations and the investment of 100,000 yen went down the drain, I thought. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: unhappy or unable to feel excited or energetic about anything
dictionary_examples: She's been really down since her husband died.
I've been (feeling) a bit down this week.
learner_examples: If you are feeling down or depressed, what are you doing? (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: If a computer or machine is down, it is temporarily not working.
dictionary_examples: The network was down all morning.
learner_examples: If other departments use the online system, it seems to be down for a while. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: having no money, no luck and no opportunities
dictionary_examples: Nobody loves you when you're down and out.
learner_examples: The neglect of social security as a vital point in state policies leaves homeless people down and out, with little chance for improving their bleak prospects. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: to be unhappy
dictionary_examples: He looks a bit down in the dumps.
learner_examples: She felt happy when I was down in the dumps or in a fix and kept on being jealous of me concerning trivial matters. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: moving from above and onto a surface
dictionary_examples: Just as I was sitting down to watch TV, the phone rang.
Why don't you lie down on the sofa for a while?
This box is really heavy - can we put it down on the floor for a minute?
Get down off that table immediately, you silly girl!
learner_examples: So I sat down to write the answer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Latvian)

learner_examples: You have to bring a pen and paper to write down the teacher's notes. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

learner_examples: She felt happy when I was down in the dumps or in a fix and kept on being jealous of me concerning trivial matters. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in addition to someone or something
dictionary_examples: Would you like anything else to eat?
What else did he say?
The book definitely isn't here. Where else should I look?
learner_examples: If you need anything else, you'll find it in the classroom. (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: different from someone or something
dictionary_examples: I don't like it here. Let's go somewhere else.
If it doesn't work, try something else.
It's not my bag. It must be someone else's.
learner_examples: I think we should go somewhere else to have a drink after the film. (Key English Test; A2; Vietnamese)

pos_items.definition: other things or people
dictionary_examples: I forgot my toothbrush, but I remembered everything else.
I turned up in my jeans and everyone else was dressed really smartly.
learner_examples: As this year I turned 12 my m[u]m and dad gave me 12 gifts and everyone else gave me clothes or money. (Key English Test; A2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: used to say what will happen if another thing does not happen
dictionary_examples: We must be there by six, or else we'll miss the beginning.
learner_examples: [He] told me to hurry up, or else I would miss my bus. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two different things or situations
dictionary_examples: He talks to her all the time, or else he completely ignores her.
learner_examples: Naturally Olivia's leaving affects Douglas, though not as strongly as one could have expected or else he simply does not show it. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: having a long distance from the top to the bottom
dictionary_examples: a deep river/sea/lake
The water's not deep here - look, I can touch the bottom.
The water's only ankle-/knee-/waist-deep, so we'll be able to get across the river easily.
learner_examples: That place [is] good for families too, because [the] water is not so deep but warm. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: A deep colour is strong and dark.
dictionary_examples: deep purple
learner_examples: He is tall and has got black hair and beautiful deep brown eyes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: A deep feeling or experience is very strong.
dictionary_examples: deep regret
Their son has been a deep disappointment to them.
learner_examples: I fell into a deep depression, and took an extremely long time to recover. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: A deep sound is low.
dictionary_examples: a wonderfully deep voice
learner_examples: "I'm not Gary," a strange and deep voice answered, "I'm someone who wants to warn you that tomorrow, you are going to die." (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: to fill your lungs with air
dictionary_examples: Take a deep breath and relax.
learner_examples: But if you took a deep breath after reading the question, don't worry. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: one metre/6 ft, etc. from the top to the bottom, or from the front to the back
dictionary_examples: This end of the pool is two metres deep.
learner_examples: Her father's friend, who is a professional scuba-diver, invited her to do her first immers[i]on on the reefs, 15 met[res] deep. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: serious and difficult for most people to understand
dictionary_examples: a deep and meaningful conversation
learner_examples: I think we really need to go back to the classics to re[ce]ive something from the deep thinkers. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: when someone is sleeping in a way that makes it difficult to wake them up
dictionary_examples: He fell into a deep sleep.
learner_examples: And then, he fell to a deep sleep, putting his sack next to him. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: giving all of your attention to what you are thinking or talking about, and not noticing anything else
dictionary_examples: I noticed that Ali and Ben were deep in conversation.
learner_examples: He was deep in thought, chewing on something brown and rectangular. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.sense_title: throw sb in at the deep end
pos_items.definition: to make someone start a new and difficult job or activity without helping them or preparing them for it
dictionary_examples: My first job was to organise a huge conference - they really threw me in at the deep end!
learner_examples: Sometimes we can be thrown in at the deep end and have qualms about making a decision. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: a long way into something from the top or outside
dictionary_examples: They travelled deep into the forest.
He thrust his hands deep in(to) his pockets.
learner_examples: I just fall deep into the story, into the writer's own world. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: If you know or feel something deep down, you are certain that it is true, or you feel it strongly although you do not admit it or show it.
dictionary_examples: Deep down, I knew that I was right.
learner_examples: No, because I [feel] deep down that it's wrong to put animals behind bars. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: If a feeling or a problem goes deep, it is very strong or serious and has existed for a long time.
dictionary_examples: Hostility between the two nations runs deep.

pos_items.definition: moving from above and onto a surface
dictionary_examples: Just as I was sitting down to watch TV, the phone rang.
Why don't you lie down on the sofa for a while?
This box is really heavy - can we put it down on the floor for a minute?
Get down off that table immediately, you silly girl!
learner_examples: So I sat down to write the answer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Latvian)

learner_examples: If other departments use the online system, it seems to be down for a while. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean)

learner_examples: She felt happy when I was down in the dumps or in a fix and kept on being jealous of me concerning trivial matters. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: more, or more than usual
dictionary_examples: She babysits to earn a bit of extra cash.
He needs extra help with his English.
The price includes travel and accommodation but meals are extra.
learner_examples: You only have to bring an extra t-shirt. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: more
dictionary_examples: They pay her extra to work nights.
learner_examples: Will there be any special events that cost extra? (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: something that you can get with something else if you pay a little more money
dictionary_examples: A sunroof is an optional extra on this model of the car.
learner_examples: The DVD contains many extras. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: an actor in a film who does not have a main part and usually plays someone in a crowd
dictionary_examples: He was an extra in the crowd scene.
learner_examples: A theatre troop at the beginning of a new project is more often than not a flabbergasting rabble of actors, technicians, extras, back-stage workers and so forth. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to or on a lower floor of a building, especially the ground floor
dictionary_examples: I went downstairs to answer the phone.
learner_examples: While I was in your house, your mom called me to help her carry some stuff, so I left my purse on your bed, and went downstairs to help her. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: on or at a lower floor of a building, especially the ground floor
dictionary_examples: The burglars had got in through a downstairs window.
learner_examples: Every year when winter com[es], our heating [doe]sn't work very well. [The] upstairs rooms [are] ok, but [the] downstairs rooms are cold. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: happening or done every day or once a day
dictionary_examples: Exercise has become part of my daily routine.
We back up our computer files at work on a daily basis.
learner_examples: It's very easy to reach because some bus companies provide a daily bus service. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: the usual things that happen to you every day
dictionary_examples: I try to keep exercise a part of my daily life.
learner_examples: Mr. Bean often does funny things in his daily life. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: every day or once a day
dictionary_examples: Take the tablets twice daily.
learner_examples: It's open daily. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: with no difficulty or effort
dictionary_examples: I can easily get some food on the way home tonight, if you'd like.
She makes friends very easily.
learner_examples: I think you can find it very easily, because it is [in the] centre of my home town. (Key English Test; A2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something is likely
dictionary_examples: A comment like that could easily be misunderstood.
learner_examples: Considering the results of our research and the available alternatives, we came to the conclusion that there is no valid reason for replacing a valuable park with a car park that could easily be located somewhere else. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: certainly the best/worst/biggest, etc.
dictionary_examples: It was easily the biggest dog I have ever seen.
learner_examples: In conclusion, the percentage of newly employed make up easily the biggest proportion of UK university students [that] graduated in 2001. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in a correct way
dictionary_examples: Have I pronounced your name correctly?
learner_examples: I don't speak English correctly. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: without any doubt
dictionary_examples: Have you definitely decided to go to America?
He definitely said he'd be here.
learner_examples: So if I were you, I would definitely stay in the city. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: used after an adverb in short, negative replies
dictionary_examples: "Do you think the work will be finished by June?" "Definitely not."
learner_examples: That's nice, but do you think that money is all that matters? Definitely not! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: in a different way
dictionary_examples: We want to do things differently.
Are girls treated differently?
learner_examples: I had always pictured it quite differently. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: with no other person or thing involved or in between
dictionary_examples: Our hotel room was directly above a building site.
The disease is directly linked to poor drainage systems.
The sun shone directly in my eyes.
learner_examples: The Youth Hostel was directly beside the sea. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: clearly and honestly
dictionary_examples: Let me answer that question directly.
learner_examples: While being interviewed, try to answer the questions directly and look into [the] interviewer's eyes. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a comfortable way
dictionary_examples: We slept very comfortably that night.
learner_examples: I was sitting comfortably on the couch watching TV when suddenly all the lights went out, [and] everything became silent. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is large or important enough to be noticed
dictionary_examples: Rates of pay vary considerably.
He's considerably fatter than he was when I knew him.
learner_examples: The departures are at 8 am. and 10 a.m. daily, but I suggest that your group be there at the time of the first departure because it is considerably less crowded. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: all the time or often
dictionary_examples: He's constantly changing his mind.
She has the television on constantly.
learner_examples: I stood up and walked around the house, constantly bumping into things! (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: without stopping
dictionary_examples: You can't work continuously for six hours without a break!
learner_examples: They continuously claim that [the] destruction of the environment is totally all human beings' responsibility. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is convenient
dictionary_examples: The house is conveniently situated near the station and the shops.
learner_examples: First of all, your group has been booked into the Palace Hotel, which is conveniently situated in the centre of Nymegen. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is critical
dictionary_examples: They were both critically injured in the crash.
learner_examples: Cars are even more important for emergency situations such as [a] fire in a house or if somebody is critically ill. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a way that relates to culture
dictionary_examples: It's a culturally diverse society.
learner_examples: What I think is that Rome has to become a cultural pole, and becoming culturally vital, it will gradually look better. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: showing that you want to know or learn more
dictionary_examples: She looked at him curiously.
learner_examples: Everyone around looked at me curiously. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese)

pos_items.definition: strangely
dictionary_examples: Curiously, there didn't seem to be a bank in the town.
learner_examples: Curiously, a few days before the murder Emma received a letter from a French girl named Martine saying she wanted to visit them. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: at the present time

learner_examples: I am 22 years old and I am currently studying trade and tourism. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: intentionally
dictionary_examples: I'm sure he says these things deliberately to annoy me.
learner_examples: Many of them choose the bicycle deliberately, just to have at least a small amount of exercise before and after [the] hours they spend sitting at their desks. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: with no other person or thing involved or in between
dictionary_examples: Our hotel room was directly above a building site.

The sun shone directly in my eyes.
learner_examples: The Youth Hostel was directly beside the sea. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: clearly and honestly
dictionary_examples: Let me answer that question directly.
learner_examples: While being interviewed, try to answer the questions directly and look into [the] interviewer's eyes. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: suddenly or obviously
dictionary_examples: Your life changes dramatically when you have a baby.
learner_examples: She fell dramatically to the floor. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is successful and achieves what you want
dictionary_examples: Teachers need to be able to communicate ideas effectively.
The tablets work more effectively if you take a hot drink after them.
learner_examples: As well as learning English, we should be aware of the cultures of many countries in order to be able to communicate more effectively. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used when you describe what the real result of a situation is
dictionary_examples: His illness effectively ended his career.
learner_examples: We have to remember that the Spanish language is becoming increasingly important, especially in countries like [the] US, where it is effectively THE second language of communication. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: quickly and effectively in an organized way
dictionary_examples: She runs the business very efficiently.
learner_examples: Needless to say, the computer plays a [key] role [in making] us use a library efficiently. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: fairly and in the same way
dictionary_examples: Everyone should be treated equally.
learner_examples: In [the] festival, all the performers were treated equally. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: into amounts or parts that are the same size
dictionary_examples: She shared the money equally between the four children.
learner_examples: The obligations should be divided equally between the members of the gro[u]p. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: to the same degree or level
dictionary_examples: an equally important question
