learner_examples: I think the choice of a good organization, which can provide good facilities and social conditions, along with good teaching, is equally important. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: very much or particularly
dictionary_examples: She's not especially interested in sport.
I chose this especially for your new house.
I loved the show, especially the dancing.
learner_examples: I like sports, especially playing basketball. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: for one particular person, purpose, or reason
dictionary_examples: I cooked this meal especially for you.
learner_examples: I remember the taste of the pineapple cake that you baked especially for me and your home-made goos[e]berry wine. (First Certificate in English; B2; Latvian)

pos_items.definition: relating to the most important characteristics or ideas of something
dictionary_examples: It's essentially a dictionary but it differs in one or two respects.
What he's saying is essentially true.
learner_examples: Although we are essentially a rock band, we integrate elements of traditional Indian music (such as sitar). (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in the end, especially after a long time
dictionary_examples: Eventually they reached an agreement.
He eventually got round to fixing the bike.
learner_examples: Anyway Pat eventually apologized to me. (First Certificate in English; B2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: more than average, but less than very
dictionary_examples: a fairly big family
She's fairly tall.
We get on fairly well.
I saw her fairly recently.
learner_examples: The weather was fairly warm. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: If you do something fairly, you do it in a way which is right and reasonable and treats people equally.
dictionary_examples: He claimed that he hadn't been treated fairly by his employers.
Officials will ensure that the election is carried out fairly.

pos_items.definition: often or usually

learner_examples: It is commonly acknowledged that, these days, mobile phones have become an important [accessory]. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: completely
dictionary_examples: We were comprehensively beaten in the final.

pos_items.definition: again and again or without stopping

learner_examples: First of all I would like to mention that new blood is re[q]uired in the club, as the membership is continually falling. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: with no difficulty or effort

learner_examples: I think you can find it very easily, because it is [in the] centre of my home town. (Key English Test; A2; Korean)

learner_examples: Considering the results of our research and the available alternatives, we came to the conclusion that there is no valid reason for replacing a valuable park with a car park that could easily be located somewhere else. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: certainly the best/worst/biggest, etc.
dictionary_examples: It was easily the biggest dog I have ever seen.
learner_examples: In conclusion, the percentage of newly employed make up easily the biggest proportion of UK university students [that] graduated in 2001. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: fairly and in the same way
dictionary_examples: Everyone should be treated equally.
learner_examples: In [the] festival, all the performers were treated equally. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: into amounts or parts that are the same size
dictionary_examples: She shared the money equally between the four children.
learner_examples: The obligations should be divided equally between the members of the gro[u]p. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: only

pos_items.definition: in a way that proves that something is true

learner_examples: This undeniable fact implies advantages that were unthinkable in the past, yet we cannot prove conclusively that the gains outweigh the losses. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: He has consistently denied the rumours.
She performed consistently throughout the whole tournament.

pos_items.definition: in a way that deals well with people without upsetting them
dictionary_examples: He phrased his question very diplomatically.
learner_examples: Even though this issue is usually settled diplomatically, there still remains [a] considerable amount of criticism to be faced. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is successful and achieves what you want

The tablets work more effectively if you take a hot drink after them.

pos_items.definition: used when you describe what the real result of a situation is

learner_examples: We have to remember that the Spanish language is becoming increasingly important, especially in countries like [the] US, where it is effectively THE second language of communication. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

She starts work fairly early.
learner_examples: Martin get[s] up early - [at] 5.00 am. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak)

learner_examples: We'll finish it early. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: near the beginning of a period of time, process, etc.
dictionary_examples: the early 1980s

My earliest memory is of being shown around our new house.
learner_examples: Tomorrow please come in the early morning. (Key English Test; A2; Bengali)

pos_items.definition: before the usual time or the time that was arranged
dictionary_examples: I'm going to have an early night.

learner_examples: I have been thinking about early retirement. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in the first stage or part of something

learner_examples: What luck that I found such a yardstick early on in my childhood. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: the direction that you face to see the sun rise, opposite to the west
dictionary_examples: The points of the compass are North, South, East and West.
Which way is east?

pos_items.definition: the part of an area that is further towards the east than the rest
dictionary_examples: Her home is in the east of France.
Most of the country, except the east, is rural.
learner_examples: You can visit the east of the town. (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: the countries of Asia
dictionary_examples: She spent her childhood in the East - mostly in China and Japan.

pos_items.definition: in or forming the east part of something
dictionary_examples: New York is east of Chicago.
The east wall of the mosque is covered with a beautiful mosaic.
learner_examples: I'll visit the romantic Robin Hood's Bay [on] the east coast of England. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: towards the east
dictionary_examples: They sailed further east.

pos_items.definition: in addition to someone or something
dictionary_examples: Would you like anything else to eat?
What else did he say?
The book definitely isn't here. Where else should I look?
learner_examples: If you need anything else, you'll find it in the classroom. (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: different from someone or something

It's not my bag. It must be someone else's.

I turned up in my jeans and everyone else was dressed really smartly.

pos_items.definition: used to compare two different things or situations

learner_examples: If you need anything else, you'll find it in the classroom. (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

learner_examples: Naturally Olivia's leaving affects Douglas, though not as strongly as one could have expected or else he simply does not show it. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: as much as is necessary
dictionary_examples: Is there enough cake for everyone?
Have you had enough to eat?
There are 25 textbooks for the class - that should be enough.
I know enough about art to realise that this painting is special.
learner_examples: My favourite present is the concert tickets because I wanted to go the concert but I didn't have enough money. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: as much as or more than is wanted
dictionary_examples: I've got enough work to do at the moment, without being given any more.
Half an hour in his company is quite enough!
Stop. You've made enough of a mess already.
You've drunk more than enough already.
learner_examples: Now I think I'm going to stay around here, as I [have] had enough disappointments for one summer. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to want something to stop because it is annoying you
dictionary_examples: I've had enough of your excuses.
learner_examples: My neighbours and I have had enough of this sudden and deafening noise, which seems to affect our pets as well. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: as much as is necessary
dictionary_examples: Are you old enough to vote?
You're not driving fast enough.
learner_examples: He didn't study enough. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: although it may seem strange
dictionary_examples: Strangely enough, I was just speaking to him the other day.
learner_examples: Today, strangely enough, people out on the sea, often local fishermen, see the complete castle, like a ghost. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used for saying that you can understand and accept someone's opinion or decision
dictionary_examples: "He says he'll only work on Sunday if he gets paid extra." "Fair enough."
learner_examples: Most of the streets are open [to] cars and therefore people tend to escape to a little area around the pedestrian streets. Fair enough, but it make[s] those streets terribly overcrowded. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: as expected
dictionary_examples: He said the book was on his desk, and sure enough, there it was.
learner_examples: And sure enough, these challenging problems come unsolicited most of the time. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize something that is surprising
dictionary_examples: Everyone danced - even Mick.
It's a very difficult job - it might even take a year to finish it.
learner_examples: You were the only one who wasn't there, even Marcelo was there! (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize a comparison
dictionary_examples: Her last film was even better.
The next 36 hours will be even colder, with snow showers just about everywhere.
I think Alex is going to be even taller than his father.
It's even more difficult to find work.
learner_examples: When I saw her getting off the train I really was close to break[ing] down because she looked even more beautiful. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the fact that something does not happen or is not true
dictionary_examples: "I never cry." "Not even when you hurt yourself really badly?"
Nobody spoke, not even the children.
learner_examples: We tried to fish, but didn't catch a thing, not even a shoe! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: whether or not
dictionary_examples: Even if you take a taxi, you'll still miss your train.
learner_examples: I often go to parks, with or without the children, even if the weather is not good. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: although
dictionary_examples: Even though he left school at 16, he still managed to become a millionaire.
He still smokes even though he's got asthma.
learner_examples: They didn't give up hope even though they were tired and wet to the bone. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something surprising is true despite what you have just said
dictionary_examples: Car prices have gone down a lot, but even so, we couldn't afford to buy one.
learner_examples: I'm sure many of [these things] happened due to bad luck, but even so, there are some arrangements that, I bel[ie]ve, can easily be improved. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to not make money but also not lose money
dictionary_examples: The company only managed to break even this year.
learner_examples: Company C does not seem to be doing well. In the year 2000, it just seems to be breaking even. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: at any time
dictionary_examples: Have you ever been to London?
If you're ever in Cambridge, do give me a ring.
Nothing ever happens here in the evenings.
The smell is worse than ever.
learner_examples: [It] is the most beautiful place I've ever seen. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: almost never
dictionary_examples: We hardly ever go out these days.
learner_examples: My bedroom hardly ever looks tidy. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: continuously since that time
dictionary_examples: We met at school and have been friends ever since.
He's been depressed ever since he got divorced.
learner_examples: The pen was given [to me] by my father on my birthday and I have treasured it ever since. (Key English Test; A2; Telugu)

pos_items.definition: always in the future
dictionary_examples: I'm not going to live here for ever.
learner_examples: My friend was leaving the city for ever and [going] to a city in another country. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: very
dictionary_examples: It was ever so kind of you to meet us at the airport.
learner_examples: It was ever so kind of you to take the trouble and make room for us although we arrived quite unexpectedly. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: a very
dictionary_examples: She's ever such a good dancer.
learner_examples: The psychiatrist was a very nice young girl that helped me ever such a lot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: better/faster/happier, etc. than at any time before
dictionary_examples: She is running faster than ever.
learner_examples: First of all, I would like to thank you for your invitation to the new opening of Longridge Arts Centre, the centre looks better than ever and I enjoyed the arts exhibition that is on now. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Breton)

pos_items.definition: always changing/growing/increasing, etc.
dictionary_examples: We live in an ever-changing world.
learner_examples: In our ever-changing society, in the affluent cities of the Western world, life moves at such a fast pace that parents are the reflection and the result of our times, the cogs of a large, rather uncontrollable wheel. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in or to every place
dictionary_examples: I looked everywhere for my keys.
Everywhere I look I see things that remind me of Brendan.
We had to stay in a hotel outside the town as everywhere else was fully booked.
learner_examples: I love the teddy bear because it's soft and I can take it with me everywhere. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at, to or from a great distance in space or time
dictionary_examples: Is the station far away?
She doesn't live far from here.
How far away does your mother live?
How far is it from Australia to New Zealand?
Bournemouth is not far from Poole.
One day, perhaps far in/into the future, you'll regret what you've done.
learner_examples: It isn't so far from my house so we can go [on foot]. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: until now
dictionary_examples: So far we've made thirty-two thousand pounds.
learner_examples: So far I like it here very much. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian)

pos_items.definition: very much
dictionary_examples: This car is far better than our old one.
It cost far more (money) than I could afford.
He loses his temper far too often.
I'd far rather/sooner go to the theatre than watch a DVD.
learner_examples: I think restaurant B is far better than restaurant A. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you think something is true, but cannot be sure
dictionary_examples: As far as I know, he's never been in trouble with the police.
learner_examples: As far as I know, accommodation at Camp California is in tents or log cabins. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sb is concerned ()
pos_items.definition: used to say what someone's opinion is
dictionary_examples: It's all over as far as I'm concerned.
learner_examples: As far as I am concerned, Bernard is similar to him. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sth is concerned ()
pos_items.definition: used to say what you are talking about
dictionary_examples: As far as sport is concerned, I like tennis and football.
learner_examples: As far as studying abroad is concerned, I totally agree with this idea. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: by a great amount
dictionary_examples: They are by far the best students in the class.
learner_examples: I have travelled to many countries, but New Zealand is by far the best. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has gone well until now
dictionary_examples: It's the first time I've done any decorating, but so far so good.
learner_examples: So far so good, only no one told us they held this point of view before the actual christening took place. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: certainly not something
dictionary_examples: The situation is far from clear.
learner_examples: The quality of catering was far from ideal as well, as a meal in a hamburger restaurant can hardly be called a typical English lunch. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to tell someone that something is certainly not true
dictionary_examples: He's not handsome - far from it.
learner_examples: The Hotel Royal cannot be considered as being luxury - far from it - i.e. our rooms were dirty and situated [o]n the 4th floor without a lift. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about how true something is
dictionary_examples: How far do politicians represent the views of ordinary people?
learner_examples: How far and to what extent would the characteristics we are born with influence our future development in life? (International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: certainly not doing something
dictionary_examples: Far from being pleased, he was embarrassed by the praise.
learner_examples: Far from asking you to close the airport, which would be quite an irrational request, I am suggesting that you should take some action to improve the situation. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.sense_title: go so far as to do sth
pos_items.definition: to take the extreme action of doing something
dictionary_examples: He even went so far as to stop her using the telephone.
learner_examples: Our present course of action may go so far as to cause irrevers[i]ble damage not only to our planet but also to the people living upon [it]. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to behave in a way that upsets or annoys other people
dictionary_examples: He's said some stupid things in the past, but this time he's gone too far.
learner_examples: Lucia let her speak and calmly said: "You really have gone too far this time." (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not happening or existing very often
dictionary_examples: Opportunities like this are few and far between.
learner_examples: Jobs in those days were few and far between and for a number of years he was alternating between temporary jobs and unemployment benefit. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to be very different from something
dictionary_examples: The princess's world was far removed from reality.
learner_examples: It is the same problem with planned excursions to street markets in Asia, souks in Arabia or even tribes that are far removed from industrialized life in Papua New Guinea or the rainforest of Brazil. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: describes the part of something that is most distant from the centre or from you
dictionary_examples: His office is at the far end of the corridor.
The children ran to the far side/corner of the room.
learner_examples: The dark spot at the far end of the wall seemed to be coming after her this time. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.sense_title: be a far cry from sth
pos_items.definition: to be very different from something
dictionary_examples: Her luxury mansion is a far cry from the house she grew up in.
learner_examples: The museum was a far cry from what we expected. Not only were the machines really old and should have been replaced a long time ago, but they were boring as well. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to describe political groups whose opinions are very extreme
dictionary_examples: He belongs to a far right group.

pos_items.definition: moving or happening quickly, or able to move or happen quickly
dictionary_examples: fast cars
a fast swimmer
Computers are getting faster all the time.
The fast train to London takes less than an hour.
learner_examples: I like fast music very much. (Key English Test; A2; Gujarati)

pos_items.definition: a very quick way of achieving or dealing with something
dictionary_examples: These intensive courses claim to offer a fast track to wealth and success.
learner_examples: If I ever found a job which lives up to these expectations, I would consider myself on [a] fast track already. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: moving or happening quickly
dictionary_examples: We ran as fast as we could.
The accident was caused by people driving too fast in bad conditions.
learner_examples: I rode my bike home as fast as I could. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a firm or tight way
dictionary_examples: He tried to get away, but she held him fast.
learner_examples: Thankfully, there are those who still cling to such age-old values as personal contentment and growth, regarding them as the anchors which hold happiness fast. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: completely asleep
dictionary_examples: I looked into her room but she was still fast asleep.
learner_examples: Karen's grandson walks into the room to find her fast asleep on her favourite chair. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the busy and exciting way of life that a successful person has
dictionary_examples: Fed up with life in the fast lane, Jack gave up his job and moved to the countryside.
learner_examples: Finally, should you ask why people are not happier than before, the answer is that nowadays they spend more hours on work than before, because modern life is mostly a life in the fast lane. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: quickly and in large numbers
dictionary_examples: Calls were coming in thick and fast by the end of the programme.

pos_items.definition: used when you are giving a choice between two or more things
dictionary_examples: Either you leave now or I call the police!
learner_examples: I thought: "Either I talk to her now or I won't be able to talk to her [at all]!" (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used in negative sentences to mean that something else is true
dictionary_examples: I don't eat meat and my husband doesn't either.
"I've never been to the States." "I haven't either."
The menu is boring at that restaurant and it's not cheap either.
learner_examples: It's so quick and not too expensive either. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: one of two people or things when it is not important which
dictionary_examples: Either candidate would be ideal for the job.
"Would you like the metal or plastic one?" "Either will do."
learner_examples: But, either option, call me [at] my house before coming. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about two possibilities where the result will be the same
dictionary_examples: You can get there by train or bus - either way it'll take an hour.
He might have to resign or he might be given a desk job, but either way, his career is effectively over.
learner_examples: If that doesn't work, you can ask them to talk to your friends' parents so you could all go together. Either way, I know you will have lots of fun this summer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: each of two sides, ends, etc.
dictionary_examples: Unfortunately I was sitting at the table with smokers on either side of me.
There are two entrances, one at either end of the campsite.
learner_examples: You can watch it while it's eating: standing up on its back legs and holding the nut with its front legs, then putting all of it into one [of] its two "sacks" on either side of its mouth. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize something that is surprising
dictionary_examples: Everyone danced - even Mick.
It's a very difficult job - it might even take a year to finish it.
learner_examples: You were the only one who wasn't there, even Marcelo was there! (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize a comparison
dictionary_examples: Her last film was even better.
The next 36 hours will be even colder, with snow showers just about everywhere.
I think Alex is going to be even taller than his father.
It's even more difficult to find work.
learner_examples: When I saw her getting off the train I really was close to break[ing] down because she looked even more beautiful. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the fact that something does not happen or is not true
dictionary_examples: "I never cry." "Not even when you hurt yourself really badly?"
Nobody spoke, not even the children.
learner_examples: We tried to fish, but didn't catch a thing, not even a shoe! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: whether or not
dictionary_examples: Even if you take a taxi, you'll still miss your train.
learner_examples: I often go to parks, with or without the children, even if the weather is not good. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: although
dictionary_examples: Even though he left school at 16, he still managed to become a millionaire.

learner_examples: They didn't give up hope even though they were tired and wet to the bone. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something surprising is true despite what you have just said
dictionary_examples: Car prices have gone down a lot, but even so, we couldn't afford to buy one.
learner_examples: I'm sure many of [these things] happened due to bad luck, but even so, there are some arrangements that, I bel[ie]ve, can easily be improved. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to not make money but also not lose money
dictionary_examples: The company only managed to break even this year.
learner_examples: Company C does not seem to be doing well. In the year 2000, it just seems to be breaking even. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: directly, meeting someone in the same place
dictionary_examples: We need to talk face to face.
learner_examples: I need to talk to her face to face. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in or to another place
dictionary_examples: The report looks at economic growth in Europe and elsewhere.
They couldn't find what they wanted and decided to look elsewhere.
learner_examples: As for communication with our relatives in Sweden or elsewhere, the fax-machine turned out to be an excellent invention. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: towards a lower place or level
dictionary_examples: The road slopes downwards to the river.
learner_examples: Water runs downwards into [the] turbine when the valve is open. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Telugu)

pos_items.definition: in a drastic way
dictionary_examples: The number of bees has drastically declined due to a combination of factors.
learner_examples: Conditions have changed drastically after the reunification. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: extremely
dictionary_examples: an exceptionally gifted student
learner_examples: Jacky Chan is an exceptionally hardworking person who won't let anything bring him down and he has a great sense of humour which is why most people like him. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a decisive way
dictionary_examples: We need to act decisively.
learner_examples: Putting your foot down quickly and decisively before things really get out of hand seems sensible. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: towards the bottom of a hill or slope
dictionary_examples: It's so much easier cycling downhill.
learner_examples: Skiing downhill in deep snow is the most rewarding experience. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: to gradually become worse
dictionary_examples: After his wife died, his health started to go downhill.
learner_examples: He had been going downhill in the last few days and so his death came as no surprise. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

a fast swimmer

learner_examples: I like fast music very much. (Key English Test; A2; Gujarati)

learner_examples: If I ever found a job which lives up to these expectations, I would consider myself on [a] fast track already. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

learner_examples: I rode my bike home as fast as I could. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

dictionary_examples: He tried to get away, but she held him fast.
learner_examples: Thankfully, there are those who still cling to such age-old values as personal contentment and growth, regarding them as the anchors which hold happiness fast. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: completely asleep
dictionary_examples: I looked into her room but she was still fast asleep.
learner_examples: Karen's grandson walks into the room to find her fast asleep on her favourite chair. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the busy and exciting way of life that a successful person has
dictionary_examples: Fed up with life in the fast lane, Jack gave up his job and moved to the countryside.
learner_examples: Finally, should you ask why people are not happier than before, the answer is that nowadays they spend more hours on work than before, because modern life is mostly a life in the fast lane. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: quickly and in large numbers
dictionary_examples: Calls were coming in thick and fast by the end of the programme.

pos_items.definition: in the past
dictionary_examples: The European Union was formerly called the European Community.
learner_examples: He was a hero in Japan, formerly known as the ungifted pupil from Switzerland. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: really or certainly, often used to emphasize something
dictionary_examples: Indeed, it could be the worst environmental disaster in Western Europe this century.
Evidence suggests that errors may indeed be occurring.
We live in strange times indeed.
Many people are very poor indeed.
learner_examples: Thank you very much indeed. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used when you say more to support or develop what has already been said
dictionary_examples: For such creatures speed is not important, indeed it is counterproductive.
learner_examples: It would be very difficult to define a country's culture by choosing only one characteristic of that country; indeed, it is a great variety of things such as language, politics, religion, customs, etc. that shape the culture of every country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not allowed by law
dictionary_examples: They entered the country illegally.
an illegally parked car
learner_examples: He was afraid and bought a gun illegally. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: in an impatient way
dictionary_examples: "Yes, you said that before," she said, impatiently.

pos_items.definition: extremely
dictionary_examples: I think the team played incredibly well.

pos_items.definition: in a way that is difficult to believe
dictionary_examples: Incredibly, no one was hurt.

dictionary_examples: We finally got home at midnight.
After months of looking he finally found a job.
learner_examples: Well, I have finally decided that I will paint my room blue. (Key English Test; A2; Marathi)

dictionary_examples: Finally, I'd like to thank everyone for coming this evening.
learner_examples: Finally, I want you to say hi [to] everybody and I am looking forward to see[ing] you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: happening because of good luck
dictionary_examples: Fortunately, we got home before it started to rain.
learner_examples: At the moment, fortunately, the weather is fine and sunny. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: completely
dictionary_examples: The restaurant was fully booked.

a fully qualified teacher

pos_items.definition: usually, or in most situations
dictionary_examples: I generally wake up early.
learner_examples: I generally prefer reading newspapers, but I don't dislike books. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: considering the whole of someone or something, and not just a particular part of them

learner_examples: Hopefully he likes me, too. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: in a hopeful way

learner_examples: I'll be waiting hopefully for your letter. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to the first thing in a list

pos_items.definition: in a way that is fluent

I don't know how anyone could think that way.

pos_items.definition: used to ask why or how something has happened

pos_items.definition: used to talk about how true something is

pos_items.definition: in the place where you are

learner_examples: He live[s] in Galicia, but now he's here in Cambridge to study English. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used when saying who you are on the phone

pos_items.definition: used when you are giving someone something

learner_examples: Dear Jo, Here is some information about the art class. (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: here you are/here it is, etc.
pos_items.definition: used when you see someone or something you have been looking for or waiting for
dictionary_examples: Here she is at last.
Here's our bus.
I've lost my watch - oh, here it is.

pos_items.definition: at this point in a discussion or piece of writing
dictionary_examples: I don't have time here to go into all the arguments.
learner_examples: My idea here is to highlight the fact that computers are going to control our lives. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in several different places or directions but without any pattern
dictionary_examples: Tall trees were growing here and there.
learner_examples: In the cinemas there were a few broken seats here and there. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: almost not, or only a very small amount
dictionary_examples: We hardly ever go to concerts.
I could hardly hear her at the back.
The party had hardly started when she left.
He ate hardly anything.
learner_examples: Well, my bedroom hardly ever looks tidy. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: certainly not
dictionary_examples: You can hardly expect a pay rise when you've only been working for the company for two weeks!
Well don't be angry with me - it's hardly my fault that it's raining!
learner_examples: And then, although you [have] allowed me to use all your stuff, I hardly think I can touch your computer and the CD player. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to ask someone if they are well and happy
dictionary_examples: "Hi, Lucy, how are you?" "Fine, thanks, how are you?"
learner_examples: Dear Ramesh, How are you? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask or talk about quantity, size, or age
dictionary_examples: Do you know how many people are coming?
How much was that dress?
How big is the house?
How old are they?
learner_examples: How much does it cost? (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to make a suggestion
dictionary_examples: How about a drink?
How about going to the cinema?
learner_examples: How about going on Monday evening? (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to ask or talk about the way something happens or is done
dictionary_examples: How do we get to the town from here?
How did you hear about the concert?
How does this machine work?
Roz doesn't know how to ride a bicycle.
How can/could he be so stupid?
I don't know how anyone could think that way.
learner_examples: How did you know I liked skateboards? (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask about someone's health
dictionary_examples: How is your mother?
How are you feeling this morning?
learner_examples: How are you feeling? I hope you are feeling better. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask or talk about what an experience or event was like
dictionary_examples: How was your flight?
How did you find the lecture?
How did you like the concert?
learner_examples: How was your birthday? (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: used for emphasis
dictionary_examples: I can't tell you how pleased I am that you came.
How nice to see you!
I was amazed at how quickly she finished.
learner_examples: It's quite amazing how quickly she could change my reason to learn English. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used to ask for someone's opinion on a particular subject
dictionary_examples: So the town was nice - how about the food?
learner_examples: I don't like shopping with my mum because she wants me to wear weird clothes. How about you? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: a formal greeting for someone that you have not met before
dictionary_examples: "I'm Jack Stewart." "How do you do? I'm Angela Black."

pos_items.definition: said to mean that something is strange/stupid, etc.
dictionary_examples: I found my keys in the fridge - how stupid is that?
learner_examples: The best thing is that my current rent is only 2/3 of the old flat and the landlord is paying the facility bills and council tax for me. How good is that? (International English Language Testing System; C2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to ask why or how something has happened
dictionary_examples: How come you didn't go to the party?
learner_examples: Off the record: How come that your reporter can print such lies when knowing they are perhaps hurting certain people in this important matter? (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to express anger about something someone has done
dictionary_examples: How dare you talk to me like that!
learner_examples: How dare you call that high standards?! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about how true something is
dictionary_examples: How far do politicians represent the views of ordinary people?
learner_examples: How far and to what extent would the characteristics we are born with influence our future development in life? (International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to ask someone if they are well and happy
dictionary_examples: "Hi, Lucy, how are you?" "Fine, thanks, how are you?"
learner_examples: Dear Ramesh, How are you? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

learner_examples: How much does it cost? (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

learner_examples: I don't like shopping with my mum because she wants me to wear weird clothes. How about you? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: "I'm Jack Stewart." "How do you do? I'm Angela Black."

learner_examples: The best thing is that my current rent is only 2/3 of the old flat and the landlord is paying the facility bills and council tax for me. How good is that? (International English Language Testing System; C2; Chinese)

dictionary_examples: How come you didn't go to the party?
learner_examples: Off the record: How come that your reporter can print such lies when knowing they are perhaps hurting certain people in this important matter? (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

dictionary_examples: How dare you talk to me like that!
learner_examples: How dare you call that high standards?! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about how true something is
dictionary_examples: How far do politicians represent the views of ordinary people?
learner_examples: How far and to what extent would the characteristics we are born with influence our future development in life? (International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: really or certainly, often used to emphasize something
dictionary_examples: Indeed, it could be the worst environmental disaster in Western Europe this century.
Evidence suggests that errors may indeed be occurring.
We live in strange times indeed.
Many people are very poor indeed.
learner_examples: Thank you very much indeed. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used when you say more to support or develop what has already been said
dictionary_examples: For such creatures speed is not important, indeed it is counterproductive.
learner_examples: It would be very difficult to define a country's culture by choosing only one characteristic of that country; indeed, it is a great variety of things such as language, politics, religion, customs, etc. that shape the culture of every country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: in addition to what has just been said
dictionary_examples: Furthermore, we have a duty to defend our country.
Furthermore, we found that the results varied according to what time of day the sample was taken.
learner_examples: I am 22 years of age and I have a degree in tourism. Furthermore, I have a working knowledge of English, Spanish, Catalan and Italian. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: almost not, or only a very small amount
dictionary_examples: We hardly ever go to concerts.
I could hardly hear her at the back.
The party had hardly started when she left.
He ate hardly anything.
learner_examples: Well, my bedroom hardly ever looks tidy. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: certainly not
dictionary_examples: You can hardly expect a pay rise when you've only been working for the company for two weeks!
Well don't be angry with me - it's hardly my fault that it's raining!
learner_examples: And then, although you [have] allowed me to use all your stuff, I hardly think I can touch your computer and the CD player. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: in or into a room, building, container, etc.
dictionary_examples: There were some keys inside the box.
learner_examples: I kept it inside the jewel box. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: in less than a particular length of time
dictionary_examples: The doctor's promised to be here inside an hour.
learner_examples: You can reach two stations on the tube-line seven inside 10 minutes; in addition there are two bus-stops even closer. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: in or into a room, building, container, etc.
dictionary_examples: I'm freezing, let's go back inside.
learner_examples: We can stay inside and play with the computer. (Key English Test; A2; Norwegian)

pos_items.definition: If you have a feeling inside, you have a feeling although you might not show it to other people.
dictionary_examples: She couldn't cope with the grief she felt inside.
learner_examples: They had to go to the vet more often but it wasn't hard for them because of the love that they felt inside. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: in or on the part of something under its surface
dictionary_examples: He put the documents carefully in his inside pocket.
learner_examples: At first Chris didn't seem to recognize him, but as soon as he did, his hand reached [into] his inside pocket. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: information that is only known by people who are part of an organization, group, etc.
dictionary_examples: I needed someone with inside knowledge to back up my story.
learner_examples: I'm pretty sure that getting in touch with the customs and lifestyle of another country will open a completely new horizon to the students and they'll be enchanted by the 'inside knowledge' they will be able to gain. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: the inner part, space or side of something
dictionary_examples: Did you clean the inside of the car?
The hotel looked shabby from the street, but it was fine on the inside.
learner_examples: Anyway, after the show I felt hungry so I went to the restaurant but it was closed because they were having the inside altered. (First Certificate in English; B2; )

pos_items.definition: If a piece of clothing is inside out, the part that is usually outside is on the inside.
dictionary_examples: She had her jumper on inside out.

pos_items.definition: to know everything about something
dictionary_examples: He knows the system inside out.
learner_examples: The participants got to know Britain inside out and they are happy with the knowledge they gained. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: having a large distance from the bottom to the top
dictionary_examples: a high building/mountain
learner_examples: And also you can see high mount[a]ins [and] beautiful lakes. (Key English Test; A2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: a large distance above the ground or the level of the sea
dictionary_examples: a high window
The village was high up in the mountains.
learner_examples: Look[ing] out [of] the window, I can see the birds high up on the trees. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: great in amount, size or level
dictionary_examples: a high temperature
high prices/costs
The car sped away at high speed.
learner_examples: Be careful while you are in Brazil because sometimes people charge really high prices for everything just because you are a tourist. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: very good
dictionary_examples: high standards/quality
She got high marks in her last exam.
learner_examples: There were lots of CD players and [everything] was high quality. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: important, powerful, or at the top level of something
dictionary_examples: a high rank
Safety is our highest priority.
learner_examples: Living is definitely the highest priority [all] over the world. (First Certificate in English; B2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: If a food is high in something, it contains a lot of it.
dictionary_examples: Avoid foods that are high in salt.
learner_examples: Since there is no time even for cooking a healthy meal, they get used to ready meals that are high in fat and salt. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Singhalese)

pos_items.definition: If someone is high, they are behaving in an unusual way because they have taken an illegal drug.
dictionary_examples: The whole band seemed to be high on drugs.
learner_examples: As he was in that enormous garden covering himself with leaves lying on his back, he realised that he didn't want to watch the end of the Universe there in that place, but because he was so high on drugs he didn't even realise that he could simply stand up and go home. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: at or to a large distance above the ground
dictionary_examples: We flew high above the city.
He threw the ball high into the air.
learner_examples: Being in the cabin high above Vienna both of them th[ought] about killing the other. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: at or to a large amount or level
dictionary_examples: Temperatures rose as high as 40 degrees.
learner_examples: Can we expect to see the world unemployment rate reach as high as fifty percent? (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: into or inside a building
dictionary_examples: Come indoors, it's cold outside.
Spring bulbs can be grown indoors.
learner_examples: I love being indoors, eating or watching TV. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: well, healthy, or happy
dictionary_examples: "How are you?" "I'm fine, thanks."
I felt terrible last night but I feel fine this morning.
learner_examples: I'm fine. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali)

pos_items.definition: used to agree with a suggestion, idea, etc.
dictionary_examples: "Shall we meet at 8 o'clock?" "Yes, that's fine."
learner_examples: OK that's fine. We['ll] meet at 8pm. (Key English Test; A2; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: good or good enough
dictionary_examples: "Is this soup hot enough?" "Yes, it's fine."

pos_items.definition: sunny and not raining
dictionary_examples: If it's fine tomorrow, we could have a picnic.
learner_examples: Today the weather is fine and warm. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: excellent or much better than average
dictionary_examples: fine wines
This building is the finest example of its type.
learner_examples: There [we] will be served a fine dinner. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: thin or made of very small pieces
dictionary_examples: fine, brown hair
fine sand
learner_examples: They got their hands on some anthrax bacteria, grew them in petri dishes and with all her knowledge in biology managed to make anthrax spores. Her friends ground the clumps of spores into fine particles. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: an amount of money that you must pay for breaking a rule or law
dictionary_examples: She had to pay a fine.
a parking fine
The maximum penalty is a $1000 fine.
If found guilty, he faces a heavy fine.
learner_examples: She was made to pay a fine and she wasn't sent to prison. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to charge someone an amount of money as a punishment for not obeying a rule or law
dictionary_examples: Drivers who break the speed limit can expect to be fined heavily.
They fined him $100 for using threatening behaviour.
learner_examples: Besides, you can be fined by the police. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: very well or without any problems
dictionary_examples: "How did your exam go?" "It went fine, I think."
The car was working fine yesterday.
learner_examples: The couple was great and everything went fine. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: a set of rooms for living in which are part of a larger building and are usually all on one floor
dictionary_examples: a furnished/unfurnished flat
a block of flats
to buy/rent/move into/move out of a flat
They have a house in the country and a flat in London.
learner_examples: I live in a flat. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: level and smooth, with no curved, high, or hollow parts
dictionary_examples: An ice rink needs to be completely flat.
Roll out the pastry on a flat surface.
Much of the countryside in East Anglia is very flat.
learner_examples: The countryside is very flat and for this kind of holiday it's really perfect!! (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: If a tyre, ball, etc. is flat, it does not contain enough air.
dictionary_examples: When I got to the car, I discovered I had a flat tyre.
learner_examples: I found my bicycle with a flat tyre and realised I would be late instead of early. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: If a drink is flat, it does not contain enough bubbles of gas.
dictionary_examples: This lemonade is flat.

pos_items.definition: Flat shoes do not raise your feet far from the ground.
dictionary_examples: Wear flat shoes - you'll be on your feet all day.
learner_examples: In your last letter you wanted me to tell you about clothes. Well, as you know I'm tall so I always wear flat shoes in light colours like white, light green and blue. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: in a level position, often against another surface
dictionary_examples: Lay the cloth flat across the table.

pos_items.definition: If an event or joke falls flat, it fails to have the effect that you wanted, such as making people laugh.
dictionary_examples: All the jokes in his speech fell flat.
learner_examples: The cultural visits fell flat [in comparison] to their expectations, although the sightseeing tour of Willstown was, as the students said, "fascinating". (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to fall over so that your face hits the ground, often in an embarrassing way
dictionary_examples: I stepped on the ice and fell flat on my face.
learner_examples: You can guess what happened next - I fell flat on my face right in the mud and I have never felt more embarrassed in my life! (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: having a large distance from the bottom to the top
dictionary_examples: a high building/mountain
learner_examples: And also you can see high mount[a]ins [and] beautiful lakes. (Key English Test; A2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: a large distance above the ground or the level of the sea
dictionary_examples: a high window
The village was high up in the mountains.
learner_examples: Look[ing] out [of] the window, I can see the birds high up on the trees. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: great in amount, size or level
dictionary_examples: a high temperature
high prices/costs

learner_examples: Be careful while you are in Brazil because sometimes people charge really high prices for everything just because you are a tourist. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: very good
dictionary_examples: high standards/quality
