learner_examples: There were lots of CD players and [everything] was high quality. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: important, powerful, or at the top level of something
dictionary_examples: a high rank
Safety is our highest priority.
learner_examples: Living is definitely the highest priority [all] over the world. (First Certificate in English; B2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: If a food is high in something, it contains a lot of it.
dictionary_examples: Avoid foods that are high in salt.
learner_examples: Since there is no time even for cooking a healthy meal, they get used to ready meals that are high in fat and salt. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Singhalese)

pos_items.definition: If someone is high, they are behaving in an unusual way because they have taken an illegal drug.
dictionary_examples: The whole band seemed to be high on drugs.
learner_examples: As he was in that enormous garden covering himself with leaves lying on his back, he realised that he didn't want to watch the end of the Universe there in that place, but because he was so high on drugs he didn't even realise that he could simply stand up and go home. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: at or to a large distance above the ground
dictionary_examples: We flew high above the city.
He threw the ball high into the air.
learner_examples: Being in the cabin high above Vienna both of them th[ought] about killing the other. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: at or to a large amount or level
dictionary_examples: Temperatures rose as high as 40 degrees.
learner_examples: Can we expect to see the world unemployment rate reach as high as fifty percent? (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not busy doing anything
dictionary_examples: Are you free this evening?
I don't have much free time.
learner_examples: I am free this afternoon. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: not costing any money
dictionary_examples: I got some free cinema tickets.
Members all receive a free copy of the monthly newsletter.
We will install your washing machine free of charge.
learner_examples: You don't have to bring any money because it is free. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: not limited or controlled
dictionary_examples: a free society
Am I free to leave now?
People should be free to say what they think.
The agreement gives companies free access to the markets of member countries.
learner_examples: The plan was this: they would call the police, which would trap the man so the child would be free to return to his mother. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: not in prison
dictionary_examples: He will soon be a free man again.
learner_examples: I will [regret it] for the rest of my life, because I wanted to be a free man... (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to allow someone to leave prison or to allow a person or animal to escape
dictionary_examples: He opened the cage and set the birds free.
learner_examples: To sum up, animals should be set free and live as they should live in nature. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: not being used by anyone
dictionary_examples: Is this seat free?
learner_examples: The hall was full of people and no seat was free. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: not containing or having anything harmful or unpleasant
dictionary_examples: a life free from pain
learner_examples: We can start to grow new plants so that our environment looks fresh and enchanting and free from pesticides and sicknesses as well. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: permission to make your own decisions about how you want to do something
dictionary_examples: The students were given a free hand as far as designing their product was concerned.
learner_examples: But unlike my parents, I wouldn't give my children a free hand in solving their problems. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: without cost or payment
dictionary_examples: Children under five travel free.
He offered to do it for free.
learner_examples: I get tickets for free. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not tied, limited, or controlled
dictionary_examples: The horse broke free and ran away.
learner_examples: If animals were born free, why [do] they have to live in a prison? (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: to suddenly escape or become separate from something
dictionary_examples: The prisoner broke free while the guards weren't looking.

pos_items.definition: to escape from someone or something that is controlling you
dictionary_examples: She tried to break free from the social conditioning of her upbringing.
learner_examples: I would like to revisit there one day as it's firmly connected to my ad[o]lescence, when I struggled to break free from my peers, [and] tried to establish my own identity. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: to allow someone to leave a prison or place where they have been kept
dictionary_examples: After a ten-hour siege the gunman agreed to free the hostages.
learner_examples: We were taken hostage by a bank robber but the police came and freed us. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in a generous way
dictionary_examples: Please give generously to Children in Need.
learner_examples: I can't think of any other person who opens her house so generously as you do! (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in or into a room, building, container, etc.
dictionary_examples: There were some keys inside the box.
learner_examples: I kept it inside the jewel box. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: in less than a particular length of time
dictionary_examples: The doctor's promised to be here inside an hour.
learner_examples: You can reach two stations on the tube-line seven inside 10 minutes; in addition there are two bus-stops even closer. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: in or into a room, building, container, etc.
dictionary_examples: I'm freezing, let's go back inside.
learner_examples: We can stay inside and play with the computer. (Key English Test; A2; Norwegian)

pos_items.definition: If you have a feeling inside, you have a feeling although you might not show it to other people.
dictionary_examples: She couldn't cope with the grief she felt inside.
learner_examples: They had to go to the vet more often but it wasn't hard for them because of the love that they felt inside. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: in or on the part of something under its surface
dictionary_examples: He put the documents carefully in his inside pocket.
learner_examples: At first Chris didn't seem to recognize him, but as soon as he did, his hand reached [into] his inside pocket. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: information that is only known by people who are part of an organization, group, etc.
dictionary_examples: I needed someone with inside knowledge to back up my story.
learner_examples: I'm pretty sure that getting in touch with the customs and lifestyle of another country will open a completely new horizon to the students and they'll be enchanted by the 'inside knowledge' they will be able to gain. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: the inner part, space or side of something
dictionary_examples: Did you clean the inside of the car?
The hotel looked shabby from the street, but it was fine on the inside.
learner_examples: Anyway, after the show I felt hungry so I went to the restaurant but it was closed because they were having the inside altered. (First Certificate in English; B2; )

pos_items.definition: If a piece of clothing is inside out, the part that is usually outside is on the inside.
dictionary_examples: She had her jumper on inside out.

pos_items.definition: to know everything about something
dictionary_examples: He knows the system inside out.
learner_examples: The participants got to know Britain inside out and they are happy with the knowledge they gained. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: extremely
dictionary_examples: I think the team played incredibly well.
learner_examples: It was incredibly crowded. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is difficult to believe
dictionary_examples: Incredibly, no one was hurt.
learner_examples: Incredibly, and against all my expectations, everything started going wrong from the very begin[n]ing. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not direct
dictionary_examples: She still controls the company indirectly, through her son.
learner_examples: This indirectly improves the quality of life and people will feel re-energised. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Malay)

pos_items.definition: in a way that cannot be avoided
dictionary_examples: Their arguments inevitably end in tears.
learner_examples: Should you, my humble reader, happen to reach fame and fortune, try never to forget that appearing always as an ordinary human being would inevitably grant you more empathy from the people surro[u]nding you. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in an informal way
dictionary_examples: It's an outdoor party, so dress informally.
learner_examples: We dress casually and very informally and you often see body piercings and tat[t]oos being displayed around the place. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: always
dictionary_examples: The train is invariably packed.
learner_examples: Nevertheless, there is invariably an exception to the rule. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in many countries
dictionary_examples: Her internationally acclaimed novel has won several literary prizes.
learner_examples: This film was directed by Yasujino-Ozo, who is internationally famous, although his film is very Japanese. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: more or extra
dictionary_examples: For further details of the offer, call this number.
Further information can be found on our website.
We'll let you know if there's any further news about the competition.
learner_examples: For further information, contact Joey Hung. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: additional
dictionary_examples: A further 20 stores will be opening in Europe next year.
learner_examples: As a matter of fact, only 5% of the total income was taken to pay for administration costs, and a further 10% to pay for the cost of entertainment. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: (comparative of far) at or to a place or time that is a longer distance away
dictionary_examples: Let's walk a bit further down the road.
learner_examples: When we left your place we drove on the motorway to Trier and further on to Luxembourg. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: more
dictionary_examples: He refused to discuss the matter further.
Did you get any further with your research?
learner_examples: I demand a full refund or I will be forced to take this mat[t]er further. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to make something develop or become more successful
dictionary_examples: He'll do anything to further his career.
learner_examples: This could be because some of [the] Education graduates were already in [the] education field and pursuing a graduate course was a means of furthering their career or knowledge. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: more or extra
dictionary_examples: For further details of the offer, call this number.
Further information can be found on our website.
We'll let you know if there's any further news about the competition.
learner_examples: For further information, contact Joey Hung. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: additional
dictionary_examples: A further 20 stores will be opening in Europe next year.
learner_examples: As a matter of fact, only 5% of the total income was taken to pay for administration costs, and a further 10% to pay for the cost of entertainment. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: (comparative of far) at or to a place or time that is a longer distance away
dictionary_examples: Let's walk a bit further down the road.
learner_examples: When we left your place we drove on the motorway to Trier and further on to Luxembourg. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: more
dictionary_examples: He refused to discuss the matter further.
Did you get any further with your research?
learner_examples: I demand a full refund or I will be forced to take this mat[t]er further. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to make something develop or become more successful
dictionary_examples: He'll do anything to further his career.
learner_examples: This could be because some of [the] Education graduates were already in [the] education field and pursuing a graduate course was a means of furthering their career or knowledge. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: after a long time or some difficulty
dictionary_examples: We finally got home at midnight.
After months of looking he finally found a job.
learner_examples: Well, I have finally decided that I will paint my room blue. (Key English Test; A2; Marathi)

pos_items.definition: used especially at the beginning of a sentence to introduce the last point or idea
dictionary_examples: Finally, I'd like to thank everyone for coming this evening.
learner_examples: Finally, I want you to say hi [to] everybody and I am looking forward to see[ing] you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: now or without waiting or thinking about something
dictionary_examples: We really ought to leave immediately.
The purpose of the meeting wasn't immediately obvious.
learner_examples: Can you send me it immediately? (Key English Test; A2; German)

pos_items.definition: next to something, or close to something in time
dictionary_examples: Milton Street is on the left, immediately after the bank.
They moved in immediately before Christmas.
We heard a loud crash from the room immediately above us.
learner_examples: You should go on up to the end of the street, as my flat is the last on the right[-hand] side, immediately before the crossroads. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: often
dictionary_examples: frequently asked questions
I see him quite frequently.
The buses run less/more frequently at certain times.
learner_examples: I met a beautiful girl and now we are seeing each other frequently, about twice a week. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: into small pieces
dictionary_examples: Finely chop the onion.

pos_items.definition: in a way that is certain or fixed
dictionary_examples: I firmly believe that we must take action on this.
learner_examples: I firmly believe that some of the things you mentioned are wrong. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: strongly; in a way that will not become loose
dictionary_examples: Make sure the rope is firmly attached before attempting to climb down it.
learner_examples: Slowly but firmly I grab[b]ed the door handle, took another quick glance in the room, and turned it. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is certain or fixed
dictionary_examples: I firmly believe that we must take action on this.
learner_examples: I firmly believe that some of the things you mentioned are wrong. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: strongly; in a way that will not become loose
dictionary_examples: Make sure the rope is firmly attached before attempting to climb down it.
learner_examples: Slowly but firmly I grab[b]ed the door handle, took another quick glance in the room, and turned it. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: without being controlled or limited
dictionary_examples: For the first time in months she could move freely.
Exotic foods are freely available in supermarkets.
She freely admits that she was partly to blame.
We encourage the victims to talk freely about their experiences.
learner_examples: We have always been able to speak freely with each other and this letter is no exception. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: slowly over a period of time or a distance
dictionary_examples: Gradually, she realized that he wasn't telling her the truth.
learner_examples: Books will gradually disappear, and instead we will read all the things we want [o]n our computer. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: at a high level
dictionary_examples: a highly paid job
a highly educated workforce
learner_examples: I am [a] 24-year-old highly educated Turkish boy. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: very or to a large degree
dictionary_examples: a highly effective treatment
We are highly unlikely to meet anyone here.
learner_examples: Now it features a highly effective searching system. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: to have or express a very good opinion of someone or something
dictionary_examples: The course is very highly thought of.
learner_examples: This in itself would speak highly of the school and will attract many candidates and parents. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in a perfect way
dictionary_examples: She seemed ideally suited for the job.
learner_examples: I believe I am ideally suited for this job. (First Certificate in English; B2; Pass)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about how something would be in a perfect situation
dictionary_examples: Ideally, I'd like to work at home.
learner_examples: Ideally, through this camp, I would like to teach Japanese songs and dance to them and I would also like to learn about their culture. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in a perfect way
dictionary_examples: She seemed ideally suited for the job.
learner_examples: I believe I am ideally suited for this job. (First Certificate in English; B2; Pass)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about how something would be in a perfect situation
dictionary_examples: Ideally, I'd like to work at home.
learner_examples: Ideally, through this camp, I would like to teach Japanese songs and dance to them and I would also like to learn about their culture. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is important
dictionary_examples: If we served more soft drinks, there would be fewer hangovers and, more importantly, fewer drink-driving incidents.
learner_examples: Lastly, and most importantly, what is the cost? (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: more and more
dictionary_examples: to be increasingly important/common
Increasingly, there is pressure on the council to reverse its decision.
learner_examples: Among them are the increasingly popular reality shows and all the daily news about gossip and scandal. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is independent
dictionary_examples: The two scientists both made the same discovery independently, at roughly the same time.
Each part of the organization operates independently of the others.
learner_examples: What students should understand is the existence of links among apparently different subjects and the impossibility of studying them independently or, [worse], studying one and neglecting the others. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: at the beginning
dictionary_examples: Initially, most people approved of the new scheme.
The damage was far more serious than initially believed.
learner_examples: He initially disagreed with his wife but after much persuasion, he finally gave in. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in an innocent way
dictionary_examples: "Have I done something wrong?" she asked innocently.
He said he had obtained the television innocently, not knowing it had been stolen.
learner_examples: Denny had innocently [turned on] the light to see if there was anything of interest in the other room. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: Both drivers were killed instantly.
learner_examples: To talk to a friend from another city or country instantly online is really nice and exciting. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: officially
dictionary_examples: The deal will be formally announced on Tuesday.
learner_examples: First of all I'll tell you a little about the ceremony. It's usually held in a church, (in our case, a Catholic one as we are Catholics); the priest reads some parts of the Bible to the bridegroom (that's usually chosen before with the couple); then they exchange rings and they'll be formally married. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in a polite way
dictionary_examples: They shook hands formally.
learner_examples: On New Year's Day all members in a family got together (members who lived separately came home), greeted [each other] more formally than usual, and ate the special food. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: officially
dictionary_examples: The deal will be formally announced on Tuesday.
learner_examples: First of all I'll tell you a little about the ceremony. It's usually held in a church, (in our case, a Catholic one as we are Catholics); the priest reads some parts of the Bible to the bridegroom (that's usually chosen before with the couple); then they exchange rings and they'll be formally married. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in a polite way
dictionary_examples: They shook hands formally.
learner_examples: On New Year's Day all members in a family got together (members who lived separately came home), greeted [each other] more formally than usual, and ate the special food. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in a happy way
dictionary_examples: He was happily married with two young children.
The baby sucked happily on a corner of her blanket.
learner_examples: Now we are happily married and I cannot stop thinking what would have happened if I had thrown away the e-mail...? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is very willing
dictionary_examples: I'd happily offer to help him if I thought it would make any difference.
learner_examples: I think young people would happily accept it. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: having a good or lucky result
dictionary_examples: Happily, the operation was a complete success.
learner_examples: Happily, I had met a friend who could take me to school! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is connected to history
dictionary_examples: The film makes no attempt to be historically accurate.
Historically, there have always been close links between France and Scotland.
learner_examples: Well, maybe this brief description of my travel in time is not historically accurate; nevertheless I hope that you have enjoyed yourself reading it as much as I did writing it, and I hope you will consider it worth[y] of publication in your magazine. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: done or happening every hour
dictionary_examples: There's an hourly bus service into town.
A nurse checked him at hourly intervals.

pos_items.definition: for each hour
dictionary_examples: an hourly rate/wage
learner_examples: I'll also call the shop and ask [about] the hourly rate and the working hours. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: once every hour
dictionary_examples: Trains stop here hourly.
learner_examples: This train runs hourly and takes about 90 minutes to Kassel which is the second stop. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: now or without waiting or thinking about something
dictionary_examples: We really ought to leave immediately.
The purpose of the meeting wasn't immediately obvious.
learner_examples: Can you send me it immediately? (Key English Test; A2; German)

pos_items.definition: next to something, or close to something in time
dictionary_examples: Milton Street is on the left, immediately after the bank.
They moved in immediately before Christmas.
We heard a loud crash from the room immediately above us.
learner_examples: You should go on up to the end of the street, as my flat is the last on the right[-hand] side, immediately before the crossroads. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: extremely
dictionary_examples: immensely powerful/popular
learner_examples: People who were previously nothing more than peasants grew immensely rich, while the former aristocracy of land owners lost its dominat[ing] position. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not suitable
dictionary_examples: The meeting was inappropriately handled and an argument broke out.
learner_examples: For instance, the refreshment tent was inappropriately located, making it difficult for the participants to reach it. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: separately rather than with others
dictionary_examples: I spoke to them all individually.
The sweets are individually wrapped.
learner_examples: This has the additional advantage that students can work individually on what seems to be most necessary for them. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: in way that involves a lot of work in a short period of time
dictionary_examples: I spent three weeks working intensively on my thesis.
learner_examples: The canteen gets very busy and noisy at lunchtimes, but we all enjoy chatting to our friend after intensively studying in the classes. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce information that you think is surprising and interesting
dictionary_examples: Interestingly, he never actually said that he was innocent.
learner_examples: Russians today prefer fast food due to a rapid lifestyle. Interestingly, this refers only to lunch time; about 80% of Russians will prefer eating [a] traditional Russian meal for dinner. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: inside a person, object, organization, place or country
dictionary_examples: This medicine is for external use only and should not be taken internally.
learner_examples: I am actually very interested in taking the course, because recently I have change[d] my job and one of my functions is to create a page on the intranet to share information about the company internally. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in a basic and important way
dictionary_examples: Nothing has fundamentally changed.
I still believe that people are fundamentally good.
learner_examples: Japanese gardens are fundamentally different from those designed in Europe. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: in a harsh way
dictionary_examples: I thought she'd been treated rather harshly.
learner_examples: The public television is harshly criticised for joining the commercial flow of the private stations and targeting large audiences, instead of presenting more ambitious programmes of high quality. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: extremely, or in a way that makes you lose hope
dictionary_examples: hopelessly lost
They met at university and fell hopelessly in love.
learner_examples: It's never easy to be young and hopelessly in love. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: for a period of time for which no end has been fixed
dictionary_examples: His visit has been postponed indefinitely.
learner_examples: Each one of them tries so painfully to hide away the natural feelings emanating from within. But it is simply impossible to do so indefinitely. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: very or very much
dictionary_examples: Travel is infinitely more comfortable now than it used to be.
learner_examples: It would be infinitely preferable for the people to park their cars in the multi-storey car park. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: extremely
dictionary_examples: Her book is intensely personal.
learner_examples: Finally it was settled: they were both fertile; still able to have the child they had longed for so intensely. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: with strong, serious emotions
dictionary_examples: She stared at me intensely.
learner_examples: She caressed the frame with great tenderness and, after looking intensely at the picture, embraced it passionately. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that a situation is strange because it is the opposite of what you expected
dictionary_examples: Ironically, the only good book on this subject has gone out of print.
learner_examples: Either way, food is a big industry and a vital contributor to our culture, but ironically, food is also the biggest problem in the world. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: coming before all others
dictionary_examples: This is my first trip to New York.
Karen was the first person to arrive.
We met for the first time yesterday.
learner_examples: My first day in college is Monday. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Albanian)

pos_items.definition: most important, top
dictionary_examples: Sheila won first prize in the photo competition.
learner_examples: It was good because my cousin played and won the first prize. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: when you first see or hear about something or someone
dictionary_examples: It was love at first sight!
It may, at first sight, seem a surprising choice.
learner_examples: It was love at first sight! (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: at the start of a situation
dictionary_examples: Why did you invite her in the first place?
learner_examples: In the first place, you were unknown people for me, but now you are my special foreign friends. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: before everything or everyone else
dictionary_examples: I can come out tonight, but I've got to do my homework first.
learner_examples: I have to go to [the] dentist first! (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: before doing anything else
dictionary_examples: First of all, we swam 200 metres in the pool.
learner_examples: First of all, I bought a new t-shirt, [a] cool jacket and jeans. After that, I went to the athletic[s] store. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce the first idea, reason, etc. in a series
dictionary_examples: First of all, I'd like to ask you a few questions about your childhood.
learner_examples: First of all, thanks for your letter. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce the first idea, reason, etc. in a series
dictionary_examples: First, I want to thank my parents.
learner_examples: First, I want to say "Thank you!" (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: for the first time
dictionary_examples: When did you first meet each other?
I first heard the song on the radio.
learner_examples: I first heard of it [o]n the radio and then I saw a leaflet about it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: at the beginning of a situation or period of time
dictionary_examples: At first I thought she was unfriendly, but actually she's just shy.
learner_examples: At first, when I arrived I was very nervous because I didn't know anyone, but then a girl started talking to me and I felt better. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: more than anything else
dictionary_examples: In spite of being elected to office, she remains first and foremost a writer.
learner_examples: First and foremost it is my longing to help others with what they cannot do for themselves. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to consider someone or something to be the most important thing
dictionary_examples: Most couples put their children first when sorting out their problems.
learner_examples: On the other hand, we forget about our personality and the worth that we have as individuals; we put our wishes first, [rather] than what we really need in life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to be the most important person or thing
dictionary_examples: Her career always comes first.
learner_examples: They do not take the time to sit down and enjoy being with their family. The work comes first, and the family next. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: the first person or thing to do or be something, or the first person or thing mentioned
dictionary_examples: Tonight sees the first of three documentaries about cancer.
She was one of the first to arrive.
He is the first to admit that much of his success is due to his good looks.
learner_examples: I prefer the first because it's an exciting story of a cat that escapes from a dangerous house lived [in] by an aggressive dog. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to be something that has never happened before
dictionary_examples: Man walking on the moon was a first in space history.

pos_items.definition: difficult to understand or do
dictionary_examples: There were some really hard questions in the exam.
It's hard being a single mother.
Her handwriting is very hard to read.
The topics get harder later in the course.
learner_examples: I don't like gram[m]ar. English gram[m]ar is hard for me. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: firm and stiff, and not easy to press or bend
dictionary_examples: a hard surface
There was a heavy frost last night and the ground is still hard.
learner_examples: We have to bring with us three pencils, two hard pencils and one soft. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: needing or using a lot of physical or mental effort
dictionary_examples: Go on - give it a good hard push!
It was hard work on the farm but satisfying.
learner_examples: It's the perfect place to stay and relax after a week of hard work. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to criticize someone too much, or to treat them unfairly
dictionary_examples: Don't be too hard on him - he's new to the job.
learner_examples: That's why I was a little hard on you at first. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not gentle or kind
dictionary_examples: She had a cold, hard look in her eyes.
learner_examples: To conclude, I'd like to apologise for being maybe a "bit too nasty" to you, but these "hard words", were due only to my hurt feelings! (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: full of problems and difficult to deal with
dictionary_examples: My grandparents had a very hard life.
The past few months must've been really hard for you.
learner_examples: It was a really hard time for all of us, but it passed and, I hope, will never come again. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to do or learn something by experiencing a lot of problems or difficulty
dictionary_examples: I learned the hard way that training every single day is not the best way to get fit.
learner_examples: If you don't know the past, you're liable to live through it again as instead of deriving the lessons from someone else's experiences, you'll have to learn them the hard way, by trial and error. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: to make someone unhappy by causing them problems
dictionary_examples: Our divorce has been particularly hard on the children.
learner_examples: Also it was hard on our family only seeing my father late at night being tired or for a weekend, if he was not on a business-trip. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to criticize someone and make them feel guilty about something they have done
dictionary_examples: Ever since I missed the goal, the other players have been giving me a hard time.
learner_examples: I'm not saying that I wasn't normal or anything, I just gave my family a hard time sometimes. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: with a lot of physical or mental effort
dictionary_examples: She tried very hard but she wasn't quite fast enough.
You'll have to work harder, if you want to pass this exam.
learner_examples: I don't like to work very hard and very late in [the] classroom and I don't like computer[s]. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: with a lot of force
dictionary_examples: It's been raining hard all day.
She kicked the ball as hard as she could.
learner_examples: It was a clo[u]dy day, the wind [was] blow[ing] hard, and the city was quiet. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in the place where you are
dictionary_examples: Does Jane live near here?
Come here!
I've lived here for about two years.
London is only 50 miles from here.
Come here - I've got something to show you.
It says here that she was born in 1984.
learner_examples: He live[s] in Galicia, but now he's here in Cambridge to study English. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used when saying who you are on the phone
dictionary_examples: Hello, it's Tim here.

pos_items.definition: used when you are giving someone something
dictionary_examples: Here's a present for you.
"Have you got the paper?" "Yes. Here you are."
learner_examples: Dear Jo, Here is some information about the art class. (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: here you are/here it is, etc.
pos_items.definition: used when you see someone or something you have been looking for or waiting for
dictionary_examples: Here she is at last.
Here's our bus.
I've lost my watch - oh, here it is.

pos_items.definition: at this point in a discussion or piece of writing
dictionary_examples: I don't have time here to go into all the arguments.
learner_examples: My idea here is to highlight the fact that computers are going to control our lives. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in several different places or directions but without any pattern
dictionary_examples: Tall trees were growing here and there.
learner_examples: In the cinemas there were a few broken seats here and there. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to ask someone if they are well and happy
dictionary_examples: "Hi, Lucy, how are you?" "Fine, thanks, how are you?"
learner_examples: Dear Ramesh, How are you? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask or talk about quantity, size, or age
dictionary_examples: Do you know how many people are coming?
How much was that dress?
How big is the house?
How old are they?
learner_examples: How much does it cost? (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to make a suggestion
dictionary_examples: How about a drink?
How about going to the cinema?
learner_examples: How about going on Monday evening? (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to ask or talk about the way something happens or is done
dictionary_examples: How do we get to the town from here?
How did you hear about the concert?
How does this machine work?
Roz doesn't know how to ride a bicycle.
How can/could he be so stupid?
I don't know how anyone could think that way.
learner_examples: How did you know I liked skateboards? (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask about someone's health
dictionary_examples: How is your mother?
How are you feeling this morning?
learner_examples: How are you feeling? I hope you are feeling better. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask or talk about what an experience or event was like
dictionary_examples: How was your flight?
How did you find the lecture?
How did you like the concert?
learner_examples: How was your birthday? (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: used for emphasis
dictionary_examples: I can't tell you how pleased I am that you came.
How nice to see you!
I was amazed at how quickly she finished.
learner_examples: It's quite amazing how quickly she could change my reason to learn English. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used to ask for someone's opinion on a particular subject
dictionary_examples: So the town was nice - how about the food?
learner_examples: I don't like shopping with my mum because she wants me to wear weird clothes. How about you? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: a formal greeting for someone that you have not met before
dictionary_examples: "I'm Jack Stewart." "How do you do? I'm Angela Black."

pos_items.definition: said to mean that something is strange/stupid, etc.
dictionary_examples: I found my keys in the fridge - how stupid is that?
learner_examples: The best thing is that my current rent is only 2/3 of the old flat and the landlord is paying the facility bills and council tax for me. How good is that? (International English Language Testing System; C2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to ask why or how something has happened
dictionary_examples: How come you didn't go to the party?
learner_examples: Off the record: How come that your reporter can print such lies when knowing they are perhaps hurting certain people in this important matter? (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to express anger about something someone has done
dictionary_examples: How dare you talk to me like that!
learner_examples: How dare you call that high standards?! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about how true something is
dictionary_examples: How far do politicians represent the views of ordinary people?
learner_examples: How far and to what extent would the characteristics we are born with influence our future development in life? (International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: coming before all others
dictionary_examples: This is my first trip to New York.
Karen was the first person to arrive.
We met for the first time yesterday.
learner_examples: My first day in college is Monday. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Albanian)

pos_items.definition: most important, top
dictionary_examples: Sheila won first prize in the photo competition.
learner_examples: It was good because my cousin played and won the first prize. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: when you first see or hear about something or someone
dictionary_examples: It was love at first sight!
It may, at first sight, seem a surprising choice.
learner_examples: It was love at first sight! (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: at the start of a situation
dictionary_examples: Why did you invite her in the first place?
learner_examples: In the first place, you were unknown people for me, but now you are my special foreign friends. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: before everything or everyone else
dictionary_examples: I can come out tonight, but I've got to do my homework first.
learner_examples: I have to go to [the] dentist first! (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: before doing anything else
dictionary_examples: First of all, we swam 200 metres in the pool.
learner_examples: First of all, I bought a new t-shirt, [a] cool jacket and jeans. After that, I went to the athletic[s] store. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce the first idea, reason, etc. in a series
dictionary_examples: First of all, I'd like to ask you a few questions about your childhood.
learner_examples: First of all, thanks for your letter. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce the first idea, reason, etc. in a series
dictionary_examples: First, I want to thank my parents.
learner_examples: First, I want to say "Thank you!" (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: for the first time
dictionary_examples: When did you first meet each other?
I first heard the song on the radio.
learner_examples: I first heard of it [o]n the radio and then I saw a leaflet about it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: at the beginning of a situation or period of time
dictionary_examples: At first I thought she was unfriendly, but actually she's just shy.
learner_examples: At first, when I arrived I was very nervous because I didn't know anyone, but then a girl started talking to me and I felt better. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: more than anything else
dictionary_examples: In spite of being elected to office, she remains first and foremost a writer.
learner_examples: First and foremost it is my longing to help others with what they cannot do for themselves. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to consider someone or something to be the most important thing
dictionary_examples: Most couples put their children first when sorting out their problems.
learner_examples: On the other hand, we forget about our personality and the worth that we have as individuals; we put our wishes first, [rather] than what we really need in life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to be the most important person or thing
dictionary_examples: Her career always comes first.
learner_examples: They do not take the time to sit down and enjoy being with their family. The work comes first, and the family next. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: the first person or thing to do or be something, or the first person or thing mentioned
dictionary_examples: Tonight sees the first of three documentaries about cancer.
She was one of the first to arrive.
He is the first to admit that much of his success is due to his good looks.
learner_examples: I prefer the first because it's an exciting story of a cat that escapes from a dangerous house lived [in] by an aggressive dog. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to be something that has never happened before
dictionary_examples: Man walking on the moon was a first in space history.

pos_items.definition: in the place where you are
dictionary_examples: Does Jane live near here?
Come here!
I've lived here for about two years.
London is only 50 miles from here.
Come here - I've got something to show you.
It says here that she was born in 1984.
learner_examples: He live[s] in Galicia, but now he's here in Cambridge to study English. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used when saying who you are on the phone
dictionary_examples: Hello, it's Tim here.

pos_items.definition: used when you are giving someone something
dictionary_examples: Here's a present for you.
"Have you got the paper?" "Yes. Here you are."
learner_examples: Dear Jo, Here is some information about the art class. (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: here you are/here it is, etc.
pos_items.definition: used when you see someone or something you have been looking for or waiting for
dictionary_examples: Here she is at last.
Here's our bus.
I've lost my watch - oh, here it is.

pos_items.definition: at this point in a discussion or piece of writing
dictionary_examples: I don't have time here to go into all the arguments.
learner_examples: My idea here is to highlight the fact that computers are going to control our lives. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in several different places or directions but without any pattern
dictionary_examples: Tall trees were growing here and there.
learner_examples: In the cinemas there were a few broken seats here and there. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: the place where you live or feel you belong
dictionary_examples: I tried to ring him, but he wasn't at home.
We sold our home in London and moved to Scotland.
He left home when he was eighteen.
I was actually born in New Zealand, but I've lived in England for so long that it feels like home now.
learner_examples: That's why I love my home. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to feel happy and confident in a place or situation
dictionary_examples: After a month she felt at home in her new job.
learner_examples: I explained: "I was in Manchester for just 10 month[s] and [during] that time the people from there made me feel at home [so] I feel proud to have the accent." (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the place where you usually find something or someone, or where they come from
dictionary_examples: France, the home of good food
learner_examples: Every golfer - and those watching golf - know, that the home of golf is St. Andrews in Scotland. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: to behave in a relaxed way in a place, as if it was your own home
dictionary_examples: Take off your coat and make yourself at home.
learner_examples: Please relax and make yourself at home and help yourself. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: a place where people who need special care live
dictionary_examples: a children's home
My grandmother lives in a home now.
learner_examples: However, I am also experienced with elderly people because I worked in an old people's home for about 3 months in the summer 1997. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: a family in which the parents do not now live together
dictionary_examples: Many of these children come from broken homes.
learner_examples: The development of the modern society has brought with it a growing number of broken homes, divorces and economic problems which have directly affected the parent-child relationship. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: to the place where you live
dictionary_examples: He didn't come home until midnight.
I went home to visit my parents.
learner_examples: I must go home at midnight because I have to travel tomorrow. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: at or in the place someone lives
dictionary_examples: Will you be home tomorrow evening?
learner_examples: I'll not be home this afternoon. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Albanian)

pos_items.definition: used to ask someone if they are well and happy
dictionary_examples: "Hi, Lucy, how are you?" "Fine, thanks, how are you?"
learner_examples: Dear Ramesh, How are you? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask or talk about quantity, size, or age
dictionary_examples: Do you know how many people are coming?
How much was that dress?
How big is the house?
How old are they?
learner_examples: How much does it cost? (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to make a suggestion
dictionary_examples: How about a drink?
How about going to the cinema?
learner_examples: How about going on Monday evening? (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to ask or talk about the way something happens or is done
dictionary_examples: How do we get to the town from here?
How did you hear about the concert?
How does this machine work?
Roz doesn't know how to ride a bicycle.
How can/could he be so stupid?
I don't know how anyone could think that way.
learner_examples: How did you know I liked skateboards? (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask about someone's health
dictionary_examples: How is your mother?
How are you feeling this morning?
learner_examples: How are you feeling? I hope you are feeling better. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask or talk about what an experience or event was like
dictionary_examples: How was your flight?
How did you find the lecture?
How did you like the concert?
learner_examples: How was your birthday? (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: used for emphasis
dictionary_examples: I can't tell you how pleased I am that you came.
How nice to see you!
I was amazed at how quickly she finished.
learner_examples: It's quite amazing how quickly she could change my reason to learn English. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: for an extremely long time or too much time
dictionary_examples: We'd better walk a bit quicker - it's going to take forever if we go this slowly.
learner_examples: It would take forever. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: towards the direction that is in front of you
dictionary_examples: She leaned forward to whisper something in my ear.
learner_examples: I had to try once again to take a step forward, gently I took a step forward. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: towards the future
dictionary_examples: I always look forward, not back.
learner_examples: I want [you to] look a bit forward, try to ima[gine] how you will feel in one or two year[s'] [time]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is making progress
dictionary_examples: This is a big step forward for democracy.
learner_examples: For us, this would be a big step forward and a perfect motivation for the accountants. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: most distant
dictionary_examples: That's the furthest I can see without glasses.

pos_items.definition: 30 minutes past one o'clock/two o'clock/three o'clock, etc.
dictionary_examples: We got back to our hotel at half past seven.
learner_examples: I start college at half past nine. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: one of two equal parts of something
dictionary_examples: Rice is eaten by half of the world's population.
It'll take half an hour to get there.
Jenny lived in Beijing for a year and a half.
He cut up the apple and gave me half.
learner_examples: It takes an hour and a half. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: to divide something into two equal parts
dictionary_examples: Divide the dough in half and roll it out into two circles.
Fold the piece of paper in half.
learner_examples: They were very surprised when they found out [that] the gold was cut in half. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: a lot
dictionary_examples: She invited a lot of people to the party but half of them didn't turn up.
I don't even know where she is half (of) the time.
learner_examples: First of all, if [the] computer hadn't been invented, I wouldn't spend half of the day in front of it! (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: to be much less good/bad/exciting, etc. than something else
dictionary_examples: Her new book's not half as good as the last one.
learner_examples: Probably they wouldn't be half as famous as they are without press photographers, journalist[s], etc. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: partly, but not completely
dictionary_examples: half empty/full

pos_items.definition: difficult to understand or do
dictionary_examples: There were some really hard questions in the exam.
It's hard being a single mother.
Her handwriting is very hard to read.
The topics get harder later in the course.
learner_examples: I don't like gram[m]ar. English gram[m]ar is hard for me. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: firm and stiff, and not easy to press or bend
dictionary_examples: a hard surface
There was a heavy frost last night and the ground is still hard.
learner_examples: We have to bring with us three pencils, two hard pencils and one soft. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: needing or using a lot of physical or mental effort
dictionary_examples: Go on - give it a good hard push!
It was hard work on the farm but satisfying.
learner_examples: It's the perfect place to stay and relax after a week of hard work. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to criticize someone too much, or to treat them unfairly
dictionary_examples: Don't be too hard on him - he's new to the job.
learner_examples: That's why I was a little hard on you at first. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not gentle or kind
dictionary_examples: She had a cold, hard look in her eyes.
learner_examples: To conclude, I'd like to apologise for being maybe a "bit too nasty" to you, but these "hard words", were due only to my hurt feelings! (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: full of problems and difficult to deal with
dictionary_examples: My grandparents had a very hard life.
The past few months must've been really hard for you.
learner_examples: It was a really hard time for all of us, but it passed and, I hope, will never come again. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to do or learn something by experiencing a lot of problems or difficulty
dictionary_examples: I learned the hard way that training every single day is not the best way to get fit.
learner_examples: If you don't know the past, you're liable to live through it again as instead of deriving the lessons from someone else's experiences, you'll have to learn them the hard way, by trial and error. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: to make someone unhappy by causing them problems
dictionary_examples: Our divorce has been particularly hard on the children.
learner_examples: Also it was hard on our family only seeing my father late at night being tired or for a weekend, if he was not on a business-trip. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to criticize someone and make them feel guilty about something they have done
dictionary_examples: Ever since I missed the goal, the other players have been giving me a hard time.
learner_examples: I'm not saying that I wasn't normal or anything, I just gave my family a hard time sometimes. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: with a lot of physical or mental effort
