learner_examples: The plan was this: they would call the police, which would trap the man so the child would be free to return to his mother. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: not in prison
dictionary_examples: He will soon be a free man again.
learner_examples: I will [regret it] for the rest of my life, because I wanted to be a free man... (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to allow someone to leave prison or to allow a person or animal to escape
dictionary_examples: He opened the cage and set the birds free.
learner_examples: To sum up, animals should be set free and live as they should live in nature. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: not being used by anyone
dictionary_examples: Is this seat free?
learner_examples: The hall was full of people and no seat was free. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: not containing or having anything harmful or unpleasant
dictionary_examples: a life free from pain
learner_examples: We can start to grow new plants so that our environment looks fresh and enchanting and free from pesticides and sicknesses as well. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: permission to make your own decisions about how you want to do something
dictionary_examples: The students were given a free hand as far as designing their product was concerned.
learner_examples: But unlike my parents, I wouldn't give my children a free hand in solving their problems. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: without cost or payment
dictionary_examples: Children under five travel free.
He offered to do it for free.
learner_examples: I get tickets for free. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not tied, limited, or controlled
dictionary_examples: The horse broke free and ran away.
learner_examples: If animals were born free, why [do] they have to live in a prison? (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: to suddenly escape or become separate from something
dictionary_examples: The prisoner broke free while the guards weren't looking.

pos_items.definition: to escape from someone or something that is controlling you
dictionary_examples: She tried to break free from the social conditioning of her upbringing.
learner_examples: I would like to revisit there one day as it's firmly connected to my ad[o]lescence, when I struggled to break free from my peers, [and] tried to establish my own identity. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: to allow someone to leave a prison or place where they have been kept
dictionary_examples: After a ten-hour siege the gunman agreed to free the hostages.
learner_examples: We were taken hostage by a bank robber but the police came and freed us. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in a genuine or sincere way
dictionary_examples: I'm genuinely sorry for the extra work this has caused.
learner_examples: We are all genuinely interested in English literature. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in the place where you are
dictionary_examples: Does Jane live near here?
Come here!
I've lived here for about two years.
London is only 50 miles from here.
Come here - I've got something to show you.
It says here that she was born in 1984.
learner_examples: He live[s] in Galicia, but now he's here in Cambridge to study English. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used when saying who you are on the phone
dictionary_examples: Hello, it's Tim here.

pos_items.definition: used when you are giving someone something
dictionary_examples: Here's a present for you.
"Have you got the paper?" "Yes. Here you are."
learner_examples: Dear Jo, Here is some information about the art class. (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: here you are/here it is, etc.
pos_items.definition: used when you see someone or something you have been looking for or waiting for
dictionary_examples: Here she is at last.
Here's our bus.
I've lost my watch - oh, here it is.

pos_items.definition: at this point in a discussion or piece of writing
dictionary_examples: I don't have time here to go into all the arguments.
learner_examples: My idea here is to highlight the fact that computers are going to control our lives. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in several different places or directions but without any pattern
dictionary_examples: Tall trees were growing here and there.
learner_examples: In the cinemas there were a few broken seats here and there. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: towards the direction that is in front of you
dictionary_examples: She leaned forward to whisper something in my ear.
learner_examples: I had to try once again to take a step forward, gently I took a step forward. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: towards the future
dictionary_examples: I always look forward, not back.
learner_examples: I want [you to] look a bit forward, try to ima[gine] how you will feel in one or two year[s'] [time]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is making progress
dictionary_examples: This is a big step forward for democracy.
learner_examples: For us, this would be a big step forward and a perfect motivation for the accountants. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: for this reason
dictionary_examples: He's got an interview today, hence the suit.
Drivers have been shown to adapt their behaviour according to perceived risk. Hence, if they are wearing seat belts, they tend to take more risks with their driving.
learner_examples: Hence, the more competition there is, the more benefits are given to both people and society. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: also and more importantly
dictionary_examples: The whole report is badly written. Moreover, it's inaccurate.
It is a cheap and, moreover, effective way of dealing with the problem.
learner_examples: Because it is a well-k[n]own hotel it should be easy to find it. Moreover, it is really well-located, so it will allow you to move around the city without any problem. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: despite
dictionary_examples: Injuries notwithstanding, he won the semi-final match.
learner_examples: Notwithstanding this zealous kind of complaint, it would appear to me that they had great fun during the third day when after the English lesson they went to the swimming pool. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in the same way
dictionary_examples: Water these plants twice a week and likewise the ones in the bedroom.
Watch what she does and then do likewise.
learner_examples: And likewise, common sense tells us it doesn't matter that oranges from Spain contain 0.01% more vitamin C than those from Florida, as long as we eat them every once in a while. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: used when agreeing to do something or when allowing someone to do something
dictionary_examples: "Could you pick me up from the station?" "OK, what time?"
"I'll pay you back tomorrow." "Okay, no problem."
learner_examples: OK. See you for dinner! (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to check that someone understands something or that they agree to something
dictionary_examples: So I'll get the food and you can get the drink, OK?
I'll see you at six-thirty, okay?
learner_examples: Don't forget to wear [an] old shirt and jeans, okay? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used as a way of showing that you are going to take action, start speaking or start something new
dictionary_examples: OK then, if you're ready we'll start.
Okay, let's go.

pos_items.definition: not ill, damaged, upset, etc.
dictionary_examples: Are you OK? You look a bit pale.
How's Paola? Is she okay after her fall yesterday?
"Is everything OK with you?" "Yes, fine."
I'll just check that the car's okay - that was a bit of a bang!
learner_examples: Hi, Ramesh What are you doing? Are you OK? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: good or good enough
dictionary_examples: Is your food OK?
"Did you have a good meal last night?" "It was okay, though I've had better."
Her voice is OK, but it's nothing special.
learner_examples: I hope the new trousers you bought are OK. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: allowed or acceptable
dictionary_examples: Is it OK if I bring a friend to the party?
Is it okay to smoke in here?
If it's okay by/with you, I'll leave the shopping till tomorrow.
learner_examples: Dear Ally, It's okay that you couldn't come. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a satisfactory way
dictionary_examples: Everything was going OK until the printer stopped working.
Did you sleep okay?
I just phoned to make sure that you got there okay.
learner_examples: Finally the day finished OK. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: in a way that relates to music
dictionary_examples: It's a school for musically gifted children.
Musically speaking, this band has a lot of talent.
learner_examples: Not that I was musically gifted or wanted to become a pianist, it was just the fact that I loved music that led my step there. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: as you would expect
dictionary_examples: Naturally, he was very disappointed.
learner_examples: Naturally we had to take his word for it. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in a normal way
dictionary_examples: Relax and try to behave naturally.
learner_examples: As a result they can't behave naturally at all and become sick. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: happening or existing as part of nature and not made or done by people
dictionary_examples: A healthy body will be able to fight off the illness naturally without the use of medicine.
He has naturally blonde hair.
learner_examples: Sometimes people say women are naturally stronger tha[n] men. (Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; French)

pos_items.definition: having been born with a characteristic
dictionary_examples: naturally aggressive/funny/slim
learner_examples: Clarisse McClellan is a spontane[o]us and naturally curious teenager who even enjoys simple things. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is connected to medicine or to someone's health
dictionary_examples: The doctor declared her medically fit.
learner_examples: This does seem wise, as there is no 'medically proven' diet or nutrition program[me] that might help everyone to achieve [a] state of health that they would be completely happy about. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: mostly or to a large degree
dictionary_examples: The waitresses are mainly French.
They argued that the tax will mainly benefit the rich.
learner_examples: I often wear jeans, mainly blue jeans. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: almost completely
dictionary_examples: a largely male company
Their complaints have been largely ignored.
Until recently, the civil war had been largely unreported in the press.
learner_examples: What I'm trying to say is that images, film-frames, videos and sound clips would be largely accepted by the young people because we're moving into a new high-technology age. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used in negatives to mean 'in every case' or 'therefore'
dictionary_examples: That's not necessarily true.
The fact that something is cheap doesn't necessarily mean it's of low quality.
You may love someone without necessarily wanting to marry them.
learner_examples: The most important point in a job interview is to give a good impression, which does not necessarily mean how you look. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: as stated or allowed by the law
dictionary_examples: Children under sixteen are not legally allowed to buy cigarettes.
learner_examples: He already had a driving licence, so by that time he could legally drive his own Ferrari. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you mean exactly what you are saying and nothing more
dictionary_examples: I wasn't complaining, I merely said that I was tired.
I didn't say that you had to go - I merely suggested that you might like to go.
learner_examples: Of course this is merely a suggestion, and if you have got anything else in mind please don't hesitate to let me know. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something is not large, important, or effective when compared to something else
dictionary_examples: The medicine doesn't make you better, it merely stops the pain.
learner_examples: The modern way of travelling conducted by agencies [...] does not broaden the mind generally. It merely relieves the mind from the oppressions of a regular schedule at work and at home by producing a different environment. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: with a bad effect
dictionary_examples: They were very negatively affected by the changes.
learner_examples: Despite the huge facilities, technology has affected our lives negatively. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: well
dictionary_examples: That table would fit nicely in the bedroom.
His business is doing very nicely.
learner_examples: It is a pleasant, easy book with useful, active vocabulary and short, nicely constructed sentences. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a pleasant way
dictionary_examples: She's always very nicely dressed.
If you ask your dad nicely, he might drive you there.
learner_examples: All the rooms are big, clean and nicely decorated. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you mean exactly what you are saying and nothing more
dictionary_examples: I wasn't complaining, I merely said that I was tired.
I didn't say that you had to go - I merely suggested that you might like to go.
learner_examples: Of course this is merely a suggestion, and if you have got anything else in mind please don't hesitate to let me know. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something is not large, important, or effective when compared to something else
dictionary_examples: The medicine doesn't make you better, it merely stops the pain.
learner_examples: The modern way of travelling conducted by agencies [...] does not broaden the mind generally. It merely relieves the mind from the oppressions of a regular schedule at work and at home by producing a different environment. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to a degree that is average but not very great
dictionary_examples: There's very little moderately priced housing in this area.
The company remains moderately profitable, but it is not making as much money as it should.
learner_examples: Very often a moderately well-off person would take his chance and try to change his life, hopefully for [the] better. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a kind way
dictionary_examples: Stella has very kindly offered to help out with the food for the party.
learner_examples: He answers my simple questions kindly. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: to not like something that someone says or does
dictionary_examples: He doesn't take kindly to criticism.
learner_examples: His wife didn't take kindly to his lateness and immediately snarled at him as though [she was] a tigress snapping her claws in a cat-fight. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in a jealous way
dictionary_examples: She eyed Gwen's engagement ring jealously.

pos_items.definition: in a worried and anxious way
dictionary_examples: to giggle/laugh nervously
learner_examples: As always the girls sat down in the fifth row and waited nervously for the event to begin. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: well
dictionary_examples: That table would fit nicely in the bedroom.
His business is doing very nicely.
learner_examples: It is a pleasant, easy book with useful, active vocabulary and short, nicely constructed sentences. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a pleasant way
dictionary_examples: She's always very nicely dressed.
If you ask your dad nicely, he might drive you there.
learner_examples: All the rooms are big, clean and nicely decorated. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: without hiding any of your thoughts or feelings
dictionary_examples: They were openly dismissive of my suggestions.
He talks quite openly about his feelings.
We discussed our reservations about the contract quite openly.
learner_examples: I do hope that you are willing to cooperate, though I cannot say it openly. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: as you would expect
dictionary_examples: Naturally, he was very disappointed.
learner_examples: Naturally we had to take his word for it. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in a normal way
dictionary_examples: Relax and try to behave naturally.
learner_examples: As a result they can't behave naturally at all and become sick. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: happening or existing as part of nature and not made or done by people
dictionary_examples: A healthy body will be able to fight off the illness naturally without the use of medicine.
He has naturally blonde hair.
learner_examples: Sometimes people say women are naturally stronger tha[n] men. (Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; French)

pos_items.definition: having been born with a characteristic
dictionary_examples: naturally aggressive/funny/slim
learner_examples: Clarisse McClellan is a spontane[o]us and naturally curious teenager who even enjoys simple things. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: on or onto a surface
dictionary_examples: Ouch, you're standing on my foot!
I dropped my pen on the floor.
Look at all the books on your desk!
We put all of our medicine on a high shelf.
Your suitcase is on top of the wardrobe.
learner_examples: I can read the book, listen to music, watch TV or just sit on my sofa and drink a hot [cup of] tea. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show the day or date when something happens
dictionary_examples: Many shops don't open on Sundays.
What are you doing on Friday?
My birthday's on the 30th of May.
learner_examples: I go to college on Monday and Wednesday. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: covering, touching, attached to or hanging from something
dictionary_examples: You've got blood on your shirt.
Which finger do you wear your ring on?
We could hang this picture on the wall next to the door.
Dogs should be kept on their leads at all times.
learner_examples: I like my bedroom, because there are [a] lot of windows, two armchair[s], a lamp next to the bed, a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a place when giving directions
dictionary_examples: Our house is the first on the left after the post office.
Take the first turning on the right.
learner_examples: My house is the first one on the left. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used for showing some methods of travelling
dictionary_examples: I love travelling on trains.
She'll be arriving on the five-thirty bus.
We went to France on the ferry.
learner_examples: I will travel on a train and then I will take [a] taxi to your home. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: in a particular place
dictionary_examples: the diagram on page 22
They lived on a farm.
learner_examples: I live on a farm in the Emmental. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: used to show the way in which something is recorded or broadcast
dictionary_examples: What's on television tonight?
When's the film coming out on DVD?
learner_examples: At the party, we watched films on television. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show what money or time is used for
dictionary_examples: She refuses to spend more than £20 on a pair of shoes.
I've wasted too much time on this already.
learner_examples: I love it and I spend all my time on it. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: walking
dictionary_examples: Are you going by bicycle or on foot?
learner_examples: It isn't far away from the main building [-] it's about 15 minutes on foot. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: available at a reduced price
dictionary_examples: I love that dress but I'm waiting until it's on sale before I buy it.
learner_examples: I bought a nice t-shirt and a pair of shorts. I bought them because they're comfortable and cheap: they were on sale. I spent 15€. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: available to buy in a shop, on the Internet, etc.
dictionary_examples: The video and book are now on sale.
learner_examples: I went window shopping with my friends yesterday and I saw this beautiful skirt on sale. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay)

pos_items.definition: about
dictionary_examples: a book on plants
Her thesis is on Italian women's literature.
learner_examples: The other one is a book on dogs and cats. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: next to or along the side of a place or area
dictionary_examples: Cambridge is on the River Cam.
Our house was on Sturton Street.
Strasbourg is on the border of France and Germany.
learner_examples: Dan, We are going to the cinema that is on Arocena street. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: using something
dictionary_examples: I do all my household accounts on computer.
Chris is on drums and Mike's on bass guitar.
I'm on the phone.
learner_examples: I was in the pizza shop to order some food for my family and I was on the phone. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: on a boat, train, aircraft, etc.
dictionary_examples: There were 230 people on board the plane.
learner_examples: I also love travelling by plane because you can have a snack on board. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If something is on fire, it is burning when it should not be.
dictionary_examples: If your home was on fire and you could save only one thing, what would it be?
learner_examples: A lot of bu[i]ldings were on fire. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: intentionally
dictionary_examples: I didn't do it on purpose, it was an accident.
learner_examples: I didn't do it on purpose; it was dark and I just walked into it. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: not early or late
dictionary_examples: I got to school on time.
learner_examples: So, I will not be on time for my English class tomorrow. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: If something is on display, it is there for people to look at.
dictionary_examples: Many old aircraft are on display at the museum at the moment.
learner_examples: There were some new musical instruments on display. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: generally
dictionary_examples: We've had a few problems, but on the whole we're very happy.
learner_examples: On the whole I don't like watching television. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: alone
dictionary_examples: I like living on my own.
learner_examples: On Wedn[e]sday morning I went on my own to see [the]Vatican. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech)

pos_items.definition: without any help
dictionary_examples: I did my buttons up all on my own, Mummy.
learner_examples: Maybe I can do the missing work on my own. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to show what happens as a result of touching or hitting against something
dictionary_examples: You'll cut yourself on that knife if you're not careful.
I hit my head on the shelf as I was standing up.
learner_examples: Suddenly I hit my head on the bed as the man was talking. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show something which is used as food or fuel
dictionary_examples: What do frogs live on?
Does this radio run on batteries?
learner_examples: All new cars run on unleaded fuel w[h]ich is a benefit to the environment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: He doesn't eat any dairy products on account of the diet he is following.
learner_examples: On account of its location, it is always busy. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.sense_title: on behalf of sb or on sb's behalf
pos_items.definition: If you do something on behalf of someone, you do it for them or instead of them.
dictionary_examples: On behalf of the entire company, I would like to thank you for all your work.
Unfortunately, George cannot be with us today so I am pleased to accept this award on his behalf.
learner_examples: I am writing on behalf of our college English club members to welcome you [to] our city. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to give your opinion after you have considered all the facts about something
dictionary_examples: On balance, I'd prefer to come straight home.
learner_examples: On balance, no matter how important or useful computers may be, they will never replace the pleasure of re-reading familiar pages of your favourite books. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: only if
dictionary_examples: I'll come with you on condition that we're back before midnight.
learner_examples: I would like to do this on condition that you will not mention my name [on] the website. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If someone such as a doctor or a soldier is on duty, they are working.
dictionary_examples: What time are you on duty tomorrow?
learner_examples: I was on duty in front of the major's house with another soldier. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to something else that is bad
dictionary_examples: On top of all this bad luck, he lost his mobile phone.
And then, on top of everything else, her car was stolen!
learner_examples: On top of everything, the weather was bad and the se[a] was so cold that I couldn't swim. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.sense_title: on the one hand ... on the other hand
pos_items.definition: used when you are comparing two different ideas or opinions
dictionary_examples: On the one hand, computer games develop many skills, but on the other, they mean kids don't get enough exercise.
learner_examples: On the one hand, I know from my experience that it's much easier in life if you know more about everything, but on the other hand, I'd say that if someone [had given] me a chance (when I was kid) to study what I enjoy[ed], probably I'd have more possibility to develop my skills. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: available
dictionary_examples: We were amazed at the range of products on offer.
You should find out about the services on offer.
learner_examples: The swimming pool is also on offer [to] tourists. Another advantage of the hotel is that it is not far from the cent[re]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be a member of a group or organization
dictionary_examples: She's on the playgroup committee.
How many people are on your staff?
She's a researcher on a women's magazine.
learner_examples: As a student on the committee w[h]ich organises this, I have to say that there have been some problems with the experience, and also that some changes should be made in order to make a better programme. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: having something as a reason
dictionary_examples: Marks are awarded on the basis of progress and performance.
learner_examples: On the basis of the points mentioned above, it is a foregone conclusion that young people do not face any severe problems. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be quick to understand and react to things
dictionary_examples: She's over ninety, but she's still on the ball.
learner_examples: When you're at Sants station, you'll need to be on the ball to find the tube. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: on television or radio
dictionary_examples: The radio station is on air from 6.00 a.m.
learner_examples: It is on air at 8.30 p.m. every Thursday and Saturday. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: because of a particular reason
dictionary_examples: You cannot discriminate on the grounds of religion.
I refused on the grounds that it was too risky.
learner_examples: I am convinced that it is better than Southside College on the grounds that a great mass of students are satisfied. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If a plan or activity is on hold, it will not be done until a later time.
dictionary_examples: The project is on hold until we get more money.
learner_examples: What's more, it might, intentional[l]y or not, raise awareness on issues that might have been put on hold by authorities, such as the legalization of soft drugs. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: waiting to speak to someone on the telephone
dictionary_examples: His secretary put me on hold.
learner_examples: The day after, I called your office and after being put on hold, the person answering the phone was unwilling to come up with a proper reply. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: likely to happen soon
dictionary_examples: Economic recovery is on the horizon.
learner_examples: Often this is justified as [a] result of society being collective[ly] afraid that a shortage of fuel is on the horizon. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If something is on the increase, it is happening more often.
dictionary_examples: Violent crime is on the increase.
learner_examples: [The] number of motorists is on the increase everywhere in the world. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Czech)

pos_items.definition: If something is on loan, someone is borrowing it.
dictionary_examples: Both paintings are on loan from the city museum.
learner_examples: For example, you can always take out on loan any video you like from our cent[re]. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If a film or television programme is made on location, it is made at a place suitable to the story.
dictionary_examples: The movie was shot on location in Kenya.
learner_examples: We can't help mentioning the nice shots on location. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: driving or travelling, usually over a long distance
dictionary_examples: We'd been on the road for 48 hours.
learner_examples: I have experienced sitting behind a steering wheel on the road for many years. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: making progress and likely to succeed
dictionary_examples: A fighter from Edinburgh is on track to become world heavyweight boxing champion.
We've got a lot of work to do but we're on the right track.
learner_examples: The sales teams are well on track and bringing [in] new customers every day. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: being shown to the public
dictionary_examples: Her designs are currently on show at the Museum of Modern Art.
learner_examples: One of the facilit[ies] that really make[s] a difference is the Art Gallery, with its great exhibition on show, as well as the Art Library. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: inside a factory, office building, etc.
dictionary_examples: There are two restaurants on site.
They provide on-site childcare facilities for employees.
learner_examples: A small period of training on site is required a few days before the beginning of the job itself and how many interesting people you will meet! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the verge of sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to happen or do something very soon
dictionary_examples: The company is on the verge of financial disaster.
learner_examples: I was on the verge of depression, when I decided to take the control of my own life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to have something with you
dictionary_examples: Do you have your driving licence on you?

pos_items.sense_title: on no account; not on any account
pos_items.definition: not for any reason or in any situation
dictionary_examples: On no account must these records be changed.
learner_examples: Mary did not want Martin to leave on any account, let alone move to a foreign country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the brink of sth
pos_items.definition: to be in a situation where something bad is going to happen very soon
dictionary_examples: The two countries are on the brink of war.
learner_examples: By the end of the 21st century, Earth was on the brink of destruction. The atmosphere was polluted, the seas were poisoned, the animals were just a distant memory. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be likely to happen
dictionary_examples: Do you think marriage is on the cards?

pos_items.definition: to be extremely happy and excited
dictionary_examples: After I heard I'd got the job, I was on cloud nine!
learner_examples: But now, after the promise in which both said "yes", she was on cloud nine. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: at that exact time
dictionary_examples: We have to leave at 7.30 on the dot.
learner_examples: He gave him an address and told him to be there at six on the dot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: I only drink alcohol on occasion.
learner_examples: As I am writing this I am begin[n]ing to conclude that there are very few disadvantages of banning private cars, only that for individuals it is far easier and [more] conven[i]ent to use a private car and not rely on our public transport, which can be on occasions very unreliable. (International English Language Testing System; C2; English)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the verge of sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to happen or to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: a company on the verge of financial disaster
learner_examples: I was on the verge of depression, when I decided to take control of my own life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If two people are on the same wavelength, they have the same way of thinking and it is easy for them to understand each other.
dictionary_examples: We chatted occasionally, but I never really felt we were on the same wavelength.
learner_examples: We were on the same wavelength and we therefore started our own research. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If someone's job, reputation, life, etc. is on the line, they may lose it.
dictionary_examples: If we don't win the contract, all our jobs are on the line.
learner_examples: The person who hopes to achieve success shouldn't be afraid of taking risks and sometimes putting his or her career on the line for the sake of gaining much bigger benefits. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to be nervous or worried
dictionary_examples: Sorry for shouting - I'm a bit on edge today.
learner_examples: I was consequently on edge all the time and was not able to have fun as much as the others did. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are describing how a situation seems on the surface
dictionary_examples: On the face of it, it seems like a bargain, but I bet there are hidden costs.
learner_examples: On the face of it, both sides have valid arguments, and it's a difficult balancing act to manage. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: If someone is in form or on form, they are feeling or performing well, and if they are off form they are not feeling or performing well.
dictionary_examples: Harry was on good form last night.

pos_items.definition: to be ready to deal with something difficult that might happen
dictionary_examples: Companies were warned to be on their guard for suspicious packages.
learner_examples: However, we should be on guard, so as not to let the things escape our control. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: near to someone or something, and ready to help or be used when necessary
dictionary_examples: Extra supplies will be on hand, should they be needed.
learner_examples: From their point of view, they can always have you on hand whenever they need help, which is the most important part in their formative years. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: suddenly and without thinking first
dictionary_examples: I tend to act on impulse.
learner_examples: I'm seeing Milly as a capricious girl who, like most teenagers, enjoy[s] buying, although I think that she buys on impulse. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: on the part of sb; on sb's part
pos_items.definition: done or experienced by someone
dictionary_examples: This is a major sacrifice on the part of the unions.
The accident was caused by carelessness on the instructor's part.
learner_examples: It seems that international sports competitions have always tended to attract a great amount of interest on the part of the media and have consistently been popular with sports fans the world over. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: If you refuse to do something on principle, you refuse to do it because you think it is morally wrong.
dictionary_examples: She doesn't wear fur on principle.
learner_examples: They granted themselves a little celebration: it was time to keep the promise made four years before; so they bought some bottles of wine and got drunk (the[y] who, on principle, never drank alcohol). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to your main job
dictionary_examples: She does a bit of bar work on the side.
learner_examples: At work, they gave her the worst jobs to do. She knew she didn't have much choice but she still tried to find something else on the side. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: I accepted the job on the spot.
learner_examples: And when it was Meredith's turn to tell her about her impending wedding, she felt she was going to have a heart attack on the spot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: on the spur of the moment
pos_items.definition: If you do something on the spur of the moment, you do it suddenly, without planning it.
dictionary_examples: On the spur of the moment we decided to go to London for the day.
learner_examples: In reality, many people buy things on the spur of the moment only to discover later that they, in fact, do not [meet] their expect[at]ions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: at the start of a new and important time or development
dictionary_examples: We're on the threshold of a new era in European relations.
learner_examples: On the threshold of the third millen[n]ium, there is no stopping progress. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If you have something on, you are wearing it.
dictionary_examples: She's got a black coat on.
Why don't you put your new dress on?
learner_examples: And I want you to put on some baggy clothes, so that you'll feel comfortable while working. (Key English Test; A2; Rajasthani)

pos_items.definition: into a bus, train, plane, etc. or onto a horse
dictionary_examples: The train suddenly started moving as I was stepping on.
Her horse began to move as soon as she was on.

pos_items.definition: happening or planned
dictionary_examples: I'm busy tomorrow, but I've got nothing on the day after.
I've got a lot on at the moment.
Do you know what's on at the cinema?
Is the party still on for tomorrow?

pos_items.definition: performing
dictionary_examples: Hurry up with the make-up - I'm on in ten minutes.
The audience cheered as the band came on.
learner_examples: My faith in youth started to fade but then a boy named Josh came on. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in a way which results in forward movement
dictionary_examples: You cycle on and I'll meet you there.
Move on, please, and let the ambulance through.
learner_examples: I had just got [o]n the subway when it stopped and didn't move on. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: working or being used
dictionary_examples: The heating has been on all day.
learner_examples: For example, the staff shouldn't leave the lights [on] and the heating's on when they don't need to use it. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: on or onto a surface
dictionary_examples: Ouch, you're standing on my foot!
I dropped my pen on the floor.
Look at all the books on your desk!
We put all of our medicine on a high shelf.
Your suitcase is on top of the wardrobe.
learner_examples: I can read the book, listen to music, watch TV or just sit on my sofa and drink a hot [cup of] tea. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show the day or date when something happens
dictionary_examples: Many shops don't open on Sundays.
What are you doing on Friday?
My birthday's on the 30th of May.
learner_examples: I go to college on Monday and Wednesday. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: covering, touching, attached to or hanging from something
dictionary_examples: You've got blood on your shirt.
Which finger do you wear your ring on?
We could hang this picture on the wall next to the door.
Dogs should be kept on their leads at all times.
learner_examples: I like my bedroom, because there are [a] lot of windows, two armchair[s], a lamp next to the bed, a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a place when giving directions
dictionary_examples: Our house is the first on the left after the post office.
Take the first turning on the right.
learner_examples: My house is the first one on the left. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used for showing some methods of travelling
dictionary_examples: I love travelling on trains.
She'll be arriving on the five-thirty bus.
We went to France on the ferry.
learner_examples: I will travel on a train and then I will take [a] taxi to your home. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: in a particular place
dictionary_examples: the diagram on page 22
They lived on a farm.
learner_examples: I live on a farm in the Emmental. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: used to show the way in which something is recorded or broadcast
dictionary_examples: What's on television tonight?
When's the film coming out on DVD?
learner_examples: At the party, we watched films on television. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show what money or time is used for
dictionary_examples: She refuses to spend more than £20 on a pair of shoes.
I've wasted too much time on this already.
learner_examples: I love it and I spend all my time on it. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: walking
dictionary_examples: Are you going by bicycle or on foot?
learner_examples: It isn't far away from the main building [-] it's about 15 minutes on foot. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: available at a reduced price
dictionary_examples: I love that dress but I'm waiting until it's on sale before I buy it.
learner_examples: I bought a nice t-shirt and a pair of shorts. I bought them because they're comfortable and cheap: they were on sale. I spent 15€. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: available to buy in a shop, on the Internet, etc.
dictionary_examples: The video and book are now on sale.
learner_examples: I went window shopping with my friends yesterday and I saw this beautiful skirt on sale. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay)

pos_items.definition: about
dictionary_examples: a book on plants
Her thesis is on Italian women's literature.
learner_examples: The other one is a book on dogs and cats. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: next to or along the side of a place or area
dictionary_examples: Cambridge is on the River Cam.
Our house was on Sturton Street.
Strasbourg is on the border of France and Germany.
learner_examples: Dan, We are going to the cinema that is on Arocena street. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: using something
dictionary_examples: I do all my household accounts on computer.
Chris is on drums and Mike's on bass guitar.
I'm on the phone.
learner_examples: I was in the pizza shop to order some food for my family and I was on the phone. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: on a boat, train, aircraft, etc.
dictionary_examples: There were 230 people on board the plane.
learner_examples: I also love travelling by plane because you can have a snack on board. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If something is on fire, it is burning when it should not be.
dictionary_examples: If your home was on fire and you could save only one thing, what would it be?
learner_examples: A lot of bu[i]ldings were on fire. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: intentionally
dictionary_examples: I didn't do it on purpose, it was an accident.
learner_examples: I didn't do it on purpose; it was dark and I just walked into it. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: not early or late
dictionary_examples: I got to school on time.
learner_examples: So, I will not be on time for my English class tomorrow. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: If something is on display, it is there for people to look at.
dictionary_examples: Many old aircraft are on display at the museum at the moment.
learner_examples: There were some new musical instruments on display. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: generally
dictionary_examples: We've had a few problems, but on the whole we're very happy.
learner_examples: On the whole I don't like watching television. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: alone
dictionary_examples: I like living on my own.
learner_examples: On Wedn[e]sday morning I went on my own to see [the]Vatican. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech)

pos_items.definition: without any help
dictionary_examples: I did my buttons up all on my own, Mummy.
learner_examples: Maybe I can do the missing work on my own. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to show what happens as a result of touching or hitting against something
dictionary_examples: You'll cut yourself on that knife if you're not careful.
I hit my head on the shelf as I was standing up.
learner_examples: Suddenly I hit my head on the bed as the man was talking. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show something which is used as food or fuel
dictionary_examples: What do frogs live on?
Does this radio run on batteries?
learner_examples: All new cars run on unleaded fuel w[h]ich is a benefit to the environment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: He doesn't eat any dairy products on account of the diet he is following.
learner_examples: On account of its location, it is always busy. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.sense_title: on behalf of sb or on sb's behalf
pos_items.definition: If you do something on behalf of someone, you do it for them or instead of them.
dictionary_examples: On behalf of the entire company, I would like to thank you for all your work.
Unfortunately, George cannot be with us today so I am pleased to accept this award on his behalf.
learner_examples: I am writing on behalf of our college English club members to welcome you [to] our city. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to give your opinion after you have considered all the facts about something
dictionary_examples: On balance, I'd prefer to come straight home.
learner_examples: On balance, no matter how important or useful computers may be, they will never replace the pleasure of re-reading familiar pages of your favourite books. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: only if
dictionary_examples: I'll come with you on condition that we're back before midnight.
learner_examples: I would like to do this on condition that you will not mention my name [on] the website. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If someone such as a doctor or a soldier is on duty, they are working.
dictionary_examples: What time are you on duty tomorrow?
learner_examples: I was on duty in front of the major's house with another soldier. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to something else that is bad
dictionary_examples: On top of all this bad luck, he lost his mobile phone.
And then, on top of everything else, her car was stolen!
learner_examples: On top of everything, the weather was bad and the se[a] was so cold that I couldn't swim. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.sense_title: on the one hand ... on the other hand
pos_items.definition: used when you are comparing two different ideas or opinions
dictionary_examples: On the one hand, computer games develop many skills, but on the other, they mean kids don't get enough exercise.
learner_examples: On the one hand, I know from my experience that it's much easier in life if you know more about everything, but on the other hand, I'd say that if someone [had given] me a chance (when I was kid) to study what I enjoy[ed], probably I'd have more possibility to develop my skills. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: available
dictionary_examples: We were amazed at the range of products on offer.
You should find out about the services on offer.
learner_examples: The swimming pool is also on offer [to] tourists. Another advantage of the hotel is that it is not far from the cent[re]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be a member of a group or organization
dictionary_examples: She's on the playgroup committee.
How many people are on your staff?
She's a researcher on a women's magazine.
learner_examples: As a student on the committee w[h]ich organises this, I have to say that there have been some problems with the experience, and also that some changes should be made in order to make a better programme. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: having something as a reason
dictionary_examples: Marks are awarded on the basis of progress and performance.
learner_examples: On the basis of the points mentioned above, it is a foregone conclusion that young people do not face any severe problems. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be quick to understand and react to things
dictionary_examples: She's over ninety, but she's still on the ball.
learner_examples: When you're at Sants station, you'll need to be on the ball to find the tube. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: on television or radio
dictionary_examples: The radio station is on air from 6.00 a.m.
learner_examples: It is on air at 8.30 p.m. every Thursday and Saturday. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: because of a particular reason
dictionary_examples: You cannot discriminate on the grounds of religion.
I refused on the grounds that it was too risky.
learner_examples: I am convinced that it is better than Southside College on the grounds that a great mass of students are satisfied. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If a plan or activity is on hold, it will not be done until a later time.
dictionary_examples: The project is on hold until we get more money.
learner_examples: What's more, it might, intentional[l]y or not, raise awareness on issues that might have been put on hold by authorities, such as the legalization of soft drugs. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: waiting to speak to someone on the telephone
dictionary_examples: His secretary put me on hold.
learner_examples: The day after, I called your office and after being put on hold, the person answering the phone was unwilling to come up with a proper reply. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: likely to happen soon
dictionary_examples: Economic recovery is on the horizon.
learner_examples: Often this is justified as [a] result of society being collective[ly] afraid that a shortage of fuel is on the horizon. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If something is on the increase, it is happening more often.
dictionary_examples: Violent crime is on the increase.
learner_examples: [The] number of motorists is on the increase everywhere in the world. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Czech)

pos_items.definition: If something is on loan, someone is borrowing it.
dictionary_examples: Both paintings are on loan from the city museum.
learner_examples: For example, you can always take out on loan any video you like from our cent[re]. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian)

dictionary_examples: She does a bit of bar work on the side.
learner_examples: At work, they gave her the worst jobs to do. She knew she didn't have much choice but she still tried to find something else on the side. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: I accepted the job on the spot.
learner_examples: And when it was Meredith's turn to tell her about her impending wedding, she felt she was going to have a heart attack on the spot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: on the spur of the moment
pos_items.definition: If you do something on the spur of the moment, you do it suddenly, without planning it.
dictionary_examples: On the spur of the moment we decided to go to London for the day.
learner_examples: In reality, many people buy things on the spur of the moment only to discover later that they, in fact, do not [meet] their expect[at]ions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: at the start of a new and important time or development
dictionary_examples: We're on the threshold of a new era in European relations.
learner_examples: On the threshold of the third millen[n]ium, there is no stopping progress. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If you have something on, you are wearing it.
dictionary_examples: She's got a black coat on.
Why don't you put your new dress on?
learner_examples: And I want you to put on some baggy clothes, so that you'll feel comfortable while working. (Key English Test; A2; Rajasthani)

pos_items.definition: into a bus, train, plane, etc. or onto a horse
dictionary_examples: The train suddenly started moving as I was stepping on.
Her horse began to move as soon as she was on.

pos_items.definition: happening or planned
dictionary_examples: I'm busy tomorrow, but I've got nothing on the day after.
I've got a lot on at the moment.
Do you know what's on at the cinema?
Is the party still on for tomorrow?

pos_items.definition: performing
dictionary_examples: Hurry up with the make-up - I'm on in ten minutes.
The audience cheered as the band came on.
learner_examples: My faith in youth started to fade but then a boy named Josh came on. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in a way which results in forward movement
dictionary_examples: You cycle on and I'll meet you there.
Move on, please, and let the ambulance through.
learner_examples: I had just got [o]n the subway when it stopped and didn't move on. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: working or being used
dictionary_examples: The heating has been on all day.
learner_examples: For example, the staff shouldn't leave the lights [on] and the heating's on when they don't need to use it. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: something that you say in order to disagree, give a negative answer, or say that something is not true
dictionary_examples: "You told me." "No, I didn't!"
"Can I have another chocolate?" "No, you've had enough."
"Do you like him?" "No."
"Did you get some bread?" "No, sorry, I forgot."
"Have you got any homework tonight?" "No."
learner_examples: I was in the office last week, but she said: "No!" (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: something that you say to agree with something that is negative
dictionary_examples: "He's not very bright, is he?" "No, I'm afraid not."

pos_items.definition: used to refuse an offer politely
dictionary_examples: "Would you like a drink?' 'No thanks, I've just had one."

pos_items.definition: something that you say when you are shocked and upset
dictionary_examples: Oh no! It's gone all over the carpet!
learner_examples: Oh no! (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: not any
dictionary_examples: The work should be done no later than Friday.
There were no more than fifteen people at the concert.
learner_examples: In no more than ten lines, my mother explained that she was moving to Brazilia, the capital of our country, and that she would take me and my brother with her. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not any
dictionary_examples: There's no butter left.
There are no pockets in these trousers.
That's my kind of holiday - no telephone, no computer and no worries.
There's no chance of us getting there by eight.
learner_examples: Dear Ally, that's no problem about the party. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used in signs and on notices to show that something is not allowed
dictionary_examples: No smoking/fishing

pos_items.definition: something that you say to mean you can or will do what someone has asked you to do
dictionary_examples: "Can you get me to the airport by 11.30?" - "No problem."
learner_examples: Dear Jo, No problem. I can help you. (Key English Test; A2; German)

pos_items.definition: something that you say when someone has thanked you for something
dictionary_examples: "Thanks for taking me home." - "No problem."
learner_examples: It's ok, no problem. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to tell someone that something is impossible
dictionary_examples: I'm sorry but there's no way we can help you.
No way will she agree to you leaving early.
learner_examples: Don't worry, there is no way I'm going to miss it! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: it is not surprising
dictionary_examples: No wonder the children are excited - this is the first time they've been abroad.
"If brutal killers like these two are at work, it is no wonder that so many people have fled," he said.
learner_examples: No wonder that people are more tired and are not interested in reading books as much as in the past. (First Certificate in English; B2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: If there is no need to do something or no need for something, it is not necessary or it is wrong.
dictionary_examples: There's no need to go to the shops - there's plenty of food in the fridge.
I understand why she was angry but there was no need for that kind of language.
There's no need to shout, for goodness' sake! Just calm down.
learner_examples: He told me that I could trust him with the ticket and that there was no need for me to take it home. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.sense_title: be no good or be not any/much good
pos_items.definition: to not be useful, helpful or valuable
dictionary_examples: Boots are no good if they aren't waterproof.
Food aid isn't much good until the fighting stops.
learner_examples: When [it] is raining, you get wet and that's no good to anyone. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something does not exist
dictionary_examples: There's no such thing as ghosts!
learner_examples: But when I asked for these, I was told that no such thing existed and so the advertisement was once again proved wrong. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something cannot be changed
dictionary_examples: I never manage to lose any weight, no matter how hard I try.
learner_examples: No matter where you are [or] what you do, appar[e]ntly you need electricity. (First Certificate in English; B2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is very likely
dictionary_examples: No doubt she'll spend the money on new clothes.
learner_examples: No doubt I will find the skills acquired [on] the course, especially speaking skills, most useful in my future contacts with clients from English-speaking countries. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: none at all
dictionary_examples: There's no evidence whatsoever that she was involved.
learner_examples: Moreover, the hotel we were finally dumped in was situated miles from Edinburgh city centre and there was no entertainment whatsoever arranged for the evening, even though all the travellers were more or less stuck there. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used when you want to emphasize that an act or achievement is very difficult
dictionary_examples: Learning to ski at 60 is no mean feat!
learner_examples: There was an interesting discussion about whether it was harder or easier for them to enter the world of cinema, given their famous names. Both said that it was no mean feat because people were more demanding as [to] their abilities. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: possibly
dictionary_examples: Maybe we're too early.
Maybe they'll come tomorrow.
Maybe you were right after all.
It could take a month, or maybe more, to complete.
"Are you coming to Kelly's party?" "Maybe."
learner_examples: Maybe I forgot it [in] your room. (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to politely suggest something
dictionary_examples: Maybe Ted would like to go.
Maybe we should start again.
learner_examples: Maybe we could visit that park you told me about or play at your house. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: I've just been on a trip to France.

learner_examples: I've just had my birthday. It was [on] Friday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: now or very soon
dictionary_examples: I'm just coming!
The doctor will be with you in just a minute/moment/second.

pos_items.definition: only; simply
dictionary_examples: "Would you like another drink?" "OK, just one more."
It was just a joke.
The film is not just about love.
Just because you're older than me doesn't mean you can tell me what to do.
learner_examples: It was just a dream... (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: almost not
dictionary_examples: This dress only just fits!
We arrived at the airport just in time to catch the plane.
learner_examples: The airplane will arrive at midday, just in time for lunch. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: exactly or equally
dictionary_examples: This carpet would be just right for the dining room.
The twins look just like each other.
Things turned out just as I expected.
You've got just as many toys as your brother.
I can't help you just now.
Just then, the lights went out.
learner_examples: After the play, which turned out to be just as bad as I thought, I wanted to relax in the Theatre Restaurant, but it was closed, and for no reason! (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize something you say
dictionary_examples: It's just dreadful what happened to her.
I just can't bear it!
learner_examples: That is my best place - it is just wonderful. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: more or less; almost
dictionary_examples: "Can you see the stage?" "Yes, just about."
I've just about finished painting the living room.
learner_examples: I was just about 2 months [older]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.sense_title: be just about to do sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: I was just about to phone you.
learner_examples: I was so amazed that I didn't realize I was just about to fall into the lake. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: equally bad/good/tall/clever, etc.
dictionary_examples: He's just as talented as his brother.
learner_examples: Everywhere he went was just as good as he expected. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: a little before/over/under, etc. something else
dictionary_examples: She left just before Michael.
It costs just under £10.
learner_examples: Last autumn I bought a new flat in Siedke which I moved into just before New Year's Eve. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that it is lucky that something happened
dictionary_examples: It's just as well we brought an umbrella.
learner_examples: It is just as well that my friends had cars to give me a lift to the school. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at the same time as
dictionary_examples: She woke up just as we got there.
learner_examples: Just as I was turning on the radio somebody knocked at the door. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.sense_title: I/you/we, etc. will just have to do sth

pos_items.definition: despite that
dictionary_examples: I knew a lot about the subject already, but her talk was interesting nevertheless.
learner_examples: Both the options you gave seem very interesting. Nevertheless, I get the impression that working with animals is much more fun, don't you think? (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in general rather than in particular, or including all the people or things in a particular group or situation
dictionary_examples: The overall situation is good, despite a few minor problems.
Overall, it has been a good year.
The overall winner, after ten games, will receive $50,000.
learner_examples: Overall these two restaurants are worth [going] to for nice meals. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: not inside a building
dictionary_examples: It's cold outside!
Go and play outside for a while.
Shall we eat outside as the weather is so nice?
learner_examples: You can sit on the chair outside and look [at the] bridge. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: not in a particular room or building but near it
dictionary_examples: I'll wait outside while you get changed.
She knocked on his bedroom door and left the tray outside.
learner_examples: We are going to go to Top Totty and [will] wait for you outside. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese)

pos_items.definition: not in a particular room, building or place, but near it
dictionary_examples: She waited outside his room for nearly two hours.

learner_examples: I'll meet you outside the art class. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: not in a building
dictionary_examples: an outside light
learner_examples: I was going to say to him to turn on the outside light, but seeing his face, I changed my mind. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: coming from another place or organization

pos_items.definition: the left side of your body, or the direction towards this side

pos_items.definition: almost or approximately

pos_items.definition: not as much

learner_examples: My books cost less than the regular price. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: more than anything or anyone else

pos_items.definition: mostly or usually

pos_items.definition: almost all

pos_items.definition: more than anyone or anything else
