pos_items.definition: having no money, no luck and no opportunities
dictionary_examples: Nobody loves you when you're down and out.
learner_examples: The neglect of social security as a vital point in state policies leaves homeless people down and out, with little chance for improving their bleak prospects. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: the ins and outs of sth
pos_items.definition: the details of a particular subject
dictionary_examples: the ins and outs of the legal system
learner_examples: I knew all the ins and outs of every story but I couldn't stay one single day in bed without reading it. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: a very short time ago
dictionary_examples: I've just been on a trip to France.
We've only just begun.
learner_examples: I've just had my birthday. It was [on] Friday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: now or very soon
dictionary_examples: I'm just coming!
The doctor will be with you in just a minute/moment/second.

pos_items.definition: only; simply
dictionary_examples: "Would you like another drink?" "OK, just one more."
It was just a joke.
The film is not just about love.
Just because you're older than me doesn't mean you can tell me what to do.
learner_examples: It was just a dream... (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: almost not
dictionary_examples: This dress only just fits!
We arrived at the airport just in time to catch the plane.
learner_examples: The airplane will arrive at midday, just in time for lunch. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: exactly or equally
dictionary_examples: This carpet would be just right for the dining room.
The twins look just like each other.
Things turned out just as I expected.
You've got just as many toys as your brother.
I can't help you just now.
Just then, the lights went out.
learner_examples: After the play, which turned out to be just as bad as I thought, I wanted to relax in the Theatre Restaurant, but it was closed, and for no reason! (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize something you say
dictionary_examples: It's just dreadful what happened to her.
I just can't bear it!
learner_examples: That is my best place - it is just wonderful. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: more or less; almost
dictionary_examples: "Can you see the stage?" "Yes, just about."
I've just about finished painting the living room.
learner_examples: I was just about 2 months [older]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.sense_title: be just about to do sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: I was just about to phone you.
learner_examples: I was so amazed that I didn't realize I was just about to fall into the lake. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: equally bad/good/tall/clever, etc.
dictionary_examples: He's just as talented as his brother.
learner_examples: Everywhere he went was just as good as he expected. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: a little before/over/under, etc. something else
dictionary_examples: She left just before Michael.
It costs just under £10.
learner_examples: Last autumn I bought a new flat in Siedke which I moved into just before New Year's Eve. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that it is lucky that something happened
dictionary_examples: It's just as well we brought an umbrella.
learner_examples: It is just as well that my friends had cars to give me a lift to the school. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at the same time as
dictionary_examples: She woke up just as we got there.
learner_examples: Just as I was turning on the radio somebody knocked at the door. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.sense_title: I/you/we, etc. will just have to do sth
pos_items.definition: used to say that there is nothing else someone can do
dictionary_examples: You'll just have to wait.
learner_examples: We will just have to wait and see..... (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: fair or morally right
dictionary_examples: a just society
learner_examples: He is really involved in what he is doing and does not fear [facing] the difficulties if it is to defend a just cause. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: a very short time ago
dictionary_examples: I've just been on a trip to France.
We've only just begun.
learner_examples: I've just had my birthday. It was [on] Friday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: now or very soon
dictionary_examples: I'm just coming!
The doctor will be with you in just a minute/moment/second.

pos_items.definition: only; simply
dictionary_examples: "Would you like another drink?" "OK, just one more."
It was just a joke.
The film is not just about love.
Just because you're older than me doesn't mean you can tell me what to do.
learner_examples: It was just a dream... (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: almost not
dictionary_examples: This dress only just fits!
We arrived at the airport just in time to catch the plane.
learner_examples: The airplane will arrive at midday, just in time for lunch. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: exactly or equally
dictionary_examples: This carpet would be just right for the dining room.
The twins look just like each other.
Things turned out just as I expected.
You've got just as many toys as your brother.
I can't help you just now.
Just then, the lights went out.
learner_examples: After the play, which turned out to be just as bad as I thought, I wanted to relax in the Theatre Restaurant, but it was closed, and for no reason! (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize something you say
dictionary_examples: It's just dreadful what happened to her.
I just can't bear it!
learner_examples: That is my best place - it is just wonderful. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: more or less; almost
dictionary_examples: "Can you see the stage?" "Yes, just about."
I've just about finished painting the living room.
learner_examples: I was just about 2 months [older]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.sense_title: be just about to do sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: I was just about to phone you.
learner_examples: I was so amazed that I didn't realize I was just about to fall into the lake. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: equally bad/good/tall/clever, etc.
dictionary_examples: He's just as talented as his brother.
learner_examples: Everywhere he went was just as good as he expected. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: a little before/over/under, etc. something else
dictionary_examples: She left just before Michael.
It costs just under £10.
learner_examples: Last autumn I bought a new flat in Siedke which I moved into just before New Year's Eve. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that it is lucky that something happened
dictionary_examples: It's just as well we brought an umbrella.
learner_examples: It is just as well that my friends had cars to give me a lift to the school. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at the same time as
dictionary_examples: She woke up just as we got there.
learner_examples: Just as I was turning on the radio somebody knocked at the door. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.sense_title: I/you/we, etc. will just have to do sth
pos_items.definition: used to say that there is nothing else someone can do
dictionary_examples: You'll just have to wait.
learner_examples: We will just have to wait and see..... (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: fair or morally right
dictionary_examples: a just society
learner_examples: He is really involved in what he is doing and does not fear [facing] the difficulties if it is to defend a just cause. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: the week/year/Monday, etc. before the present one
dictionary_examples: I went to Barcelona last month.
Where were you last Thursday?
learner_examples: Last month I [went] to college every day. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish)

pos_items.definition: the evening or night that has just passed
dictionary_examples: I didn't sleep well last night.
Did you go out last night?
learner_examples: I think I left my coat in your house last night. (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: the most recent
dictionary_examples: What was the last film you saw?
It's rained for the last three days.
learner_examples: Thank you for your last letter. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: The last book, house, job, etc. is the one before the present one.
dictionary_examples: My last house was half this size.
I liked his last book but I'm not so keen on this latest one.
learner_examples: I like it because my last watch was broken. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: happening or coming at the end
dictionary_examples: It's the last room on the left.
That's the last programme of the series.
I was the last one to arrive.
"How did she get on in her race?" "She was last."
learner_examples: I live op[p]osite the last bus-stop. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: only remaining
dictionary_examples: Who wants the last piece of cake?
learner_examples: The cam[e]ras watch everybody in the house 24 hours [a day]. Every Friday, the public decide[s] who [should leave]. The last person wins this show. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: the least expected or wanted person or thing
dictionary_examples: Three extra people to feed - that's the last thing I need!
The last thing I wanted was to make you unhappy.
Matthew is the last person I'd expect to be interested in dance.
He's the last person I'd trust with my keys.
learner_examples: I thought it would be the last thing I wanted, but it wasn't. I've really enjoyed this opportunity. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: something that you do because everything else has failed
dictionary_examples: Soldiers were given the authority to shoot, but only as a last resort.
learner_examples: But forcing the child to believe in the way we would like it to believe should be used only as a last resort, after discussion and persuading, not before. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about the most recent time you did something
dictionary_examples: When did you last see her?
I think it was July when I last spoke to him.
learner_examples: Write back soon and let me know what you [have been] up to since I heard from you last. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: after everything or everyone else
dictionary_examples: I wasn't expecting to win the race but I didn't think I'd come last!
We've still got to check the figures but we'll do that last.
learner_examples: When I reached the other end of the pool, my heart suddenly stopped and I just couldn't move my legs to continue swimming. So, I arrived last. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: something that you say to introduce the last person or thing on a list
dictionary_examples: This is Jeremy, this is Cath and, last but not least, this is Eva.
learner_examples: And, last but not least, some complaints were made [about] the entertainment the café provides. (First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: finally
dictionary_examples: At last, I've found a pair of jeans that actually fit.
learner_examples: At last, all of us agreed on "Cinema Farhang". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: a person or thing that does something after all the others
dictionary_examples: We were the last to get there.
learner_examples: After a short time, the last of Mrs. O'Connell's guests arrived. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: the only part of something that remains
dictionary_examples: We've just finished the last of the apples.
She was among the last of the truly great entertainers.
learner_examples: They felt the joy their predecessors must have felt after years of struggle, after risking their lives, after accepting in resignation to be the last of a lineage that had lasted for centuries. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the day, week, year, etc. before the one that has just finished
dictionary_examples: I only had my hair cut the week before last.
learner_examples: But the year before last I went with my parents on holiday and we had a lot of fun. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.sense_title: the last sb heard/saw of sb ()
pos_items.definition: the last time someone heard anything about a person or the last time they saw them
dictionary_examples: I had a letter from Bristol, and that was the last I heard of her.
I told them exactly what I thought, and that was the last I saw of them.
learner_examples: That was the last I heard of her for a long time. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to continue to happen, exist, or be useful
dictionary_examples: How long will the meeting last?
We don't get much sun - enjoy it while it lasts!
Most sessions last about an hour.
The batteries only last about five hours.
learner_examples: We saw a new film, "Signs", that I liked very much, even though I found it very long: it lasted about 3 hours! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to be enough for a period of time
dictionary_examples: I've only got £30 to last me till the end of the month.
We've got enough food to last another week.
learner_examples: Until now half of the Filipinos in the Philippines who [devote] themselves to farming are still on [a] hand to mouth existence, having just enough food to last until the next harvest. (International English Language Testing System; B2; Tagalog)

pos_items.definition: making a lot of noise
dictionary_examples: a loud explosion/noise/voice
I heard a loud bang and then saw black smoke.
learner_examples: We were dancing then [the] police arrived, because of [the] loud music. (Key English Test; A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: loudly
dictionary_examples: Could you speak a little louder, please?
learner_examples: I cried louder. (First Certificate in English; B2; Norwegian)

pos_items.definition: If you say or read something out loud, you say or read it so that other people can hear you.
dictionary_examples: I had to read the essay out loud in front of the whole school.
learner_examples: She wouldn't accept it so I read [it] out loud for her to hear: "Director, Jason Meyer, and producer, Sami Woods, are receiving...". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a lucky way
dictionary_examples: Luckily, I had some money with me.
learner_examples: Luckily, the weather was nice. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in the time between two things happening, or while something else is happening
dictionary_examples: Carl's starting college in September. Meanwhile, he's travelling around Europe.
The mother is ill. The child, meanwhile, is living with his grandparents.
learner_examples: Meanwhile, if you agree, I can do some English exercises to cover the class that I'm going to miss. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the week/year/Monday, etc. that follows the present one
dictionary_examples: I'll call you next week.
I'm planning to visit California next year.
Are you doing anything next Wednesday?
learner_examples: See you next week. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: The next time, event, person, or thing is the one nearest to now or the one that follows the present one.
dictionary_examples: What time's the next train to London?
We're going to be very busy for the next few months.
learner_examples: My next free day is Saturday 20th and we can meet [at] my place. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: The next place is the one nearest to the present one.
dictionary_examples: She only lives in the next village.
Turn left at the next roundabout.
learner_examples: [At the] first roundabout turn right, and then [at the] next roundabout turn right again. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about part of a story that happens in a sudden and surprising way
dictionary_examples: A car came speeding round the corner, and the next thing I knew I was lying on the ground.
learner_examples: And the next thing I knew was that I was playing cards with 3 men. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: the thing that is best, if you cannot have or do the thing you really want
dictionary_examples: Coaching football is the next best thing to playing.
learner_examples: For many working people, there is hardly time to cook and prepare your dinner, so the next best thing is to rush into a Macdonalds' or Burger King. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Yapese)

pos_items.definition: immediately after
dictionary_examples: You'll never guess what happened next.
Where shall we go next?
First, fry the garlic. Next, add the ginger.
learner_examples: Next, turn left and you will be in front of my house. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: The time when you next do something is the first time you do it again.
dictionary_examples: Could you get some coffee when you next go to the supermarket?
learner_examples: I will talk to you about it much more when I next see you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech)

pos_items.definition: the person or thing that follows the present person or thing
dictionary_examples: Who's next to see the nurse?
Blue roses? Whatever next?

pos_items.definition: the weekend/week/Thursday, etc. that follows the next one
dictionary_examples: We're seeing Paul the Saturday after next.

pos_items.definition: in the next room, house, or building
dictionary_examples: That's the old man who lives next door to Paul.
learner_examples: Maria didn't understand, but then she realized that the man she was looking for lived next door. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to form a negative phrase after verbs like 'be', 'can', 'have', 'will', 'must', etc., usually used in the short form 'n't' in speech
dictionary_examples: He's not fat!
I won't tell her.
I can't go.
Don't you like her?
It isn't difficult.
I'm just not interested.
He's not bad-looking!
He's not as tall as his father.
learner_examples: It's not a problem for me. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: used to give the next word or group of words a negative meaning
dictionary_examples: I told you not to do that.
I like most vegetables but not cabbage.
"Come and play football, Dad." "Not now, Jamie."
It was Yuko who said that, not Richard.
learner_examples: You know I go to college [but] not every day. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Cantonese)

pos_items.definition: used after verbs like 'be afraid', 'hope', 'suspect', etc. in short, negative replies
dictionary_examples: "Is he coming with us?" "I hope not."
"Have you finished?" "I'm afraid not."

pos_items.definition: used to form questions when you think the answer will be 'yes', using the short form 'n't'
dictionary_examples: She's very pretty, isn't she?
You like cheese, don't you?
learner_examples: I know that you love horror movies, don't you? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to express the possibility that something might not happen
dictionary_examples: Are you going to reply or not?
I still don't know whether she's coming or not.
learner_examples: Are [you] busy or not that day? (Key English Test; A2; Singhalese)

pos_items.definition: used to say what the situation will be if something does not happen
dictionary_examples: I hope to see you there but, if not, I'll call you.
learner_examples: I'm going to paint my bedroom with the pink paint. Remember to put on your old cloth[e]s. If not, your clothes will become pinky and you can't use them anymore. (Key English Test; A2; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: used before adjectives and adverbs to mean 'not very'
dictionary_examples: "How was your exam?" "Not too bad, I suppose."
I didn't play too well today.
He wasn't too happy when I told him about the mistake.
learner_examples: How are you? [I'm] not too bad. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say 'no' or 'not' strongly
dictionary_examples: "Was he a nuisance?" "No, not at all."
I'm not at all happy about it.
learner_examples: I sen[s]ed that invisible hand was touching my shoulder, but it didn't scare me, not at all. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used as a polite reply after someone has thanked you
dictionary_examples: "Thanks for helping." "Not at all."
learner_examples: "Hello Cédric, it's Christophe from Alcatel. I hope I['m not] disturb[ing] you?" "Not at all, I'm just on holiday". (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is true although it seems surprising
dictionary_examples: He even remembered my birthday, believe it or not.
learner_examples: First I visited the "Roman Bath'' which is more than 2000 years old and, believe it or not, it still works! (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to say that more than one thing is true
dictionary_examples: Not only was the hotel expensive, it was dirty too.
You have let down not only yourself, but the entire team.
learner_examples: In this show, not only can we see [the] latest fashions, sportswear, make-up and hairstyles, but we can [also] enter for free. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: satisfactory
dictionary_examples: That's not bad for such a small company.
learner_examples: The presents are not bad. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: to be much less good/bad/exciting, etc. than something else
dictionary_examples: Her new book's not half as good as the last one.
learner_examples: Probably they wouldn't be half as famous as they are without press photographers, journalist[s], etc. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the importance of something that you are adding to a list
dictionary_examples: The resort has great hotels and restaurants, not to mention some of the best skiing in the region.
learner_examples: It is crowded everywhere, the shop assist[a]nts are stressed, you get to wait for hours to pay for your goods, not to mention the time you must wait to get them wrapped. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: almost but not completely
dictionary_examples: I'm not quite sure that I understand this.
The colours almost match but not quite.
He didn't get quite enough votes to win.
learner_examples: The student cafe has a welcoming atmosphere and most people said it was nice to sit and to drink coffee [there]. [T]he only problem is that there are not quite enough tables and chairs for everyone at busy times. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the fact that something does not happen or is not true
dictionary_examples: "I never cry." "Not even when you hurt yourself really badly?"
Nobody spoke, not even the children.
learner_examples: We tried to fish, but didn't catch a thing, not even a shoe! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that there is nothing of what you are talking about
dictionary_examples: Not one person came to hear him talk.
"You haven't heard from Nick, have you?" "Not a word."
learner_examples: Nowadays, I can only see buildings and roads. Not one single tree to refresh yourself from the hot and tropical sun at midday. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used after an adverb in short, negative replies
dictionary_examples: "She's not exactly poor, is she?" "Certainly not."
"We won't need much money, will we?" "Hopefully not."
learner_examples: That's nice, but do you think that money is all that matters? Definitely not! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: especially
dictionary_examples: The whole trip was fascinating, not least because of the people I met.
learner_examples: We are all human beings but we are all different, not least because of a different cultural background. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: not at all
dictionary_examples: I don't mind staying at home, not in the least.
learner_examples: Educating two children was not so easy a task, not in the least! (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: at the present time, especially when compared to the past
dictionary_examples: Everything seems more expensive nowadays.
Who remembers those films nowadays?
Nowadays, I bake my own bread rather than buy it.
learner_examples: Well, nowadays I hardly ever watch television, as time is something that I really don't have enough [of]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not anywhere
dictionary_examples: The room was very crowded - there was nowhere to sit.
These young people have nowhere else to go.
Nowhere does the article mention the names of the people involved.
learner_examples: Then she left the airport, but she had nowhere to go without money and identity, so she called her family asking [for] some help. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: a long way from places where people live
dictionary_examples: His car broke down in the middle of nowhere.
learner_examples: You know I really don't want to [get] lost in the middle of nowhere. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If someone or something appears out of nowhere, it appears suddenly or unexpectedly.
dictionary_examples: The car came out of nowhere and we had to swerve to miss it.
learner_examples: I was lying all alone on the beach, then suddenly, out of nowhere, right behind me those strange creatures appeared. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: not close in distance, time, amount or quality
dictionary_examples: The house was nowhere near the sea.
It's nowhere near time for us to leave yet.
I'm nowhere near finishing the book - I'm only half-way through it.
He's nowhere near as tall as his sister.
learner_examples: Although people are well aware of the current situation in Switzerland, they prefer looking at other countries and comparing us to them (we are nowhere near as fat as them). (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: If something gets you nowhere, it does not help you to succeed.
dictionary_examples: Bad manners will get you nowhere.
learner_examples: As this is a loophole in [the] law system, it's creating a conflict between house-owners and squatters and getting them nowhere. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: not at work
dictionary_examples: I had six months off after my son was born.
I'm going to take/have some time off to work on my house.
She was off sick last week.
learner_examples: I will take a day off on Friday. (Key English Test; A2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing
dictionary_examples: Take your jacket off.
One of my buttons has come off.
She's had all her hair cut off.
I left the lid off.
learner_examples: I took off my ring. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: not operating or being used
dictionary_examples: Make sure the computers are all off before you go home.
learner_examples: I tr[i]ed to contact my neighbour, but his phone was off and nobody was at home. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Pashto)

pos_items.definition: away from a place or position
dictionary_examples: I'm just off to the shops.
Keep the dog on the lead or he'll just run off.
If we can get off early tomorrow morning we'll avoid most of the traffic.
I'm off now - see you tomorrow.
She's off to Canada next week.
learner_examples: They g[o]t into the car and drove off. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: If a price has a certain amount of money off, it costs that much less than the usual price.
dictionary_examples: You can get some money off if you pay cash.
There's 40% off this week on all winter coats.
There was $40 or $50 off most jackets in the shop.
learner_examples: He promised me 30% off the price, so I'm going to buy the TV and the CD player from him. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: far in distance or time
dictionary_examples: You can see the village off in the distance.
My holidays seem a long way off.
The exams are so far off that I'm not even thinking about them yet.
learner_examples: Allow me to start by saying that one day, which may l[ie] not so far off in the future, people will visit the buildings which were formerly known as "Educational Institutions" like we visit museums to gape at the sheer size of the Dinosaurs... (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: down or away from a place or position
dictionary_examples: All the leaves had dropped off the tree.
He fell off his bike.
learner_examples: I still remember the way your brother fell off the lad[d]er that day. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing
dictionary_examples: I can't get the lid off this jar.
Has anyone taken a book off my desk?
Could you cut me a small piece off that white cheese?
Take your feet off the seat.
learner_examples: Next month, I'm going to change my bedroom. I'll take the photographs off the wall. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: near to a building or place
dictionary_examples: an island off the coast of Spain
learner_examples: He spent all night off the coast, (unfinished) (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If someone such as a doctor or a soldier is off duty, they are not working.
dictionary_examples: What time are you off duty tomorrow?
learner_examples: Sometimes I come off duty at ten p.m. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If an area is off limits, you are not allowed to enter it.
dictionary_examples: Most of the palace is off limits to the public.
learner_examples: The only place that was off limits for us was on the other side of the mountain, because it was too dangerous. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If you say something off the record, you do not want the public to know about it.
dictionary_examples: Off the record, ministers are saying the president must resign.
learner_examples: Off the record, how come that your reporter can print such lies when knowing they are perhaps hurting certain people in this important matter? (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: in a place where few people go
dictionary_examples: I prefer to take my holiday somewhere off the beaten track.
learner_examples: Furthermore, in areas off the beaten track, there [are] not even police sometimes. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If food or drink is off, it is not now fresh and good to eat or drink.
dictionary_examples: This milk smells off.
learner_examples: Who knows if the food isn't off? (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: stopped or given up
dictionary_examples: The wedding's off - she's decided she's too young to settle down.
It's all off between Philippa and Mike.
The boat trip is off because of the weather.
learner_examples: On that day, she had written him a big long letter and told him that it was all off, for she didn't love him any longer. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not at work
dictionary_examples: I had six months off after my son was born.
I'm going to take/have some time off to work on my house.
She was off sick last week.
learner_examples: I will take a day off on Friday. (Key English Test; A2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing
dictionary_examples: Take your jacket off.
One of my buttons has come off.
She's had all her hair cut off.
I left the lid off.
learner_examples: I took off my ring. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: not operating or being used
dictionary_examples: Make sure the computers are all off before you go home.
learner_examples: I tr[i]ed to contact my neighbour, but his phone was off and nobody was at home. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Pashto)

pos_items.definition: away from a place or position
dictionary_examples: I'm just off to the shops.
Keep the dog on the lead or he'll just run off.
If we can get off early tomorrow morning we'll avoid most of the traffic.
I'm off now - see you tomorrow.
She's off to Canada next week.
learner_examples: They g[o]t into the car and drove off. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: If a price has a certain amount of money off, it costs that much less than the usual price.
dictionary_examples: You can get some money off if you pay cash.
There's 40% off this week on all winter coats.
There was $40 or $50 off most jackets in the shop.
learner_examples: He promised me 30% off the price, so I'm going to buy the TV and the CD player from him. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: far in distance or time
dictionary_examples: You can see the village off in the distance.
My holidays seem a long way off.
The exams are so far off that I'm not even thinking about them yet.
learner_examples: Allow me to start by saying that one day, which may l[ie] not so far off in the future, people will visit the buildings which were formerly known as "Educational Institutions" like we visit museums to gape at the sheer size of the Dinosaurs... (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: down or away from a place or position
dictionary_examples: All the leaves had dropped off the tree.
He fell off his bike.
learner_examples: I still remember the way your brother fell off the lad[d]er that day. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing
dictionary_examples: I can't get the lid off this jar.
Has anyone taken a book off my desk?
Could you cut me a small piece off that white cheese?
Take your feet off the seat.
learner_examples: Next month, I'm going to change my bedroom. I'll take the photographs off the wall. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

learner_examples: On that day, she had written him a big long letter and told him that it was all off, for she didn't love him any longer. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: one single time
dictionary_examples: I went sailing once, but I didn't like it.
I go swimming once a week.
We have lunch together once a month.
Once a year we all get together.
learner_examples: I can write to him once a week. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in the past, but not now
dictionary_examples: This house once belonged to my grandfather.
Computers are much cheaper nowadays than they once were.
learner_examples: I once went to England and I love the style of the clothes and how people dress there! (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: again
dictionary_examples: Once again I'm left with all the washing-up!
learner_examples: Once again I'm sorry. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: one more time
dictionary_examples: I'd like to visit the colleges once more before we leave.
learner_examples: On Friday I will see him once more. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: I knew at once that I'd like it here.
learner_examples: She called for an ambulance which came at once. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a story to mean a long time ago
dictionary_examples: Once upon a time there was a beautiful princess.
learner_examples: Once upon a time there was a very poor family. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: at the same time
dictionary_examples: They all started talking at once.
learner_examples: The study centre is really small and all the students talk at once. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to mean that something is happening that does not usually happen
dictionary_examples: For once, the bus came on time.
learner_examples: We would take lots of pictures, and play our own instruments, and if we get lucky enough, we would even touch the very stones and for once be embraced by magic itself. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: sometimes but not often
dictionary_examples: We do go to the beach once in a while.
learner_examples: She did not say very much except for "oh" and "yes, yes" every once in a while. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: suddenly
dictionary_examples: All at once he stood up and walked out of the room.
learner_examples: All at once, everything started to work again. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: completely and finally
dictionary_examples: Let's get to the bottom of this matter once and for all!
learner_examples: Now I was sure that my wife had left me once and for all. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: as soon as
dictionary_examples: Once I've found somewhere to live I'll send you my address.
Remember that you won't be able to cancel the contract once you've signed.
learner_examples: I'll write back soon once I know exactly when I can visit you. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: not more than a particular size or amount
dictionary_examples: She's only 13.
These shoes only cost £20.
He only passed one of his exams.
It's only four o'clock and it's already getting dark.
learner_examples: This is only ten minutes by car. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: not anyone or anything else
dictionary_examples: Only Sue and Mark came to the meeting.
This club is for members only.
Only food bought at the café may be eaten here.
learner_examples: Only Marco, Anna, Sue and Nick came. (Key English Test; A2; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: not in any other place
dictionary_examples: At present these televisions are only available in Japan.
These birds are only found in New Zealand.
learner_examples: I think animals, just as human beings, can only live in their natural habitat. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to mean that something happened very recently
dictionary_examples: I only arrived half an hour ago.
They only put the roof on last week.
People were leaving and I'd only just arrived.
We'd only just set off when the car broke down.
learner_examples: I am really sorry I didn't write back earlier but I have only just got back from holiday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is not important, or that you did not mean to upset someone
dictionary_examples: Don't worry - it's only a scratch.
I was only joking.
I was only trying to help.
learner_examples: It was only a dream! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when you want to say how doing something simple would make it possible to avoid something unpleasant
dictionary_examples: If only she'd listen to what he's saying, I'm sure they could work it out.
learner_examples: If only I had been more careful. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize what you are hoping or wishing for
dictionary_examples: I only hope you know what you're doing.
I only wish that they would keep in touch more regularly.
learner_examples: I only hope I can have the chance to see her too. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that more than one thing is true
dictionary_examples: Not only did he turn up late, he also forgot his books.
If this project fails it will affect not only our department, but also the whole organization.
learner_examples: Not only did she introduce me to her friends but she also introduced me to her brother. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: to not be perfect
dictionary_examples: Of course Tom makes mistakes - he's only human.
learner_examples: In theory, it is easy to say "We should learn from the mistakes of the past" but is it easy to do so in practice? Many people would say "No" to this question, as we are only human. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that there are limits to something
dictionary_examples: There's only so much help you can give someone.
learner_examples: The effects of a longer life span have many side ef[f]ects such as an increase in the world's population and, since there is only so much food, m[any] more people are st[ar]ving to death. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to mean that there are not any others
dictionary_examples: This is our only chance.
I was the only person on the train.
Is this really the only way to do it?
The only thing that matters is that the baby is healthy.
It was the only thing I could do under the circumstances.
Rita was the only person to complain.
learner_examples: I am the only French student in my class. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce a statement which explains why something you have just said cannot happen or is not completely true
dictionary_examples: I'd invite Frances to the party, only I don't want her husband to come.
I'd phone him myself, only I've got to go out.
This fabric is similar to wool, only cheaper.
learner_examples: He was always there for me when I needed him, only I needed him less and less. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used after an order or suggestion to show what the result will be if you do not follow that order or suggestion
dictionary_examples: I'd better write it down, otherwise I'll forget it.
You really must phone home. Otherwise, your parents will start to worry.
learner_examples: Oh! I'll have to buy a table for the computer. Otherwise, I'll have to use my computer on my bed. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: different to what has just been stated
dictionary_examples: I'll meet you there at 6 o'clock, unless I hear otherwise.
The police believe he is the thief, but all the evidence suggests otherwise.
Under the law, a person is presumed innocent until proved otherwise.
Marion Morrison, otherwise known as the film star John Wayne, was born in 1907.
I can't meet you on Tuesday - I'm otherwise engaged.
learner_examples: An important event in the history of Greece was the Civil War between the cities of Athens and Sparti around 400 B.C., otherwise known as [the] Pelopon[n]esian War. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: except for what has just been referred to
dictionary_examples: The bike needs a new saddle, but otherwise it's in good condition.
The poor sound quality ruined an otherwise splendid film.
learner_examples: This seemed the high point of an otherwise dull and disorganised event. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a period of time when someone goes away from home for a social activity
dictionary_examples: He's out nearly every night.
He's asked me out to the cinema next week.
learner_examples: After the film, we can have dinner out. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not in the place where you usually live or work, especially for a short time
dictionary_examples: I came round to see you this morning, but you were out.
Someone phoned for you while you were out.
learner_examples: Will you give [it] back to my father because I am out for a while. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container
dictionary_examples: Get out!
She opened the window and stuck her head out.
The bag burst and the apples fell out.
He opened the drawer and took out a pair of socks.
My secretary will see you out.
learner_examples: When I was on the plane, I decided to open my suitcase to take out my CD player because I was bored. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: able to be seen
dictionary_examples: The stars are out tonight.
The rain stopped and the sun came out.
The flowers are starting to come out.
learner_examples: In the beginning it was raining a little bit, but then the sun came out. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If a light or fire is out, it is no longer shining or burning.
dictionary_examples: When we got home, all the lights were out.
Is that fire completely out?
learner_examples: I looked out through the window to check if the lights were out in the windows of the block of flats next to ours. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: available to buy or see
dictionary_examples: Is the new Harry Potter book out yet?
The new Tarantino movie comes out in August.
learner_examples: It came out just yesterday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to the point where something is removed or disappears
dictionary_examples: The stain won't come out.
Cross out any words that are not on the list.
learner_examples: A friend of mine told me, when he was in Lampton, that you couldn't have special rates for students at Hotel Royal, so you should cross [that information] out of the guide. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: If you say or read something out loud, you say or read it so that other people can hear you.
dictionary_examples: I had to read the essay out loud in front of the whole school.
learner_examples: She wouldn't accept it so I read [it] out loud for her to hear: "Director, Jason Meyer, and producer, Sami Woods, are receiving...". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: a long distance away from land, a town or your own country
dictionary_examples: The fishing boats were out at sea for three days.
They live out in the countryside, miles from anywhere.
He lived out in Zambia for seven years.
learner_examples: Today I live out in the country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romansch)

pos_items.definition: not accurate
dictionary_examples: Your figures are out by £300.

pos_items.definition: having no money, no luck and no opportunities

pos_items.definition: If you say or read something out loud, you say or read it so that other people can hear you.
dictionary_examples: I had to read the essay out loud in front of the whole school.
learner_examples: She wouldn't accept it so I read [it] out loud for her to hear: "Director, Jason Meyer, and producer, Sami Woods, are receiving...". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: a long distance away from land, a town or your own country
dictionary_examples: The fishing boats were out at sea for three days.
They live out in the countryside, miles from anywhere.
He lived out in Zambia for seven years.
learner_examples: Today I live out in the country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romansch)

pos_items.definition: not accurate
dictionary_examples: Your figures are out by £300.

pos_items.definition: having no money, no luck and no opportunities
dictionary_examples: Nobody loves you when you're down and out.
learner_examples: The neglect of social security as a vital point in state policies leaves homeless people down and out, with little chance for improving their bleak prospects. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: the ins and outs of sth
pos_items.definition: the details of a particular subject
dictionary_examples: the ins and outs of the legal system
learner_examples: I knew all the ins and outs of every story but I couldn't stay one single day in bed without reading it. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a period of time when someone goes away from home for a social activity
dictionary_examples: He's out nearly every night.
He's asked me out to the cinema next week.
learner_examples: After the film, we can have dinner out. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not in the place where you usually live or work, especially for a short time
dictionary_examples: I came round to see you this morning, but you were out.
Someone phoned for you while you were out.
learner_examples: Will you give [it] back to my father because I am out for a while. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container
dictionary_examples: Get out!
She opened the window and stuck her head out.
The bag burst and the apples fell out.
He opened the drawer and took out a pair of socks.
My secretary will see you out.
learner_examples: When I was on the plane, I decided to open my suitcase to take out my CD player because I was bored. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: able to be seen
dictionary_examples: The stars are out tonight.
The rain stopped and the sun came out.
The flowers are starting to come out.
learner_examples: In the beginning it was raining a little bit, but then the sun came out. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If a light or fire is out, it is no longer shining or burning.
dictionary_examples: When we got home, all the lights were out.
Is that fire completely out?
learner_examples: I looked out through the window to check if the lights were out in the windows of the block of flats next to ours. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: available to buy or see
dictionary_examples: Is the new Harry Potter book out yet?
The new Tarantino movie comes out in August.
learner_examples: It came out just yesterday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to the point where something is removed or disappears
dictionary_examples: The stain won't come out.
Cross out any words that are not on the list.
learner_examples: A friend of mine told me, when he was in Lampton, that you couldn't have special rates for students at Hotel Royal, so you should cross [that information] out of the guide. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: If you say or read something out loud, you say or read it so that other people can hear you.
dictionary_examples: I had to read the essay out loud in front of the whole school.
learner_examples: She wouldn't accept it so I read [it] out loud for her to hear: "Director, Jason Meyer, and producer, Sami Woods, are receiving...". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: a long distance away from land, a town or your own country
dictionary_examples: The fishing boats were out at sea for three days.
They live out in the countryside, miles from anywhere.
He lived out in Zambia for seven years.
learner_examples: Today I live out in the country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romansch)

pos_items.definition: not accurate
dictionary_examples: Your figures are out by £300.

pos_items.definition: having no money, no luck and no opportunities
dictionary_examples: Nobody loves you when you're down and out.
learner_examples: The neglect of social security as a vital point in state policies leaves homeless people down and out, with little chance for improving their bleak prospects. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: the ins and outs of sth
pos_items.definition: the details of a particular subject
dictionary_examples: the ins and outs of the legal system
learner_examples: I knew all the ins and outs of every story but I couldn't stay one single day in bed without reading it. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: outside
dictionary_examples: If the weather's good, we'll eat outdoors.
learner_examples: My parents always tell me that I should spend more time outdoors. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: more than a particular amount, number, or age
dictionary_examples: Most of the bikes cost/are over £300.
Children over the age of 12 must have full-price tickets.
They are already $25 million over budget.
learner_examples: We have to dance in a school and over two hundred people [will watch] us. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: covering something or someone
dictionary_examples: Put a blanket over you to keep warm.
I put my hands over my eyes because I didn't want to see.
learner_examples: Wear an apron over your clothes. (Key English Test; A2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: above or higher than something
dictionary_examples: The sign over the door said "Exit".
A flock of geese flew over the trees.
She held the umbrella over both of us.
learner_examples: Besides that, you have voted for the construction of a new bridge over the main street. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: across from one side of something to the other, especially by going up and then down
dictionary_examples: She jumped over the gate.
The road goes over the mountains.
She is always chatting with her neighbour over the garden fence.
From the top of the tower you could see for miles over the city.
Tanks travel over the most difficult ground.
learner_examples: I most enjoyed [it] when we [were] cycling over the hills, because there weren't any people and it was peaceful and qui[et]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: everywhere in a particular place
dictionary_examples: Soon the news was all over town.
learner_examples: The people in the class are from all over the world. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: during a particular period of time
dictionary_examples: I was in Seattle over the summer.
We discussed the matter over lunch.
It's fascinating to watch how a baby changes and develops over time.
learner_examples: He apologised for the trouble and when he heard that they just wanted to stay over the weekend, he said they should go and buy the most important things and enjoy the weekend as the suitcase wo[uld]n't arrive until Monday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: on the other side of
dictionary_examples: There's a pub over the road we could go to.
The story continues over the page.
The station is over the bridge.

pos_items.definition: in control of or teaching someone or something
dictionary_examples: A good teacher has an easy authority over a class.
She's a sales manager but she has a regional sales director over her.
The victory over the French at Waterloo was Wellington's greatest triumph.
learner_examples: Fortunately, my parents do not wield authority over me and my siblings like dictators. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: using
dictionary_examples: They spoke over the phone.
We heard the news over the radio.
learner_examples: She laughed over the phone, and said "It's really like you". (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in this/that place
dictionary_examples: Put your bags down over there.
learner_examples: How is everything over there? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: connected with or about
dictionary_examples: It's stupid arguing over something so trivial.
learner_examples: The teams themselves suffered from these money problems: recently strikes broke out in basketball teams in the U.S when players began to argue over money. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: too extreme and not suitable
dictionary_examples: I thought her performance was way over the top.
learner_examples: In addition to that, many so-called "stars" have that certain over the top attitude, which would not be welcome in normal life. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: more than a particular amount or level
dictionary_examples: People who are 65 years old and over can get half-price tickets.
learner_examples: In my opinion, the minimum working age being 18 and over, I think the school leaving age should be limited to just 16. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Others)

pos_items.definition: from one side or place to another
dictionary_examples: She leaned over and kissed me.
Why don't you come over for dinner on Thursday?
I've got a friend over from Canada this week.
Now we're going over to Wembley for commentary on the Cup Final.
learner_examples: He came over to me and we talked a while. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: describes the way an object moves or is moved so that a different part of it is facing up
dictionary_examples: She turned another page over.
learner_examples: A big truck had turned over and blocked the road and there was no other way for us to go, so we had to wait. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: finished
dictionary_examples: I'll be glad when the competition is over.
I used to have a thriving business and a happy marriage, but that's all over now.
learner_examples: David smiled triumphantly and said, "It is all over!" (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: happening or done many times
dictionary_examples: I read the article over and over till it made sense.
learner_examples: I've been searching in newspapers over and over again and finally after a couple of days I found something. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: repeated from the beginning
dictionary_examples: We had to start all over again.
learner_examples: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to do something difficult or unpleasant as soon as you can so that you do not have to worry about it any more
dictionary_examples: I got all my apologies over and done with at the beginning of the meeting.
learner_examples: Not to mention that he knew that he had to get his degree over and done with before he started making serious decisions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: more than a particular amount, number, or age
dictionary_examples: Most of the bikes cost/are over £300.
Children over the age of 12 must have full-price tickets.
They are already $25 million over budget.
learner_examples: We have to dance in a school and over two hundred people [will watch] us. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

I put my hands over my eyes because I didn't want to see.
learner_examples: Wear an apron over your clothes. (Key English Test; A2; Hindi)

learner_examples: He came over to me and we talked a while. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

dictionary_examples: She turned another page over.
learner_examples: A big truck had turned over and blocked the road and there was no other way for us to go, so we had to wait. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)
