dictionary_examples: I'll be glad when the competition is over.
I used to have a thriving business and a happy marriage, but that's all over now.
learner_examples: David smiled triumphantly and said, "It is all over!" (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: happening or done many times
dictionary_examples: I read the article over and over till it made sense.
learner_examples: I've been searching in newspapers over and over again and finally after a couple of days I found something. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: repeated from the beginning
dictionary_examples: We had to start all over again.
learner_examples: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to do something difficult or unpleasant as soon as you can so that you do not have to worry about it any more
dictionary_examples: I got all my apologies over and done with at the beginning of the meeting.
learner_examples: Not to mention that he knew that he had to get his degree over and done with before he started making serious decisions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: the week/year/Monday, etc. before the present one
dictionary_examples: I went to Barcelona last month.
Where were you last Thursday?
learner_examples: Last month I [went] to college every day. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish)

pos_items.definition: the evening or night that has just passed
dictionary_examples: I didn't sleep well last night.
Did you go out last night?
learner_examples: I think I left my coat in your house last night. (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: the most recent
dictionary_examples: What was the last film you saw?
It's rained for the last three days.
learner_examples: Thank you for your last letter. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: The last book, house, job, etc. is the one before the present one.
dictionary_examples: My last house was half this size.
I liked his last book but I'm not so keen on this latest one.
learner_examples: I like it because my last watch was broken. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: happening or coming at the end
dictionary_examples: It's the last room on the left.
That's the last programme of the series.
I was the last one to arrive.
"How did she get on in her race?" "She was last."
learner_examples: I live op[p]osite the last bus-stop. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: only remaining
dictionary_examples: Who wants the last piece of cake?
learner_examples: The cam[e]ras watch everybody in the house 24 hours [a day]. Every Friday, the public decide[s] who [should leave]. The last person wins this show. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: the least expected or wanted person or thing
dictionary_examples: Three extra people to feed - that's the last thing I need!
The last thing I wanted was to make you unhappy.
Matthew is the last person I'd expect to be interested in dance.
He's the last person I'd trust with my keys.
learner_examples: I thought it would be the last thing I wanted, but it wasn't. I've really enjoyed this opportunity. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: something that you do because everything else has failed
dictionary_examples: Soldiers were given the authority to shoot, but only as a last resort.
learner_examples: But forcing the child to believe in the way we would like it to believe should be used only as a last resort, after discussion and persuading, not before. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about the most recent time you did something
dictionary_examples: When did you last see her?
I think it was July when I last spoke to him.
learner_examples: Write back soon and let me know what you [have been] up to since I heard from you last. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: after everything or everyone else
dictionary_examples: I wasn't expecting to win the race but I didn't think I'd come last!
We've still got to check the figures but we'll do that last.
learner_examples: When I reached the other end of the pool, my heart suddenly stopped and I just couldn't move my legs to continue swimming. So, I arrived last. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: something that you say to introduce the last person or thing on a list
dictionary_examples: This is Jeremy, this is Cath and, last but not least, this is Eva.
learner_examples: And, last but not least, some complaints were made [about] the entertainment the café provides. (First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: finally
dictionary_examples: At last, I've found a pair of jeans that actually fit.
learner_examples: At last, all of us agreed on "Cinema Farhang". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: a person or thing that does something after all the others
dictionary_examples: We were the last to get there.
learner_examples: After a short time, the last of Mrs. O'Connell's guests arrived. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: the only part of something that remains
dictionary_examples: We've just finished the last of the apples.
She was among the last of the truly great entertainers.
learner_examples: They felt the joy their predecessors must have felt after years of struggle, after risking their lives, after accepting in resignation to be the last of a lineage that had lasted for centuries. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the day, week, year, etc. before the one that has just finished
dictionary_examples: I only had my hair cut the week before last.
learner_examples: But the year before last I went with my parents on holiday and we had a lot of fun. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.sense_title: the last sb heard/saw of sb ()
pos_items.definition: the last time someone heard anything about a person or the last time they saw them
dictionary_examples: I had a letter from Bristol, and that was the last I heard of her.
I told them exactly what I thought, and that was the last I saw of them.
learner_examples: That was the last I heard of her for a long time. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to continue to happen, exist, or be useful
dictionary_examples: How long will the meeting last?
We don't get much sun - enjoy it while it lasts!
Most sessions last about an hour.
The batteries only last about five hours.
learner_examples: We saw a new film, "Signs", that I liked very much, even though I found it very long: it lasted about 3 hours! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to be enough for a period of time
dictionary_examples: I've only got £30 to last me till the end of the month.
We've got enough food to last another week.
learner_examples: Until now half of the Filipinos in the Philippines who [devote] themselves to farming are still on [a] hand to mouth existence, having just enough food to last until the next harvest. (International English Language Testing System; B2; Tagalog)

pos_items.definition: happening or arriving after the planned, expected, usual or necessary time
dictionary_examples: This train is always late.
You'll be late for your flight if you don't hurry up.
Sorry I'm late. I was held up in the traffic.
We always have a late breakfast on Sunday mornings.
learner_examples: I hope I am not late. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: happening or being near the end of a period of time
dictionary_examples: It was late at night.
Is that the time? I'd no idea it was so late.
It was late summer when it happened.
It was built in the late nineteenth century.
He's probably in his late twenties.
learner_examples: I don't like the time the class finish[es]. It's too late! (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: describes someone who has died, especially recently
dictionary_examples: She gave her late husband's clothes to charity.
learner_examples: It took me a while to find a person whom I regard as successful, the outcome is a friend of my late father. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: If you tell someone to do something by a particular time at the latest, you mean they must do it before that time.
dictionary_examples: She said to be there by 8 o'clock at the latest.

pos_items.definition: after the planned, expected, usual or necessary time
dictionary_examples: Kathryn's just phoned to say she's working late this evening.
The rains came late this year.
learner_examples: The party finished late. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: near the end of a period of time
dictionary_examples: We talked late into the night.
As late as the 1980s they were still using horses on this farm.
learner_examples: Firstly, he usually starts working at eight in the morning and he keeps on writing and phoning till late in the evening. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: existing or happening in all parts of a particular country
dictionary_examples: a nationwide network/chain of shops
a nationwide survey
learner_examples: The nationwide blackout was the first in the past decade. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in all parts of a country
dictionary_examples: Schools nationwide are experiencing a shortage of teachers.
learner_examples: On Thursday, Friday or Saturday you could visit the annual festival, which is well-known nationwide for the music, costumes and dance of the local people. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: close in distance
dictionary_examples: Is there a train station near here?
We were near the exit.
The hotel is near the airport.
Don't come too near me - you might catch my cold.
Which bus stop is nearest (to) your house?
I moved my chair nearer to the fire.
learner_examples: The park is near my house, about 10 minutes on foot. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: close in time
dictionary_examples: He arrived near the end of the lesson.
It was nearer four when we finally arrived.
We can decide which route to take nearer the time.

pos_items.definition: almost in a particular state or condition
dictionary_examples: The runners looked near exhaustion.
I was near (to) tears at one point during the film.
This is the nearest I've ever got to winning anything.
He came near to punching him.
learner_examples: It is strictly related to the fact that the old possess a vast amount of experience and are nearer to death. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: not close in distance, time, amount or quality
dictionary_examples: The house was nowhere near the sea.
It's nowhere near time for us to leave yet.
I'm nowhere near finishing the book - I'm only half-way through it.
He's nowhere near as tall as his sister.
learner_examples: Although people are well aware of the current situation in Switzerland, they prefer looking at other countries and comparing us to them (we are nowhere near as fat as them). (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: used in questions and negatives to mean 'close to being or doing something'
dictionary_examples: The house isn't anywhere near ready.
learner_examples: We could not have gone anywhere near 5000 miles because all our minibuses were broken down - we even stayed in one place for 8 days. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: close in distance
dictionary_examples: I was standing just near enough to hear what they were saying.
Don't come any nearer.
learner_examples: And they are getting nearer, I must run for my life. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: close in time
dictionary_examples: Her birthday was getting nearer and I still hadn't bought her a present.
As the date of his operation drew near, he became more and more anxious.
learner_examples: I would appreciate very much if you could reply as soon as possible, as the school holiday is drawing near. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: close in distance
dictionary_examples: Where's the nearest post office?
learner_examples: Dear Dan, My friends and I have decided to go to the nearest cinema, the one which is in The Mall, three blocks from here. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at a time that is not far away
dictionary_examples: Space travel may become very common in the near future.
learner_examples: I look forward to receiving your reply in the near future. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: similar in characteristics or quality
dictionary_examples: My pocket knife is the nearest thing to a weapon that I have.
I couldn't get any cream cheese so I bought the nearest equivalent that I could find.

pos_items.definition: used to say that a negative fact is also true of someone or something else
dictionary_examples: Jerry doesn't like it, and neither do I.
Her family wouldn't help her and neither would anyone else.
She's not very tall and neither is her husband.
learner_examples: Of course, she never thought those would be the lucky numbers and neither did her husband, so he forgot to ask her about the ticket later. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: not either of two people or things
dictionary_examples: Luckily, neither child was hurt in the accident.
Neither of us had ever been to London before.
They gave us two keys, but neither worked.
"Which one would you choose?" "Neither."
learner_examples: Three years ago, when I was in Japan, my parents were both working and neither of them were at home by the time I g[o]t back from school. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used when a negative fact is true of two people or things or when someone or something does not have either of two qualities
dictionary_examples: Neither he nor his mother would talk to the police.
Their performance was neither entertaining nor educational.
learner_examples: I was just having a bath when the lights went out. [...] No lights at all, neither the cooker nor the fridge were working in my flat, so what had happened? (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: not ever, not one time
dictionary_examples: We've never been to Australia.
I've never heard anything so ridiculous.
Let us never forget those who gave their lives for their country.
Wars never solve anything.
He threatened to shoot, but I never thought he would.
It's never too late to start eating a healthy diet.
learner_examples: I never have enough time [to do] it. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to tell someone not to worry about something because it is not important
dictionary_examples: "I'm afraid I've lost that wallet you gave me." "Well, never mind, I can easily buy you another one."
learner_examples: Never mind Ally, forget it, I know you['ve] been busy. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize something negative
dictionary_examples: I never knew you lived around here.
learner_examples: I never knew what happened after I left. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when a negative fact is true of two people or things or when someone or something does not have either of two qualities
dictionary_examples: Neither he nor his mother would talk to the police.
Their performance was neither entertaining nor educational.
learner_examples: I was just having a bath when the lights went out. [...] No lights at all, neither the cooker nor the fridge were working in my flat, so what had happened? (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that a negative fact is also true of someone else
dictionary_examples: "I don't like cats." "Nor do I."
I've never been to Iceland." "Nor have I."
I can't be at the meeting and nor can Andrew.
learner_examples: In fact when Mrs. McGillicuddy told the train assist[a]nt about that, he did not believe her. Nor did the Police, [to] whom Mrs. McGillicuddy wrote about what she had seen. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: at the present time
dictionary_examples: I'm used to it now.
She used to be a teacher, but now she works in publishing.
I thought you'd have finished by now.
You should have mentioned it before now.
That's all for now.
learner_examples: I am now vegetarian! (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: We're going home now.
Shall we eat now or later?
I don't want to wait until tomorrow, I want it now!
I can't do it right now.
learner_examples: Please, buy it right now. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to show the length of time that something has been happening, from the time it began until the present
dictionary_examples: I've lived in Cambridge for two years now.
She's been a vegetarian for ten years now.

pos_items.definition: If something happens now and then, it happens sometimes but not very often.
dictionary_examples: I love chocolate, but I only eat it now and then.
learner_examples: If you really love to have a snack now and then, try to eat fruit and vegetables, instead of sweets. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something will happen very soon
dictionary_examples: We're expecting our second child any day now.
learner_examples: The evil creatures who were bound to come out of the dark [w]ould see Carla any minute now. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: We still meet up every now and then.
learner_examples: Each day choose 10 new words and learn them by heart. In a week you will have learned 70 new words, and in a year 3640, a lot of words. Please, do not forget to repeat them every now and then. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: a very short time ago
dictionary_examples: When I came in just now, everyone was laughing.
Who was that woman who was speaking just now?
learner_examples: I [was] watch[ing] a badminton competition just now. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: as a result of a new situation
dictionary_examples: Now that I've got a car I can visit her more often.
You should help in the house more, now you're older.
She's enjoying the job now that she's got more responsibility.
learner_examples: Now I am in England for fu[r]ther studies, I would be very grateful to you if you will give me the oppo[r]tunity to join your club. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: many times or regularly
dictionary_examples: I often shop there.
How often do you wash your hair?
I don't often drink spirits.
I don't see him very often.
It's not often that you meet someone who you're instantly attracted to.
I don't see my parents as often as I'd like to.
learner_examples: We often go shopping or to pubs. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something often happens or is often true, it is normal for it to happen or it is usually true.
dictionary_examples: Brothers and sisters often argue.
Headaches are often caused by stress.
Christmas is often mild in Britain.
learner_examples: Very often, people link classical music to Austrian or German [composers], [such] as Mozart or Handel, but rarely to England and genius[es] [such] as Haydn and Purcell. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: He went into town every so often to buy supplies.
learner_examples: Elizabeth and others visited her every so often until [one] day she left them. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: on or onto a surface
dictionary_examples: Ouch, you're standing on my foot!
I dropped my pen on the floor.
Look at all the books on your desk!
We put all of our medicine on a high shelf.
Your suitcase is on top of the wardrobe.
learner_examples: I can read the book, listen to music, watch TV or just sit on my sofa and drink a hot [cup of] tea. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show the day or date when something happens
dictionary_examples: Many shops don't open on Sundays.
What are you doing on Friday?
My birthday's on the 30th of May.
learner_examples: I go to college on Monday and Wednesday. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: covering, touching, attached to or hanging from something
dictionary_examples: You've got blood on your shirt.
Which finger do you wear your ring on?
We could hang this picture on the wall next to the door.
Dogs should be kept on their leads at all times.
learner_examples: I like my bedroom, because there are [a] lot of windows, two armchair[s], a lamp next to the bed, a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a place when giving directions
dictionary_examples: Our house is the first on the left after the post office.
Take the first turning on the right.
learner_examples: My house is the first one on the left. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used for showing some methods of travelling
dictionary_examples: I love travelling on trains.
She'll be arriving on the five-thirty bus.
We went to France on the ferry.
learner_examples: I will travel on a train and then I will take [a] taxi to your home. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: in a particular place
dictionary_examples: the diagram on page 22
They lived on a farm.
learner_examples: I live on a farm in the Emmental. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: used to show the way in which something is recorded or broadcast
dictionary_examples: What's on television tonight?
When's the film coming out on DVD?
learner_examples: At the party, we watched films on television. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show what money or time is used for
dictionary_examples: She refuses to spend more than £20 on a pair of shoes.
I've wasted too much time on this already.
learner_examples: I love it and I spend all my time on it. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: walking
dictionary_examples: Are you going by bicycle or on foot?
learner_examples: It isn't far away from the main building [-] it's about 15 minutes on foot. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: available at a reduced price
dictionary_examples: I love that dress but I'm waiting until it's on sale before I buy it.
learner_examples: I bought a nice t-shirt and a pair of shorts. I bought them because they're comfortable and cheap: they were on sale. I spent 15€. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: available to buy in a shop, on the Internet, etc.
dictionary_examples: The video and book are now on sale.
learner_examples: I went window shopping with my friends yesterday and I saw this beautiful skirt on sale. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay)

pos_items.definition: about
dictionary_examples: a book on plants
Her thesis is on Italian women's literature.
learner_examples: The other one is a book on dogs and cats. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: next to or along the side of a place or area
dictionary_examples: Cambridge is on the River Cam.
Our house was on Sturton Street.
Strasbourg is on the border of France and Germany.
learner_examples: Dan, We are going to the cinema that is on Arocena street. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: using something
dictionary_examples: I do all my household accounts on computer.
Chris is on drums and Mike's on bass guitar.
I'm on the phone.
learner_examples: I was in the pizza shop to order some food for my family and I was on the phone. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: on a boat, train, aircraft, etc.
dictionary_examples: There were 230 people on board the plane.
learner_examples: I also love travelling by plane because you can have a snack on board. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If something is on fire, it is burning when it should not be.
dictionary_examples: If your home was on fire and you could save only one thing, what would it be?
learner_examples: A lot of bu[i]ldings were on fire. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: intentionally
dictionary_examples: I didn't do it on purpose, it was an accident.
learner_examples: I didn't do it on purpose; it was dark and I just walked into it. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: not early or late
dictionary_examples: I got to school on time.
learner_examples: So, I will not be on time for my English class tomorrow. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: If something is on display, it is there for people to look at.
dictionary_examples: Many old aircraft are on display at the museum at the moment.
learner_examples: There were some new musical instruments on display. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: generally
dictionary_examples: We've had a few problems, but on the whole we're very happy.
learner_examples: On the whole I don't like watching television. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: alone
dictionary_examples: I like living on my own.
learner_examples: On Wedn[e]sday morning I went on my own to see [the]Vatican. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech)

pos_items.definition: without any help
dictionary_examples: I did my buttons up all on my own, Mummy.
learner_examples: Maybe I can do the missing work on my own. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to show what happens as a result of touching or hitting against something
dictionary_examples: You'll cut yourself on that knife if you're not careful.
I hit my head on the shelf as I was standing up.
learner_examples: Suddenly I hit my head on the bed as the man was talking. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show something which is used as food or fuel
dictionary_examples: What do frogs live on?
Does this radio run on batteries?
learner_examples: All new cars run on unleaded fuel w[h]ich is a benefit to the environment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: He doesn't eat any dairy products on account of the diet he is following.
learner_examples: On account of its location, it is always busy. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.sense_title: on behalf of sb or on sb's behalf
pos_items.definition: If you do something on behalf of someone, you do it for them or instead of them.
dictionary_examples: On behalf of the entire company, I would like to thank you for all your work.
Unfortunately, George cannot be with us today so I am pleased to accept this award on his behalf.
learner_examples: I am writing on behalf of our college English club members to welcome you [to] our city. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to give your opinion after you have considered all the facts about something
dictionary_examples: On balance, I'd prefer to come straight home.
learner_examples: On balance, no matter how important or useful computers may be, they will never replace the pleasure of re-reading familiar pages of your favourite books. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: only if
dictionary_examples: I'll come with you on condition that we're back before midnight.
learner_examples: I would like to do this on condition that you will not mention my name [on] the website. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If someone such as a doctor or a soldier is on duty, they are working.
dictionary_examples: What time are you on duty tomorrow?
learner_examples: I was on duty in front of the major's house with another soldier. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to something else that is bad
dictionary_examples: On top of all this bad luck, he lost his mobile phone.
And then, on top of everything else, her car was stolen!
learner_examples: On top of everything, the weather was bad and the se[a] was so cold that I couldn't swim. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.sense_title: on the one hand ... on the other hand
pos_items.definition: used when you are comparing two different ideas or opinions
dictionary_examples: On the one hand, computer games develop many skills, but on the other, they mean kids don't get enough exercise.
learner_examples: On the one hand, I know from my experience that it's much easier in life if you know more about everything, but on the other hand, I'd say that if someone [had given] me a chance (when I was kid) to study what I enjoy[ed], probably I'd have more possibility to develop my skills. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: available
dictionary_examples: We were amazed at the range of products on offer.
You should find out about the services on offer.
learner_examples: The swimming pool is also on offer [to] tourists. Another advantage of the hotel is that it is not far from the cent[re]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be a member of a group or organization
dictionary_examples: She's on the playgroup committee.
How many people are on your staff?
She's a researcher on a women's magazine.
learner_examples: As a student on the committee w[h]ich organises this, I have to say that there have been some problems with the experience, and also that some changes should be made in order to make a better programme. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: having something as a reason
dictionary_examples: Marks are awarded on the basis of progress and performance.
learner_examples: On the basis of the points mentioned above, it is a foregone conclusion that young people do not face any severe problems. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be quick to understand and react to things
dictionary_examples: She's over ninety, but she's still on the ball.
learner_examples: When you're at Sants station, you'll need to be on the ball to find the tube. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: on television or radio
dictionary_examples: The radio station is on air from 6.00 a.m.
learner_examples: It is on air at 8.30 p.m. every Thursday and Saturday. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: because of a particular reason
dictionary_examples: You cannot discriminate on the grounds of religion.
I refused on the grounds that it was too risky.
learner_examples: I am convinced that it is better than Southside College on the grounds that a great mass of students are satisfied. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If a plan or activity is on hold, it will not be done until a later time.
dictionary_examples: The project is on hold until we get more money.
learner_examples: What's more, it might, intentional[l]y or not, raise awareness on issues that might have been put on hold by authorities, such as the legalization of soft drugs. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: waiting to speak to someone on the telephone
dictionary_examples: His secretary put me on hold.
learner_examples: The day after, I called your office and after being put on hold, the person answering the phone was unwilling to come up with a proper reply. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: likely to happen soon
dictionary_examples: Economic recovery is on the horizon.
learner_examples: Often this is justified as [a] result of society being collective[ly] afraid that a shortage of fuel is on the horizon. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If something is on the increase, it is happening more often.
dictionary_examples: Violent crime is on the increase.
learner_examples: [The] number of motorists is on the increase everywhere in the world. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Czech)

pos_items.definition: If something is on loan, someone is borrowing it.
dictionary_examples: Both paintings are on loan from the city museum.
learner_examples: For example, you can always take out on loan any video you like from our cent[re]. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If a film or television programme is made on location, it is made at a place suitable to the story.
dictionary_examples: The movie was shot on location in Kenya.
learner_examples: We can't help mentioning the nice shots on location. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: driving or travelling, usually over a long distance
dictionary_examples: We'd been on the road for 48 hours.
learner_examples: I have experienced sitting behind a steering wheel on the road for many years. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: making progress and likely to succeed
dictionary_examples: A fighter from Edinburgh is on track to become world heavyweight boxing champion.
We've got a lot of work to do but we're on the right track.
learner_examples: The sales teams are well on track and bringing [in] new customers every day. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: being shown to the public
dictionary_examples: Her designs are currently on show at the Museum of Modern Art.
learner_examples: One of the facilit[ies] that really make[s] a difference is the Art Gallery, with its great exhibition on show, as well as the Art Library. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: inside a factory, office building, etc.
dictionary_examples: There are two restaurants on site.
They provide on-site childcare facilities for employees.
learner_examples: A small period of training on site is required a few days before the beginning of the job itself and how many interesting people you will meet! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the verge of sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to happen or do something very soon
dictionary_examples: The company is on the verge of financial disaster.
learner_examples: I was on the verge of depression, when I decided to take the control of my own life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to have something with you
dictionary_examples: Do you have your driving licence on you?

pos_items.sense_title: on no account; not on any account
pos_items.definition: not for any reason or in any situation
dictionary_examples: On no account must these records be changed.
learner_examples: Mary did not want Martin to leave on any account, let alone move to a foreign country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the brink of sth
pos_items.definition: to be in a situation where something bad is going to happen very soon
dictionary_examples: The two countries are on the brink of war.
learner_examples: By the end of the 21st century, Earth was on the brink of destruction. The atmosphere was polluted, the seas were poisoned, the animals were just a distant memory. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be likely to happen
dictionary_examples: Do you think marriage is on the cards?

pos_items.definition: to be extremely happy and excited
dictionary_examples: After I heard I'd got the job, I was on cloud nine!
learner_examples: But now, after the promise in which both said "yes", she was on cloud nine. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: at that exact time
dictionary_examples: We have to leave at 7.30 on the dot.
learner_examples: He gave him an address and told him to be there at six on the dot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: I only drink alcohol on occasion.
learner_examples: As I am writing this I am begin[n]ing to conclude that there are very few disadvantages of banning private cars, only that for individuals it is far easier and [more] conven[i]ent to use a private car and not rely on our public transport, which can be on occasions very unreliable. (International English Language Testing System; C2; English)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the verge of sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to happen or to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: a company on the verge of financial disaster
learner_examples: I was on the verge of depression, when I decided to take control of my own life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If two people are on the same wavelength, they have the same way of thinking and it is easy for them to understand each other.
dictionary_examples: We chatted occasionally, but I never really felt we were on the same wavelength.
learner_examples: We were on the same wavelength and we therefore started our own research. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If someone's job, reputation, life, etc. is on the line, they may lose it.
dictionary_examples: If we don't win the contract, all our jobs are on the line.
learner_examples: The person who hopes to achieve success shouldn't be afraid of taking risks and sometimes putting his or her career on the line for the sake of gaining much bigger benefits. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to be nervous or worried
dictionary_examples: Sorry for shouting - I'm a bit on edge today.
learner_examples: I was consequently on edge all the time and was not able to have fun as much as the others did. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are describing how a situation seems on the surface
dictionary_examples: On the face of it, it seems like a bargain, but I bet there are hidden costs.
learner_examples: On the face of it, both sides have valid arguments, and it's a difficult balancing act to manage. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: If someone is in form or on form, they are feeling or performing well, and if they are off form they are not feeling or performing well.
dictionary_examples: Harry was on good form last night.

pos_items.definition: to be ready to deal with something difficult that might happen
dictionary_examples: Companies were warned to be on their guard for suspicious packages.
learner_examples: However, we should be on guard, so as not to let the things escape our control. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: near to someone or something, and ready to help or be used when necessary
dictionary_examples: Extra supplies will be on hand, should they be needed.
learner_examples: From their point of view, they can always have you on hand whenever they need help, which is the most important part in their formative years. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: suddenly and without thinking first
dictionary_examples: I tend to act on impulse.
learner_examples: I'm seeing Milly as a capricious girl who, like most teenagers, enjoy[s] buying, although I think that she buys on impulse. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: on the part of sb; on sb's part
pos_items.definition: done or experienced by someone
dictionary_examples: This is a major sacrifice on the part of the unions.
The accident was caused by carelessness on the instructor's part.
learner_examples: It seems that international sports competitions have always tended to attract a great amount of interest on the part of the media and have consistently been popular with sports fans the world over. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: If you refuse to do something on principle, you refuse to do it because you think it is morally wrong.
dictionary_examples: She doesn't wear fur on principle.
learner_examples: They granted themselves a little celebration: it was time to keep the promise made four years before; so they bought some bottles of wine and got drunk (the[y] who, on principle, never drank alcohol). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to your main job
dictionary_examples: She does a bit of bar work on the side.
learner_examples: At work, they gave her the worst jobs to do. She knew she didn't have much choice but she still tried to find something else on the side. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: I accepted the job on the spot.
learner_examples: And when it was Meredith's turn to tell her about her impending wedding, she felt she was going to have a heart attack on the spot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: on the spur of the moment
pos_items.definition: If you do something on the spur of the moment, you do it suddenly, without planning it.
dictionary_examples: On the spur of the moment we decided to go to London for the day.
learner_examples: In reality, many people buy things on the spur of the moment only to discover later that they, in fact, do not [meet] their expect[at]ions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: at the start of a new and important time or development
dictionary_examples: We're on the threshold of a new era in European relations.
learner_examples: On the threshold of the third millen[n]ium, there is no stopping progress. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If you have something on, you are wearing it.
dictionary_examples: She's got a black coat on.
Why don't you put your new dress on?
learner_examples: And I want you to put on some baggy clothes, so that you'll feel comfortable while working. (Key English Test; A2; Rajasthani)

pos_items.definition: into a bus, train, plane, etc. or onto a horse
dictionary_examples: The train suddenly started moving as I was stepping on.
Her horse began to move as soon as she was on.

pos_items.definition: happening or planned
dictionary_examples: I'm busy tomorrow, but I've got nothing on the day after.
I've got a lot on at the moment.
Do you know what's on at the cinema?
Is the party still on for tomorrow?

pos_items.definition: performing
dictionary_examples: Hurry up with the make-up - I'm on in ten minutes.
The audience cheered as the band came on.
learner_examples: My faith in youth started to fade but then a boy named Josh came on. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in a way which results in forward movement
dictionary_examples: You cycle on and I'll meet you there.
Move on, please, and let the ambulance through.
learner_examples: I had just got [o]n the subway when it stopped and didn't move on. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: working or being used
dictionary_examples: The heating has been on all day.
learner_examples: For example, the staff shouldn't leave the lights [on] and the heating's on when they don't need to use it. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: on or onto a surface
dictionary_examples: Ouch, you're standing on my foot!
I dropped my pen on the floor.
Look at all the books on your desk!
We put all of our medicine on a high shelf.
Your suitcase is on top of the wardrobe.
learner_examples: I can read the book, listen to music, watch TV or just sit on my sofa and drink a hot [cup of] tea. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show the day or date when something happens
dictionary_examples: Many shops don't open on Sundays.
What are you doing on Friday?
My birthday's on the 30th of May.
learner_examples: I go to college on Monday and Wednesday. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: covering, touching, attached to or hanging from something
dictionary_examples: You've got blood on your shirt.
Which finger do you wear your ring on?
We could hang this picture on the wall next to the door.
Dogs should be kept on their leads at all times.
learner_examples: I like my bedroom, because there are [a] lot of windows, two armchair[s], a lamp next to the bed, a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a place when giving directions
dictionary_examples: Our house is the first on the left after the post office.
Take the first turning on the right.
learner_examples: My house is the first one on the left. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used for showing some methods of travelling
dictionary_examples: I love travelling on trains.
She'll be arriving on the five-thirty bus.
We went to France on the ferry.
learner_examples: I will travel on a train and then I will take [a] taxi to your home. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: in a particular place
dictionary_examples: the diagram on page 22
They lived on a farm.
learner_examples: I live on a farm in the Emmental. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: on a boat, train, aircraft, etc.

pos_items.definition: intentionally

pos_items.definition: generally

learner_examples: I am writing on behalf of our college English club members to welcome you [to] our city. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: in addition to something else that is bad

learner_examples: On the one hand, I know from my experience that it's much easier in life if you know more about everything, but on the other hand, I'd say that if someone [had given] me a chance (when I was kid) to study what I enjoy[ed], probably I'd have more possibility to develop my skills. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: available
dictionary_examples: We were amazed at the range of products on offer.
You should find out about the services on offer.
learner_examples: The swimming pool is also on offer [to] tourists. Another advantage of the hotel is that it is not far from the cent[re]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be a member of a group or organization
dictionary_examples: She's on the playgroup committee.
How many people are on your staff?
She's a researcher on a women's magazine.
learner_examples: As a student on the committee w[h]ich organises this, I have to say that there have been some problems with the experience, and also that some changes should be made in order to make a better programme. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: having something as a reason
dictionary_examples: Marks are awarded on the basis of progress and performance.
learner_examples: On the basis of the points mentioned above, it is a foregone conclusion that young people do not face any severe problems. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be quick to understand and react to things
dictionary_examples: She's over ninety, but she's still on the ball.
learner_examples: When you're at Sants station, you'll need to be on the ball to find the tube. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: on television or radio
dictionary_examples: The radio station is on air from 6.00 a.m.
learner_examples: It is on air at 8.30 p.m. every Thursday and Saturday. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: because of a particular reason
dictionary_examples: You cannot discriminate on the grounds of religion.
I refused on the grounds that it was too risky.
learner_examples: I am convinced that it is better than Southside College on the grounds that a great mass of students are satisfied. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If a plan or activity is on hold, it will not be done until a later time.
dictionary_examples: The project is on hold until we get more money.
learner_examples: What's more, it might, intentional[l]y or not, raise awareness on issues that might have been put on hold by authorities, such as the legalization of soft drugs. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: waiting to speak to someone on the telephone
dictionary_examples: His secretary put me on hold.
learner_examples: The day after, I called your office and after being put on hold, the person answering the phone was unwilling to come up with a proper reply. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: likely to happen soon
dictionary_examples: Economic recovery is on the horizon.
learner_examples: Often this is justified as [a] result of society being collective[ly] afraid that a shortage of fuel is on the horizon. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If something is on the increase, it is happening more often.
dictionary_examples: Violent crime is on the increase.
learner_examples: [The] number of motorists is on the increase everywhere in the world. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Czech)

pos_items.definition: If something is on loan, someone is borrowing it.
dictionary_examples: Both paintings are on loan from the city museum.
learner_examples: For example, you can always take out on loan any video you like from our cent[re]. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If a film or television programme is made on location, it is made at a place suitable to the story.
dictionary_examples: The movie was shot on location in Kenya.
learner_examples: We can't help mentioning the nice shots on location. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: driving or travelling, usually over a long distance
dictionary_examples: We'd been on the road for 48 hours.
learner_examples: I have experienced sitting behind a steering wheel on the road for many years. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: making progress and likely to succeed
dictionary_examples: A fighter from Edinburgh is on track to become world heavyweight boxing champion.
We've got a lot of work to do but we're on the right track.
learner_examples: The sales teams are well on track and bringing [in] new customers every day. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: being shown to the public
dictionary_examples: Her designs are currently on show at the Museum of Modern Art.
learner_examples: One of the facilit[ies] that really make[s] a difference is the Art Gallery, with its great exhibition on show, as well as the Art Library. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: inside a factory, office building, etc.
dictionary_examples: There are two restaurants on site.
They provide on-site childcare facilities for employees.
learner_examples: A small period of training on site is required a few days before the beginning of the job itself and how many interesting people you will meet! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the verge of sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to happen or do something very soon
dictionary_examples: The company is on the verge of financial disaster.
learner_examples: I was on the verge of depression, when I decided to take the control of my own life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to have something with you
dictionary_examples: Do you have your driving licence on you?

pos_items.sense_title: on no account; not on any account
pos_items.definition: not for any reason or in any situation
dictionary_examples: On no account must these records be changed.
learner_examples: Mary did not want Martin to leave on any account, let alone move to a foreign country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the brink of sth
pos_items.definition: to be in a situation where something bad is going to happen very soon
dictionary_examples: The two countries are on the brink of war.
learner_examples: By the end of the 21st century, Earth was on the brink of destruction. The atmosphere was polluted, the seas were poisoned, the animals were just a distant memory. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be likely to happen
dictionary_examples: Do you think marriage is on the cards?

pos_items.definition: to be extremely happy and excited
dictionary_examples: After I heard I'd got the job, I was on cloud nine!
learner_examples: But now, after the promise in which both said "yes", she was on cloud nine. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: at that exact time
dictionary_examples: We have to leave at 7.30 on the dot.
learner_examples: He gave him an address and told him to be there at six on the dot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: I only drink alcohol on occasion.
learner_examples: As I am writing this I am begin[n]ing to conclude that there are very few disadvantages of banning private cars, only that for individuals it is far easier and [more] conven[i]ent to use a private car and not rely on our public transport, which can be on occasions very unreliable. (International English Language Testing System; C2; English)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the verge of sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to happen or to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: a company on the verge of financial disaster
learner_examples: I was on the verge of depression, when I decided to take control of my own life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If two people are on the same wavelength, they have the same way of thinking and it is easy for them to understand each other.
dictionary_examples: We chatted occasionally, but I never really felt we were on the same wavelength.
learner_examples: We were on the same wavelength and we therefore started our own research. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If someone's job, reputation, life, etc. is on the line, they may lose it.
dictionary_examples: If we don't win the contract, all our jobs are on the line.
learner_examples: The person who hopes to achieve success shouldn't be afraid of taking risks and sometimes putting his or her career on the line for the sake of gaining much bigger benefits. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to be nervous or worried
dictionary_examples: Sorry for shouting - I'm a bit on edge today.
learner_examples: I was consequently on edge all the time and was not able to have fun as much as the others did. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are describing how a situation seems on the surface
dictionary_examples: On the face of it, it seems like a bargain, but I bet there are hidden costs.
learner_examples: On the face of it, both sides have valid arguments, and it's a difficult balancing act to manage. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: If someone is in form or on form, they are feeling or performing well, and if they are off form they are not feeling or performing well.
dictionary_examples: Harry was on good form last night.

pos_items.definition: to be ready to deal with something difficult that might happen
dictionary_examples: Companies were warned to be on their guard for suspicious packages.
learner_examples: However, we should be on guard, so as not to let the things escape our control. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: near to someone or something, and ready to help or be used when necessary
dictionary_examples: Extra supplies will be on hand, should they be needed.
learner_examples: From their point of view, they can always have you on hand whenever they need help, which is the most important part in their formative years. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: suddenly and without thinking first
dictionary_examples: I tend to act on impulse.
learner_examples: I'm seeing Milly as a capricious girl who, like most teenagers, enjoy[s] buying, although I think that she buys on impulse. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: on the part of sb; on sb's part
pos_items.definition: done or experienced by someone
dictionary_examples: This is a major sacrifice on the part of the unions.
The accident was caused by carelessness on the instructor's part.
learner_examples: It seems that international sports competitions have always tended to attract a great amount of interest on the part of the media and have consistently been popular with sports fans the world over. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: If you refuse to do something on principle, you refuse to do it because you think it is morally wrong.
dictionary_examples: She doesn't wear fur on principle.
learner_examples: They granted themselves a little celebration: it was time to keep the promise made four years before; so they bought some bottles of wine and got drunk (the[y] who, on principle, never drank alcohol). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to your main job
dictionary_examples: She does a bit of bar work on the side.
learner_examples: At work, they gave her the worst jobs to do. She knew she didn't have much choice but she still tried to find something else on the side. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: I accepted the job on the spot.
learner_examples: And when it was Meredith's turn to tell her about her impending wedding, she felt she was going to have a heart attack on the spot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: on the spur of the moment
pos_items.definition: If you do something on the spur of the moment, you do it suddenly, without planning it.
dictionary_examples: On the spur of the moment we decided to go to London for the day.
learner_examples: In reality, many people buy things on the spur of the moment only to discover later that they, in fact, do not [meet] their expect[at]ions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: at the start of a new and important time or development
dictionary_examples: We're on the threshold of a new era in European relations.
learner_examples: On the threshold of the third millen[n]ium, there is no stopping progress. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If you have something on, you are wearing it.
dictionary_examples: She's got a black coat on.
Why don't you put your new dress on?
learner_examples: And I want you to put on some baggy clothes, so that you'll feel comfortable while working. (Key English Test; A2; Rajasthani)

pos_items.definition: into a bus, train, plane, etc. or onto a horse
dictionary_examples: The train suddenly started moving as I was stepping on.
Her horse began to move as soon as she was on.

pos_items.definition: happening or planned
dictionary_examples: I'm busy tomorrow, but I've got nothing on the day after.
I've got a lot on at the moment.
Do you know what's on at the cinema?
Is the party still on for tomorrow?

pos_items.definition: performing
dictionary_examples: Hurry up with the make-up - I'm on in ten minutes.
The audience cheered as the band came on.
learner_examples: My faith in youth started to fade but then a boy named Josh came on. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in a way which results in forward movement
dictionary_examples: You cycle on and I'll meet you there.
Move on, please, and let the ambulance through.
learner_examples: I had just got [o]n the subway when it stopped and didn't move on. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: working or being used
dictionary_examples: The heating has been on all day.
learner_examples: For example, the staff shouldn't leave the lights [on] and the heating's on when they don't need to use it. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used after an order or suggestion to show what the result will be if you do not follow that order or suggestion
dictionary_examples: I'd better write it down, otherwise I'll forget it.
You really must phone home. Otherwise, your parents will start to worry.
learner_examples: Oh! I'll have to buy a table for the computer. Otherwise, I'll have to use my computer on my bed. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: different to what has just been stated
dictionary_examples: I'll meet you there at 6 o'clock, unless I hear otherwise.
The police believe he is the thief, but all the evidence suggests otherwise.
Under the law, a person is presumed innocent until proved otherwise.
Marion Morrison, otherwise known as the film star John Wayne, was born in 1907.
I can't meet you on Tuesday - I'm otherwise engaged.
learner_examples: An important event in the history of Greece was the Civil War between the cities of Athens and Sparti around 400 B.C., otherwise known as [the] Pelopon[n]esian War. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: except for what has just been referred to
dictionary_examples: The bike needs a new saddle, but otherwise it's in good condition.
The poor sound quality ruined an otherwise splendid film.
learner_examples: This seemed the high point of an otherwise dull and disorganised event. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a period of time when someone goes away from home for a social activity
dictionary_examples: He's out nearly every night.
He's asked me out to the cinema next week.
learner_examples: After the film, we can have dinner out. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not in the place where you usually live or work, especially for a short time
dictionary_examples: I came round to see you this morning, but you were out.
Someone phoned for you while you were out.
learner_examples: Will you give [it] back to my father because I am out for a while. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container
dictionary_examples: Get out!
She opened the window and stuck her head out.
The bag burst and the apples fell out.
He opened the drawer and took out a pair of socks.
My secretary will see you out.
learner_examples: When I was on the plane, I decided to open my suitcase to take out my CD player because I was bored. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: able to be seen
dictionary_examples: The stars are out tonight.
The rain stopped and the sun came out.
The flowers are starting to come out.
learner_examples: In the beginning it was raining a little bit, but then the sun came out. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If a light or fire is out, it is no longer shining or burning.
dictionary_examples: When we got home, all the lights were out.
Is that fire completely out?
learner_examples: I looked out through the window to check if the lights were out in the windows of the block of flats next to ours. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: available to buy or see
dictionary_examples: Is the new Harry Potter book out yet?
The new Tarantino movie comes out in August.
learner_examples: It came out just yesterday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to the point where something is removed or disappears
dictionary_examples: The stain won't come out.
Cross out any words that are not on the list.
learner_examples: A friend of mine told me, when he was in Lampton, that you couldn't have special rates for students at Hotel Royal, so you should cross [that information] out of the guide. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: If you say or read something out loud, you say or read it so that other people can hear you.
dictionary_examples: I had to read the essay out loud in front of the whole school.
learner_examples: She wouldn't accept it so I read [it] out loud for her to hear: "Director, Jason Meyer, and producer, Sami Woods, are receiving...". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: a long distance away from land, a town or your own country
dictionary_examples: The fishing boats were out at sea for three days.
They live out in the countryside, miles from anywhere.
He lived out in Zambia for seven years.
learner_examples: Today I live out in the country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romansch)

pos_items.definition: not accurate
dictionary_examples: Your figures are out by £300.

pos_items.definition: having no money, no luck and no opportunities
dictionary_examples: Nobody loves you when you're down and out.
learner_examples: The neglect of social security as a vital point in state policies leaves homeless people down and out, with little chance for improving their bleak prospects. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: the ins and outs of sth
pos_items.definition: the details of a particular subject
dictionary_examples: the ins and outs of the legal system
learner_examples: I knew all the ins and outs of every story but I couldn't stay one single day in bed without reading it. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: more than a particular amount, number, or age
dictionary_examples: Most of the bikes cost/are over £300.
Children over the age of 12 must have full-price tickets.
They are already $25 million over budget.
learner_examples: We have to dance in a school and over two hundred people [will watch] us. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: covering something or someone
dictionary_examples: Put a blanket over you to keep warm.
I put my hands over my eyes because I didn't want to see.
learner_examples: Wear an apron over your clothes. (Key English Test; A2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: above or higher than something
dictionary_examples: The sign over the door said "Exit".
A flock of geese flew over the trees.
She held the umbrella over both of us.
learner_examples: Besides that, you have voted for the construction of a new bridge over the main street. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: across from one side of something to the other, especially by going up and then down
dictionary_examples: She jumped over the gate.
The road goes over the mountains.
She is always chatting with her neighbour over the garden fence.
From the top of the tower you could see for miles over the city.
Tanks travel over the most difficult ground.
learner_examples: I most enjoyed [it] when we [were] cycling over the hills, because there weren't any people and it was peaceful and qui[et]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: everywhere in a particular place
dictionary_examples: Soon the news was all over town.
learner_examples: The people in the class are from all over the world. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: during a particular period of time
dictionary_examples: I was in Seattle over the summer.
We discussed the matter over lunch.
It's fascinating to watch how a baby changes and develops over time.
learner_examples: He apologised for the trouble and when he heard that they just wanted to stay over the weekend, he said they should go and buy the most important things and enjoy the weekend as the suitcase wo[uld]n't arrive until Monday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: on the other side of
dictionary_examples: There's a pub over the road we could go to.
The story continues over the page.
The station is over the bridge.

pos_items.definition: in control of or teaching someone or something
dictionary_examples: A good teacher has an easy authority over a class.
She's a sales manager but she has a regional sales director over her.
The victory over the French at Waterloo was Wellington's greatest triumph.
learner_examples: Fortunately, my parents do not wield authority over me and my siblings like dictators. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: using
dictionary_examples: They spoke over the phone.
We heard the news over the radio.
learner_examples: She laughed over the phone, and said "It's really like you". (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in this/that place
dictionary_examples: Put your bags down over there.
learner_examples: How is everything over there? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: connected with or about
dictionary_examples: It's stupid arguing over something so trivial.
learner_examples: The teams themselves suffered from these money problems: recently strikes broke out in basketball teams in the U.S when players began to argue over money. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: too extreme and not suitable
dictionary_examples: I thought her performance was way over the top.
learner_examples: In addition to that, many so-called "stars" have that certain over the top attitude, which would not be welcome in normal life. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: more than a particular amount or level
dictionary_examples: People who are 65 years old and over can get half-price tickets.
learner_examples: In my opinion, the minimum working age being 18 and over, I think the school leaving age should be limited to just 16. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Others)

pos_items.definition: from one side or place to another
dictionary_examples: She leaned over and kissed me.
Why don't you come over for dinner on Thursday?
I've got a friend over from Canada this week.
Now we're going over to Wembley for commentary on the Cup Final.
learner_examples: He came over to me and we talked a while. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: describes the way an object moves or is moved so that a different part of it is facing up
dictionary_examples: She turned another page over.
learner_examples: A big truck had turned over and blocked the road and there was no other way for us to go, so we had to wait. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: finished
dictionary_examples: I'll be glad when the competition is over.
I used to have a thriving business and a happy marriage, but that's all over now.
learner_examples: David smiled triumphantly and said, "It is all over!" (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: happening or done many times
dictionary_examples: I read the article over and over till it made sense.
learner_examples: I've been searching in newspapers over and over again and finally after a couple of days I found something. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: repeated from the beginning
dictionary_examples: We had to start all over again.
learner_examples: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to do something difficult or unpleasant as soon as you can so that you do not have to worry about it any more
dictionary_examples: I got all my apologies over and done with at the beginning of the meeting.
learner_examples: Not to mention that he knew that he had to get his degree over and done with before he started making serious decisions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are going to give more detail about something you have just said
dictionary_examples: She learned an important lesson from failing that exam, namely that nothing is ever certain.
learner_examples: This network is used by the four most used means of transport in our city (namely, bus, car, bicycle and motorcycle) and has been plagued by problems such as potholes, poor drainage and poor use (or lack!) of traffic signs. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: despite what has just been said
dictionary_examples: He was extremely rude in meetings. Nonetheless, his arguments found some support.
learner_examples: Nonetheless, all the people from whom I have received letters are satisfied, as well as their children, who enjoyed the stories and the pony rides very much. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: not at work
dictionary_examples: I had six months off after my son was born.
I'm going to take/have some time off to work on my house.
She was off sick last week.
learner_examples: I will take a day off on Friday. (Key English Test; A2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing
dictionary_examples: Take your jacket off.
One of my buttons has come off.
She's had all her hair cut off.
I left the lid off.
learner_examples: I took off my ring. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: not operating or being used
dictionary_examples: Make sure the computers are all off before you go home.
learner_examples: I tr[i]ed to contact my neighbour, but his phone was off and nobody was at home. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Pashto)

pos_items.definition: away from a place or position
dictionary_examples: I'm just off to the shops.
Keep the dog on the lead or he'll just run off.
If we can get off early tomorrow morning we'll avoid most of the traffic.
I'm off now - see you tomorrow.
She's off to Canada next week.
learner_examples: They g[o]t into the car and drove off. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: If a price has a certain amount of money off, it costs that much less than the usual price.
dictionary_examples: You can get some money off if you pay cash.
There's 40% off this week on all winter coats.
There was $40 or $50 off most jackets in the shop.
learner_examples: He promised me 30% off the price, so I'm going to buy the TV and the CD player from him. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: far in distance or time
dictionary_examples: You can see the village off in the distance.
My holidays seem a long way off.
The exams are so far off that I'm not even thinking about them yet.
learner_examples: Allow me to start by saying that one day, which may l[ie] not so far off in the future, people will visit the buildings which were formerly known as "Educational Institutions" like we visit museums to gape at the sheer size of the Dinosaurs... (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: down or away from a place or position
dictionary_examples: All the leaves had dropped off the tree.
He fell off his bike.
learner_examples: I still remember the way your brother fell off the lad[d]er that day. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing
dictionary_examples: I can't get the lid off this jar.
Has anyone taken a book off my desk?
Could you cut me a small piece off that white cheese?
Take your feet off the seat.
learner_examples: Next month, I'm going to change my bedroom. I'll take the photographs off the wall. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: near to a building or place
dictionary_examples: an island off the coast of Spain
learner_examples: He spent all night off the coast, (unfinished) (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If someone such as a doctor or a soldier is off duty, they are not working.
dictionary_examples: What time are you off duty tomorrow?
learner_examples: Sometimes I come off duty at ten p.m. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If an area is off limits, you are not allowed to enter it.
dictionary_examples: Most of the palace is off limits to the public.
learner_examples: The only place that was off limits for us was on the other side of the mountain, because it was too dangerous. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If you say something off the record, you do not want the public to know about it.
dictionary_examples: Off the record, ministers are saying the president must resign.
learner_examples: Off the record, how come that your reporter can print such lies when knowing they are perhaps hurting certain people in this important matter? (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: in a place where few people go
dictionary_examples: I prefer to take my holiday somewhere off the beaten track.
learner_examples: Furthermore, in areas off the beaten track, there [are] not even police sometimes. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If food or drink is off, it is not now fresh and good to eat or drink.
dictionary_examples: This milk smells off.
learner_examples: Who knows if the food isn't off? (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: stopped or given up
dictionary_examples: The wedding's off - she's decided she's too young to settle down.
It's all off between Philippa and Mike.
The boat trip is off because of the weather.

pos_items.definition: different to what has just been stated

pos_items.definition: except for what has just been referred to

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a period of time when someone goes away from home for a social activity

pos_items.definition: not in the place where you usually live or work, especially for a short time

pos_items.definition: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container

pos_items.definition: If a woman or girl is pretty, she is attractive.

a pretty little village

pos_items.definition: now

pos_items.definition: available at a good price

pos_items.definition: good/successful/well, etc. enough but not very good or very well

pos_items.definition: in a fair way, showing good judgment
dictionary_examples: Stop shouting and let's discuss this reasonably.

pos_items.definition: in an unhappy way

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not satisfactory

pos_items.definition: in a reluctant way

pos_items.definition: in a sensible way

pos_items.definition: in a respectful way
