learner_examples: They were living separately and missing each other. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: not completely
dictionary_examples: partially cooked
learner_examples: Building a parking area outside the city centre would partially solve this problem. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: badly
dictionary_examples: poorly educated
learner_examples: On the contrary, to my mind both issues were handled rather poorly. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: ill
dictionary_examples: Rosie was feeling poorly so I put her to bed.
learner_examples: When a colle[a]gue is absent [due to] feeling poorly, I can automatically do the duties of that person because we work as a group. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Ibo/Igbo)

pos_items.definition: If something is done publicly, it is done so that everyone can know about it
dictionary_examples: The company publicly apologized and agreed to contribute some money to charity.
learner_examples: It would be a sound opportunity for our singers to perform their new albums and make their work publicly known. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: only
dictionary_examples: She married him purely for his money.
learner_examples: And we had to arrange our social programme purely by ourselves. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that shows radical change or beliefs
dictionary_examples: The company has changed radically in recent years.
Barker introduced some radically new ideas.
learner_examples: During the last decades our eating habits have changed radically in Sweden. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in a random way
dictionary_examples: The books were randomly arranged on the shelves.
learner_examples: It is based on the survey of the Language Institute's students, who were randomly selected. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: in a way that shows things and people as they really are, or that makes them seem real
dictionary_examples: The characters are portrayed very realistically.
learner_examples: It was realistically captured in the TV reports you have seen. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that shows that you accept the true facts of a situation
dictionary_examples: Realistically, we cannot expect to have finished by the weekend.
learner_examples: Realistically, separate schools will probably be with us for a long time to come, but it will remain the least used form of the two. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans)

pos_items.definition: in a way that makes you feel surprised
dictionary_examples: She has remarkably good skin for her age.
learner_examples: As for your flight attendants, who are always friendly and remarkably helpful, it would be excellent if they were able to speak other languages apart from English. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: many times
dictionary_examples: He telephoned repeatedly, begging her to return.
The European Union has repeatedly stressed the importance of language learning.
learner_examples: Once you pick up the new words and learn something, you need to say it repeatedly otherwise you will easily forget [it]. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: in a way that relates to each of the people or things that you have just talked about
dictionary_examples: They scored 10 and 17 points, respectively.
learner_examples: Not only [did] we reach our target figure but also, 85% of the revenue generated went to the hospital, and only 10% and 5% were for entertainment costs and administration costs, respectively. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: in a satisfactory way
dictionary_examples: I'm sure these problems can be satisfactorily resolved.
learner_examples: The main problem is finding the most accurate meaning of some words, phrasal verbs, idioms etc. Dictionaries can do the job satisfactorily but the problem inside is left unsolved. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: appearing to be something without really being that thing
dictionary_examples: a seemingly harmless comment
learner_examples: You also claim that we did not reach our target figure - a statement seemingly based on pure assumption - which is completely incorrect. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: mostly or mainly
dictionary_examples: a predominantly Asian community
learner_examples: Nevertheless the Japanese scientist refutes the latter argument on basis of his famous theory, according to which the predominantly masculine pleasure of driving is caused by a 'hidden dictator's syndrome'. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a profound way
dictionary_examples: I think this approach is profoundly misguided.
Her recent songs have been profoundly influenced by current events.
learner_examples: In my opinion the reason why Olivia left Douglas was not so much that she didn't love him as the fact that she was profoundly bored by the life she conducted in India. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that shows things and people as they really are, or that makes them seem real

pos_items.definition: in a way that never stops or never gets less extreme
dictionary_examples: They pestered her relentlessly to take them to the seaside.
learner_examples: After the killing of the two sensible members of the group, namely Piggy and Simon, Ralph is relentlessly pursued by Jack. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: approximately
dictionary_examples: There has been an increase of roughly 2.25 million.
Roughly speaking, it's 2.25 million.
We have roughly the same tastes.
learner_examples: These are very special cases and roughly speaking, confined to one thing. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: forcefully or violently
dictionary_examples: He pushed us roughly out of the door.
learner_examples: My mother treated me roughly and unkindly by thrashing or smacking me a[t] any time possible. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: without taking a lot of care to make something perfect
dictionary_examples: Roughly chop the tomatoes and add to the onions.
learner_examples: She glanced at the mirror, roughly [brushed] her hair with her fingers and went outside for her car. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: only just
dictionary_examples: They had scarcely finished eating when the doorbell rang.
learner_examples: Scarcely had the ferry reached the shore than the heavy storm abated. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a time after midday but before midnight
dictionary_examples: We'll be arriving at about 4.30 p.m.
The 6 p.m. train is usually very crowded.
learner_examples: See you tomorrow at 7 p.m. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show that something is possible or that you are not certain about something
dictionary_examples: He hasn't written to me recently - perhaps he's lost my address.
We plan to travel to Europe - to Spain or Italy perhaps.
learner_examples: What about Saturday or perhaps Friday? (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: surrounding or being on all sides of something, or in a circular movement
dictionary_examples: We sat round the fire.
I put my arm round her.
She had a scarf round her neck.
The Moon goes round the Earth.
learner_examples: There [is] a big wood round this lake. (Key English Test; A2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: to or in different parts of a place
dictionary_examples: The landlord showed me round the house.
I had to go all round town to find a hotel that was open.
learner_examples: Well, she showed me round her hometown and we did some sight-seeing. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: to someone's home
dictionary_examples: Wendy's coming round this afternoon.
I'll go round and see her later.
learner_examples: So would you come round and see me? (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: with a circular movement
dictionary_examples: This switch makes the wheels go round.

pos_items.definition: to the opposite direction
dictionary_examples: She looked round.
Turn the car round and let's go home.
learner_examples: I turned round and I saw that the one who was calling me was the singer!! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: from one place or person to another
dictionary_examples: Could you pass these forms round, please?

pos_items.definition: moving in a circle without stopping
dictionary_examples: We drove round and round trying to find the hotel.
learner_examples: It's not fun to look at an animal who is bored and only walks round and round. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in the shape of a circle or ball
dictionary_examples: a round hole/stone/table/window
a round face
learner_examples: It is on the round table in your room. (Key English Test; A2; Kannada)

pos_items.definition: the first/second/third/final, etc. stage in a competition
dictionary_examples: He was beaten in the first round.
learner_examples: At five o'clock in the afternoon, the second round of the games [will begin]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: when people clap
dictionary_examples: The crowd gave him a huge round of applause.
learner_examples: It was unbelievable, there was a round of applause and some people couldn't help crying. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: drinks that you buy for a group of people
dictionary_examples: It's your turn to buy the next round.
learner_examples: Rob (her husband) was so happy and in such a splendid mood that he decided to pay [for] a round of beer. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: a group of events that is part of a series
dictionary_examples: a round of interviews
a new round of talks between the two countries
learner_examples: My life was an endless round of parties, and social events. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: correct or true
dictionary_examples: He only got half the answers right.
You're right about Alison - she's incredible!
"You came here in 1979, didn't you?" "That's right."
learner_examples: You're right! (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: on or towards the side of your body that is to the east when you are facing north
dictionary_examples: Most people write with their right hand.
There's a tree on the right side of the house.
learner_examples: He saw a man running away holding a gun [i]n his right hand. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: suitable or best in a particular situation
dictionary_examples: I'm not sure she's the right person for the job.
Are we going in the right direction?
learner_examples: I know that you will make the right choice! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: fair or morally acceptable
dictionary_examples: It's not right to criticize him behind his back.

learner_examples: Was he doing the right thing or he was just making matters worse? (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to the side of your body that is to the east when you are facing north
dictionary_examples: Turn/Go right at the first traffic lights.
learner_examples: When you go from [the] city, [at the] first roundabout turn right. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to get someone's attention or to show you have understood someone
dictionary_examples: Right, whose turn is it to tidy up?
Right, so Helen's coming tomorrow and Trevor on Thursday.

pos_items.definition: exactly in a place or time
dictionary_examples: He's right here with me.
I fell asleep right in the middle of her speech.
They live right in the centre of the city.
learner_examples: That's me, right here. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: correctly
dictionary_examples: He guessed right most of the time.

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: Do you want to start right away?
learner_examples: I [would] love to see your new trousers but I'm busy right now. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: all the way
dictionary_examples: Did you read it right through to the end?
learner_examples: As time passes by, Ralph learns about Piggy's value as he is the only one that stays with him right to the end. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: the right side of your body, or the direction towards this side

pos_items.definition: morally correct behaviour
dictionary_examples: I've tried to teach them the difference between right and wrong.
learner_examples: He was raised not knowing the difference between right and wrong. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: something that the law allows you to do
dictionary_examples: the right to free speech
the right to vote
learner_examples: To sum up, famous people are the same as we are, and we all have the right to lead a private life and no right to break into their privacy. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: political groups which support capitalism
dictionary_examples: The right campaigned against the president.

pos_items.sense_title: have a/no right to do sth

learner_examples: [O]n the other hand, New Zealand came second [for] senior government. (International English Language Testing System; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about the second in a series of things
dictionary_examples: Second, they failed to send written warning.
learner_examples: Second, the pedestrian area in the commercial centre has to grow, wh[ich] would make this part of the town more pleasant for walking and would improve the opportunities [for] the shops. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: one of the 60 parts a minute is divided into
dictionary_examples: There are sixty seconds in a minute.
These computers process millions of instructions per second.
The new system can trace a phone call in a fraction of a second.
learner_examples: I thought the British one, Peter, was going to win, but [in] the last 10 seconds, the Venez[ue]lan won! (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: a very short period of time
dictionary_examples: "Come on, hurry up!" "I'll just/only be a second - I've got to lock the back door."
Have you got a second, Paul? I'd like to have a word with you.
It won't take a second .
Wait a couple of/a few seconds before trying again.
learner_examples: A few seconds later, a huge tree beside my house fell down and destroyed most of my house. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: something that is sold cheaply because it is damaged or not in perfect condition
dictionary_examples: Some of those towels are seconds.

pos_items.definition: not often
dictionary_examples: We seldom go out in the evenings.
learner_examples: Alice was a quiet girl, she seldom talked, but he just couldn't stop talking. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If something has reportedly happened or is reportedly a fact, people say it has happened or is true.
dictionary_examples: Two students were reportedly killed and several wounded.
learner_examples: Some types of birds have reportedly become extinct in the area. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: correct or true
dictionary_examples: He only got half the answers right.
You're right about Alison - she's incredible!
"You came here in 1979, didn't you?" "That's right."
learner_examples: You're right! (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: on or towards the side of your body that is to the east when you are facing north
dictionary_examples: Most people write with their right hand.
There's a tree on the right side of the house.
learner_examples: He saw a man running away holding a gun [i]n his right hand. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: suitable or best in a particular situation
dictionary_examples: I'm not sure she's the right person for the job.
Are we going in the right direction?
learner_examples: I know that you will make the right choice! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: fair or morally acceptable
dictionary_examples: It's not right to criticize him behind his back.
Someone had to tell him - I think you did the right thing.
learner_examples: Was he doing the right thing or he was just making matters worse? (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to the side of your body that is to the east when you are facing north
dictionary_examples: Turn/Go right at the first traffic lights.
learner_examples: When you go from [the] city, [at the] first roundabout turn right. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to get someone's attention or to show you have understood someone
dictionary_examples: Right, whose turn is it to tidy up?
Right, so Helen's coming tomorrow and Trevor on Thursday.

pos_items.definition: exactly in a place or time
dictionary_examples: He's right here with me.
I fell asleep right in the middle of her speech.
They live right in the centre of the city.
learner_examples: That's me, right here. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: correctly
dictionary_examples: He guessed right most of the time.

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: Do you want to start right away?
learner_examples: I [would] love to see your new trousers but I'm busy right now. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: all the way
dictionary_examples: Did you read it right through to the end?
learner_examples: As time passes by, Ralph learns about Piggy's value as he is the only one that stays with him right to the end. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: the right side of your body, or the direction towards this side
dictionary_examples: You'll find her in the second room on the right.
learner_examples: On the right there is a wardrobe and a table with a chair. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: morally correct behaviour
dictionary_examples: I've tried to teach them the difference between right and wrong.
learner_examples: He was raised not knowing the difference between right and wrong. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: something that the law allows you to do
dictionary_examples: the right to free speech
the right to vote
learner_examples: To sum up, famous people are the same as we are, and we all have the right to lead a private life and no right to break into their privacy. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: political groups which support capitalism
dictionary_examples: The right campaigned against the president.

pos_items.sense_title: have a/no right to do sth
pos_items.definition: to have, or not have, a good reason for something
dictionary_examples: He has a right to be angry.
She had no right to speak to me like that.
learner_examples: Finally, you have no right to say that we "did not reach our target figure" since the whole event was considered to be a success by many people. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: in a way that does not rely on anything or anyone else
dictionary_examples: I think this is a dialect, rather than a language in its own right.
These experiments are very important in their own right.
learner_examples: Major international sports competitions can either be understood as a means to an end or an end in their own right. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to express agreement with someone
dictionary_examples: "Johnny, you climb up first." - "Right!"

pos_items.definition: used after saying a fact to introduce what then happened as a result
dictionary_examples: They planned to reduce staff and thus to cut costs.
learner_examples: As a result of the density, the atmosphere in the halls also became hot and humid, thus making the whole experience rather unpleasant. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: certain
dictionary_examples: "What's wrong with him?" "I'm not sure."
I'm sure (that) I left my keys on the table.
I feel absolutely sure (that) you've made the right decision.
Simon isn't sure whether/if he'll be able to come to the party or not.
Are you sure about that?
It now seems sure (that) the election will result in another victory for the government.
learner_examples: I think it's in your room but I'm not sure. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to take action so that you are certain that something happens, is true, etc.
dictionary_examples: Make sure that you close all the windows before you leave.
learner_examples: So please make sure that you we[ar] old clothes. (Key English Test; A2; Albanian)

pos_items.definition: to be confident that something is true
dictionary_examples: He'll win this year, I'm sure of it.
learner_examples: I think that I [would be a] really useful person for your company. I'm sure of it. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: to be confident of your own abilities, qualities, etc.
dictionary_examples: She seems a bit more sure of herself since she got a job.
learner_examples: He is a tall, dark man who walks with confidence and is sure of himself because of his success [i]n the world of business. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: something that is certain to happen
dictionary_examples: Death is the one sure thing about life.
learner_examples: There is only one sure thing, we are not able to even imagine what we will be able to do in the future to get communicated. (Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If you are sure to do something, it is certain that you will do it.
dictionary_examples: He's sure to go back there again.
learner_examples: What she does not know is that her ex-husband has a very serious type of cancer and is sure to pass away in a few months (that is why he agrees to spend his summer with his son, knowing it would be the last). (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: as expected
dictionary_examples: He said the book was on his desk, and sure enough, there it was.
learner_examples: And sure enough, these challenging problems come unsolicited most of the time. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used to show agreement
dictionary_examples: "Can I take this pen?" "Sure."
"Do you want to come swimming with us?" "Sure."
learner_examples: You asked me if I wanted to go to the cinema tonight. Sure! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: without any doubts
dictionary_examples: I think he's Canadian but I don't know for sure.
One thing's for sure - once the baby's born, your lives will never be the same again.
learner_examples: For sure, you'll love Brazil. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: slightly
dictionary_examples: The resort has changed somewhat over the last few years.
She's somewhat more confident than she used to be.
We were somewhat tired after our long walk.
learner_examples: We found the written article to be somewhat inaccurate, since several facts were mistaken and others were blown out of proportion. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: as a result of a particular action or event
dictionary_examples: The new dam will improve the water supply and thereby reduce hunger and disease.
learner_examples: By interacting live with people from all over the world, you can use non-native languages on a daily basis and thereby help developing your foreign language skills. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: after a particular amount, time, or event
dictionary_examples: Faxes cost £1.10p for the first page, and 70p for each page thereafter.
learner_examples: The unemployment rate thereafter started to rise yearly and reached its highest rate in March 1998 (approximately 5.5%). (International English Language Testing System; C2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: very
dictionary_examples: She was terribly upset.
We were terribly lucky that nothing was damaged.
learner_examples: I'm terribly sorry but I've got a job interview. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: very badly
dictionary_examples: I slept terribly last night.
learner_examples: Although he s[a]ng quite well, he danced terribly and that spoiled part of the show. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: completely
dictionary_examples: They're totally different.
I'd totally forgotten I'd arranged to meet her.
I totally agree with you.
learner_examples: But in the new class, it is totally different. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: badly or severely
dictionary_examples: seriously ill/worried
He wasn't seriously injured - he just got a few cuts and bruises.
learner_examples: She is seriously ill with cancer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: in a way that shows that you are not joking
dictionary_examples: Seriously now, did he really say that or are you just being silly?
You're not seriously thinking of leaving, are you?
learner_examples: Seriously, Tom, I have noticed that you get angry very easily since your examinations started. (First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: to consider a person, subject or situation to be important or dangerous and worth your attention or respect
dictionary_examples: The police have to take any terrorist threat seriously.
You don't take anything seriously, do you? It's all one big joke to you.
She wants to be taken seriously as an actress.
These young actors take themselves so seriously!
learner_examples: I hope you take my suggestions seriously. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize what you are saying
dictionary_examples: We simply don't have the time.
You look simply beautiful in that dress.
The hunger in parts of Africa is terrible - there's (quite) simply no other word for it.
learner_examples: It's said that most of the centre's sports facilities are very expensive, [but] that is simply not true. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: only
dictionary_examples: A lot of people miss out on this opportunity simply because they don't know about it.
learner_examples: I am very interested in fashion, simply because it is a style, an attitude, a way of life. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in a way which is not complicated or difficult to understand
dictionary_examples: He explained it as simply as he could, but the class still didn't understand.
learner_examples: Try to organize your work as simply as possible. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: a little
dictionary_examples: She's slightly taller than her sister.
I'm slightly upset she forgot my birthday.
learner_examples: Even at night, it will take you only slightly longer to get from A to B, provided you are near the city centre. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: very much or in a very serious way
dictionary_examples: They strongly believe their children should make choices for themselves.
Many locals are strongly opposed to the development.
learner_examples: I strongly disagree with the statement saying that "At school, students should only study what they enjoy". (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you believe something is very likely
dictionary_examples: Surely they'd have called us by now to say they're not coming.
learner_examples: Surely you are interested in how we spent the rest of our holiday? (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to express surprise that something has happened or is going to happen
dictionary_examples: Surely you don't expect me to believe that?
Surely he wasn't expecting us to pay the whole amount?
learner_examples: Surely it doesn't mean that they have learnt the exciting news? (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you believe something is very likely
dictionary_examples: Surely they'd have called us by now to say they're not coming.
learner_examples: Surely you are interested in how we spent the rest of our holiday? (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to express surprise that something has happened or is going to happen
dictionary_examples: Surely you don't expect me to believe that?
Surely he wasn't expecting us to pay the whole amount?
learner_examples: Surely it doesn't mean that they have learnt the exciting news? (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: very or very much
dictionary_examples: They've worked tremendously hard.
We all enjoyed ourselves tremendously.
learner_examples: I enjoyed it tremendously. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize a description of something
dictionary_examples: This is a truly remarkable achievement.
It was a truly terrifying experience.
learner_examples: Those concerts are truly eye-opening. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something is sincere or honest
dictionary_examples: Truly I could not have done this without you.
He truly believes he can cure himself by willpower alone.
learner_examples: It would probably take years to achieve it but in the long run I truly believe it would work, as long as everyone is willing to [make] an effort. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to end a letter
dictionary_examples: I look forward to hearing from you. Yours truly, Taylor Champinski.
learner_examples: Dear Clyde, . . . I hope my advice helps you [with] your decision. Yours truly, (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: as much as is necessary
dictionary_examples: McGeechan has not recovered sufficiently to play in the semifinal tomorrow.
The case was sufficiently serious to warrant investigation by the police.
learner_examples: As for me, I like to think that my situation will be better than those who are not educated sufficiently. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: unexpectedly or in a way that is unusual
dictionary_examples: The restaurant turned out to be surprisingly cheap.
Not surprisingly, the jury found them guilty.
learner_examples: Surprisingly, I met a friend of mine from primary school. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is very sad
dictionary_examples: She died tragically young.
Tragically, the side-effects of the drug were not discovered until many people had been seriously damaged by it.
learner_examples: She improved his eyesight and tragically disappeared. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a way that relates to or involves technology
dictionary_examples: Their society was technologically advanced.
learner_examples: The economy nowadays is so technologically driven it is [a] common belief that having a job in the computer industry means high pay and perks. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the quantity, quality or amount of something
dictionary_examples: The house is so beautiful.
Don't be so stupid!
I didn't know she had so many children!
Thank you so much for all your help.
I've never seen so many people in one place before!
I'm so tired (that) I could sleep in this chair!
learner_examples: Thank you so much for [your] help! (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something that has just been mentioned, especially to give a short answer to a question
dictionary_examples: "I hope they stay together." "I hope so too."
"Do you think he's upset?" "I don't think so."
James is coming tonight, or so he said.
learner_examples: Do you like this colour? I hope so. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used after a list of things to show that you could have added other similar things
dictionary_examples: She plays a lot of tennis and squash and so on.
learner_examples: I like watching television, playing [on] the computer, reading book[s] and so on. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.sense_title: so did we/so have I/so is mine, etc.
pos_items.definition: used to say that someone else also does something or that the same thing is true about someone or something else
dictionary_examples: "We saw the new Star Trek movie last night." "Oh, so did we."
learner_examples: My eyes went watery and so did hers but then we laughed at each other. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: until now
dictionary_examples: So far we've made thirty-two thousand pounds.
learner_examples: So far I like it here very much. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian)

pos_items.definition: approximately
dictionary_examples: "How many people were at the party?" "Fifty or so, I guess."
learner_examples: After an hour or so they changed the flight and new people came, the he realised that his suitcase was lost. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: if this is the case
dictionary_examples: It might rain this afternoon. If so, we'll have to have the party indoors.
learner_examples: Will you be in time for dinner? If so, I'll cook your favourite dish. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in order to
dictionary_examples: I always keep fruit in the fridge so as to keep insects off it.
learner_examples: I could come on 8th July so as to be there on Tim's birthday. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: if you do this, or if this is done
dictionary_examples: They want to build a completely new school, but to do so would cost far too much.
I would strongly advise you against taking out a loan of this size. To do so would be a great risk to your business.
learner_examples: It is generally believed that if [a] better education is provided, children are better prepared for adult life. To do so, money is essential. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something surprising is true despite what you have just said
dictionary_examples: Car prices have gone down a lot, but even so, we couldn't afford to buy one.
learner_examples: I'm sure many of [these things] happened due to bad luck, but even so, there are some arrangements that, I bel[ie]ve, can easily be improved. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has not been useful or successful
dictionary_examples: "The computer's crashed again." "So much for modern technology."
learner_examples: So much for turkey, crackling and mince pies - we ended up having a Christmas party of our own at Pizza Hut! (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to say that there are limits to something
dictionary_examples: There's only so much help you can give someone.
learner_examples: The effects of a longer life span have many side ef[f]ects such as an increase in the world's population and, since there is only so much food, m[any] more people are st[ar]ving to death. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: so as not to do sth
pos_items.definition: used for saying what the purpose of an action is
dictionary_examples: He went in very quietly so as not to wake the baby.
learner_examples: Secondly, I think we should plan some other kind of activities in case of bad weather and we should have more than one bus with us so as not to waste time in case it breaks down. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you were right and that someone should have believed you
dictionary_examples: He's lazy? I told you so, didn't I?
learner_examples: See, I told you so", Azman said with a grin. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: He went into town every so often to buy supplies.
learner_examples: Elizabeth and others visited her every so often until [one] day she left them. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has gone well until now
dictionary_examples: It's the first time I've done any decorating, but so far so good.
learner_examples: So far so good, only no one told us they held this point of view before the actual christening took place. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to explain that the words you are using do not have their usual meaning
dictionary_examples: That was our accommodation, so to speak.
learner_examples: In those cases, travelling turns into a sort of alienation, so to speak. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is the reason why something else happens
dictionary_examples: I was tired so I went to bed.
Greg had some money so he bought a bike.
My knee started hurting so I stopped running.
I was lost so I bought a street map.
learner_examples: I'm going to change my school, so I have to sell all my books. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to connect it with something that was said or happened previously
dictionary_examples: So, there I was standing at the edge of the road with only my underwear on ...
So, just to finish what I was saying earlier...
So, who do you think is going to win the election?
So, here we are again - just you and me.
So that's what he does when I'm not around!
So we leave on the Thursday and get back the next Tuesday, is that right?
learner_examples: I remember you said that you want to help me. So, can you buy the items for me and then I pay you? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in order to make something happen or be possible
dictionary_examples: He put his glasses on so that he could see the television better.
I deliberately didn't have lunch so (that) I would be hungry tonight.
Leave the keys out so (that) I remember to take them with me.
learner_examples: Could you please give me some extra exercises so that I can cover the work I missed? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: for that reason
dictionary_examples: We were unable to get funding and therefore had to abandon the project.
learner_examples: [I] want to make it look more modern. Therefore, I've decided to get a CD player and some speakers. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: from one end or side of something to the other
dictionary_examples: We drove through the tunnel.
The River Seine flows through Paris.
The sun was shining through the window.
She cut through the wire.
They walked slowly through the woods.
learner_examples: So, through the windows I can see [the sea] and it is wonderful. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: from the start to the end of something
dictionary_examples: He worked through the night.
The phone rang halfway through the programme.
learner_examples: It begins in the evening and goes through the night, because it's a very long play. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: because of someone or something, or with someone's help
dictionary_examples: I got the job through a friend of my mum's.
He became ill through eating undercooked meat.
learner_examples: I knew her through my husband, she is my husband's friend's wife. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: from one end or side to another
dictionary_examples: He opened the door and walked through.
The needle just wouldn't go through.
learner_examples: A few bombs crashed close to the car but we managed to get through. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: A through train goes all the way from one place to another place without the passenger having to change trains.
dictionary_examples: We caught the through train to Manchester.
learner_examples: Then go to the information desk and ask about the time of departure of through trains to Lodz. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something or someone that can be seen or pointed to
dictionary_examples: Did you know that woman in the post office?
How much are those shoes?

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something or someone that has already been talked about or seen
dictionary_examples: Where's that pen gone?
She lives in that house by the bus station.
learner_examples: I like that place be[cause] I like swim[m]ing in [the] sea. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that what you have just said is only an example from a larger group of things
dictionary_examples: They sell souvenirs, postcards, that sort of thing.
learner_examples: I also enjoy using new clothes for the first time, but I prefer buying other stuff like electronic devices or that sort of thing. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used after some verbs, nouns, and adjectives to introduce a new part of a sentence
dictionary_examples: She said (that) she'd collect it for me after work.
Is it true (that) she's gone back to teaching?
We'll be there at about 7.30, provided/providing (that) there's a suitable train.
It was so dark (that) I couldn't see anything.
learner_examples: It's true that I bought a mobile phone. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: because of or for this reason
dictionary_examples: The course is good in that it provides a very practical training.
learner_examples: Nowadays it is widely argued that professional sports are damaging to people's health in that they involve gruelling training sessions as an integral part of the occupation. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something that can be seen or pointed to
dictionary_examples: What's that in the corner?
I'd like some of those.
That looks heavy.

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something that has already been talked about or seen
dictionary_examples: If you do that, you'll be sorry.
I don't think you should put up with that.
You can't wear those to a wedding.
learner_examples: After that we have a break. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to make a connection with an earlier statement
dictionary_examples: My usual train was cancelled. That's why I'm so late.
She tricked him, and that's what really upset him.
learner_examples: I decided [not to] play football any more! That is why I want to sell them. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used instead of 'who' or 'which' at the beginning of a relative clause
dictionary_examples: Have you eaten all the cake that I made yesterday?
learner_examples: I like my old-fashioned blue jeans, [and] the old shoes that I always use. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used for saying that other similar things are included or that the whole of a situation is considered
dictionary_examples: He told us about his school and all that.
We decided to stay in bed, with it being a holiday and all that.
learner_examples: I really enjoy shopping for clothes, but not only for clothes, also for things like earrings and all that! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has ended
dictionary_examples: Well that's it then, we've finished.
I think that's it for now - I'll email you about the other project next week.
learner_examples: Well, that's it. Good luck and have a good time. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is correct
dictionary_examples: You need to push the two pieces together. That's it.

pos_items.definition: used to express a reaction to something
dictionary_examples: I didn't know she'd been so ill. That's terrible.
Turn the engine on, then put the car in gear. That's right.
Smile for the camera. That's more like it.

pos_items.definition: used to refer to events or experiences in the past
dictionary_examples: That was before we had a car.
learner_examples: That was when I went to live in Barcelona by myself in a student residence. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has happened or a decision has been made and there is nothing more to say or do

pos_items.definition: If something happens now and then, it happens sometimes but not very often.
dictionary_examples: I love chocolate, but I only eat it now and then.
learner_examples: If you really love to have a snack now and then, try to eat fruit and vegetables, instead of sweets. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: We still meet up every now and then.
learner_examples: Each day choose 10 new words and learn them by heart. In a week you will have learned 70 new words, and in a year 3640, a lot of words. Please, do not forget to repeat them every now and then. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: at that time
dictionary_examples: I was working in the city then.
I'm having a day off on Friday - I could meet you then.
Give it to me next week - I won't have time to read it before/until then.
I'll phone you tomorrow - I should have the details by then.
I saw her at Annie's but I haven't seen her since then.
learner_examples: See you then. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Panjabi)

pos_items.definition: next, or after something has happened
dictionary_examples: She trained as a teacher and then became a lawyer.
Let me finish this job, then we'll go.
learner_examples: I finish work at 7 o'clock, and then I want to have a bath. [A]fter that I will come. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: so or because of that
dictionary_examples: Have a rest now, then you won't be so tired this evening.
"My interview's at 9 o'clock." "You'll be catching an early train, then?"
learner_examples: You can read the text from a song on [screen] and then you can sing the song. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used in order to add something to what you have just said
dictionary_examples: I've got two essays to write and then my science project to finish.
This is the standard model, then there's the luxury version which costs more.

pos_items.definition: If something happens now and then, it happens sometimes but not very often.
dictionary_examples: I love chocolate, but I only eat it now and then.
learner_examples: If you really love to have a snack now and then, try to eat fruit and vegetables, instead of sweets. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: We still meet up every now and then.
learner_examples: Each day choose 10 new words and learn them by heart. In a week you will have learned 70 new words, and in a year 3640, a lot of words. Please, do not forget to repeat them every now and then. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that something exists or happens
dictionary_examples: There are three pubs in the village.
There's not much room in the back of the car.
There have been a lot of accidents on this road.
Is there any milk?
learner_examples: There are three swim[m]ing pools inside, for different people. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in or at a particular place
dictionary_examples: We live in York because my wife works there.
I went to the party but I didn't know anyone there.
We'll never get there in time!
The museum is closed today. We'll go there tomorrow.
There's that book you were looking for.
learner_examples: I will be there at 7 o'clo[c]k tomorrow. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: used when you are pointing or looking at something in order to make someone look in the same direction
dictionary_examples: Put them in that box there.
Your bag's over there by the door.

pos_items.definition: used when you are giving someone something
dictionary_examples: There's some money for your cinema ticket.
"Could I have a pencil?" "Yes. There you are."

pos_items.definition: at a particular point in a process or activity
dictionary_examples: Do you want to play another game or do you want to stop there?
I'll have to stop you there, we've run out of time.
Keep on trying - you'll get there in the end.
learner_examples: My misfortunes don't stop there. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in several different places but without any pattern
dictionary_examples: Tall trees were growing here and there.
learner_examples: In the cinemas there were a few broken seats here and there. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to show that something exists or happens
dictionary_examples: There are three pubs in the village.
There's not much room in the back of the car.
There have been a lot of accidents on this road.
Is there any milk?
learner_examples: There are three swim[m]ing pools inside, for different people. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

learner_examples: I will be there at 7 o'clo[c]k tomorrow. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

dictionary_examples: Put them in that box there.
Your bag's over there by the door.

pos_items.definition: used when you are giving someone something
dictionary_examples: There's some money for your cinema ticket.
"Could I have a pencil?" "Yes. There you are."

pos_items.definition: at a particular point in a process or activity
dictionary_examples: Do you want to play another game or do you want to stop there?
I'll have to stop you there, we've run out of time.
Keep on trying - you'll get there in the end.
learner_examples: My misfortunes don't stop there. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in several different places but without any pattern
dictionary_examples: Tall trees were growing here and there.
learner_examples: In the cinemas there were a few broken seats here and there. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: on this day
dictionary_examples: What's the date today?
It's Annabelle's birthday today.
He's going to ring you at some point today.
learner_examples: If you ring me today, I can [make] some cake. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in the period of time that is happening now
dictionary_examples: Today, people are much more concerned about their health than they were in the past.
learner_examples: Today we cannot go to a place without se[e]ing a computer. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: this day
dictionary_examples: Today is even hotter than yesterday!
Is that today's paper?
learner_examples: Today is my birthday. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: the period of time that is happening now
dictionary_examples: With today's technology almost anything seems possible.
learner_examples: However, technology has made immense steps forward and the cars of today come close to perfection. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: on the day after today
dictionary_examples: I'll call you tomorrow.
I've arranged to see Rachel tomorrow night.
Oh, leave it till tomorrow.
learner_examples: Tomorrow I must work in the shop, but in the evening I've got time and can com[e] to you at 7 o'clock. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German)

pos_items.definition: the day after today
dictionary_examples: Is John coming to tomorrow's meeting?
Tomorrow is Friday.
learner_examples: Tomorrow is [the] Chinese new year. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: the future
dictionary_examples: the children of tomorrow
learner_examples: In fact, young children are our future and what tomorrow's world will be depends a lot on what kind of adults our children will be. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: during the night of the present day
dictionary_examples: I hope you sleep well tonight.
Tonight there's going to be a party.
learner_examples: I think I left my mobile phone in your house last night. It's very important for me because I have to call my father tonight. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the night of the present day
dictionary_examples: Tonight will be my first opportunity to meet her.
Tonight's meeting will take place in the main school hall.

pos_items.definition: used before adjectives and adverbs to mean 'more than is allowed, necessary, possible, etc.'
dictionary_examples: Do you think this jacket is too big for me?
There are too many cars on the roads these days.
We enjoyed the film but it was much too long.
There were far too many people for such a small room.
learner_examples: [Maths] is too hard for me sometimes. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: also
dictionary_examples: Do you know Jason too?
I'll probably go there next year too.
I'd like to come too.
"I love chocolate." "Me too."
learner_examples: Do you like it, too? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German)

pos_items.definition: used before adjectives and adverbs to mean 'not very'
dictionary_examples: "How was your exam?" "Not too bad, I suppose."
I didn't play too well today.
He wasn't too happy when I told him about the mistake.
learner_examples: How are you? [I'm] not too bad. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you are sorry about a situation
dictionary_examples: "He didn't get the job." "Oh, that's too bad."
learner_examples: Too bad you couldn't come to my party. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the quantity, quality or amount of something
dictionary_examples: The house is so beautiful.
Don't be so stupid!
I didn't know she had so many children!
Thank you so much for all your help.
I've never seen so many people in one place before!
I'm so tired (that) I could sleep in this chair!
learner_examples: Thank you so much for [your] help! (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something that has just been mentioned, especially to give a short answer to a question
dictionary_examples: "I hope they stay together." "I hope so too."
"Do you think he's upset?" "I don't think so."
James is coming tonight, or so he said.
learner_examples: Do you like this colour? I hope so. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used after a list of things to show that you could have added other similar things
dictionary_examples: She plays a lot of tennis and squash and so on.
learner_examples: I like watching television, playing [on] the computer, reading book[s] and so on. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.sense_title: so did we/so have I/so is mine, etc.
pos_items.definition: used to say that someone else also does something or that the same thing is true about someone or something else
dictionary_examples: "We saw the new Star Trek movie last night." "Oh, so did we."
learner_examples: My eyes went watery and so did hers but then we laughed at each other. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: until now
dictionary_examples: So far we've made thirty-two thousand pounds.
learner_examples: So far I like it here very much. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian)

pos_items.definition: approximately
dictionary_examples: "How many people were at the party?" "Fifty or so, I guess."
learner_examples: After an hour or so they changed the flight and new people came, the he realised that his suitcase was lost. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: if this is the case
dictionary_examples: It might rain this afternoon. If so, we'll have to have the party indoors.
learner_examples: Will you be in time for dinner? If so, I'll cook your favourite dish. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in order to
dictionary_examples: I always keep fruit in the fridge so as to keep insects off it.
learner_examples: I could come on 8th July so as to be there on Tim's birthday. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: if you do this, or if this is done
dictionary_examples: They want to build a completely new school, but to do so would cost far too much.
I would strongly advise you against taking out a loan of this size. To do so would be a great risk to your business.
learner_examples: It is generally believed that if [a] better education is provided, children are better prepared for adult life. To do so, money is essential. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something surprising is true despite what you have just said
dictionary_examples: Car prices have gone down a lot, but even so, we couldn't afford to buy one.
learner_examples: I'm sure many of [these things] happened due to bad luck, but even so, there are some arrangements that, I bel[ie]ve, can easily be improved. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has not been useful or successful
dictionary_examples: "The computer's crashed again." "So much for modern technology."
learner_examples: So much for turkey, crackling and mince pies - we ended up having a Christmas party of our own at Pizza Hut! (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to say that there are limits to something
dictionary_examples: There's only so much help you can give someone.
learner_examples: The effects of a longer life span have many side ef[f]ects such as an increase in the world's population and, since there is only so much food, m[any] more people are st[ar]ving to death. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: so as not to do sth
pos_items.definition: used for saying what the purpose of an action is
dictionary_examples: He went in very quietly so as not to wake the baby.
learner_examples: Secondly, I think we should plan some other kind of activities in case of bad weather and we should have more than one bus with us so as not to waste time in case it breaks down. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you were right and that someone should have believed you
dictionary_examples: He's lazy? I told you so, didn't I?
learner_examples: See, I told you so", Azman said with a grin. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: He went into town every so often to buy supplies.
learner_examples: Elizabeth and others visited her every so often until [one] day she left them. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has gone well until now
dictionary_examples: It's the first time I've done any decorating, but so far so good.
learner_examples: So far so good, only no one told us they held this point of view before the actual christening took place. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to explain that the words you are using do not have their usual meaning
dictionary_examples: That was our accommodation, so to speak.
learner_examples: In those cases, travelling turns into a sort of alienation, so to speak. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is the reason why something else happens
dictionary_examples: I was tired so I went to bed.
Greg had some money so he bought a bike.
My knee started hurting so I stopped running.
I was lost so I bought a street map.
learner_examples: I'm going to change my school, so I have to sell all my books. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to connect it with something that was said or happened previously
dictionary_examples: So, there I was standing at the edge of the road with only my underwear on ...
So, just to finish what I was saying earlier...
So, who do you think is going to win the election?
So, here we are again - just you and me.
So that's what he does when I'm not around!
So we leave on the Thursday and get back the next Tuesday, is that right?
learner_examples: I remember you said that you want to help me. So, can you buy the items for me and then I pay you? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in order to make something happen or be possible
dictionary_examples: He put his glasses on so that he could see the television better.
I deliberately didn't have lunch so (that) I would be hungry tonight.
Leave the keys out so (that) I remember to take them with me.
learner_examples: Could you please give me some extra exercises so that I can cover the work I missed? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a place when you do not know exactly where it is or when it is not important exactly where it is
dictionary_examples: He was last heard of living somewhere on the south coast.
You must have put their letter somewhere!
I'm looking for somewhere to eat/stay.
Can we go somewhere else to talk - it's very noisy here.
Wouldn't you like to go to Disneyland or somewhere?
learner_examples: And I think we should go somewhere else to have a drink after the film. (Key English Test; A2; Vietnamese)

pos_items.definition: approximately
dictionary_examples: Somewhere between 900 and 1100 minor crimes are reported in this city every week.
It will take us somewhere between three and four hours to get to Madrid.
The company's annual turnover is somewhere around £70.7 million.
learner_examples: The gathering will take place somewhere betwe[e]n the first and second week of the month, so you can come somewhere around then. (First Certificate in English; B2; Serbian)

pos_items.definition: used for saying goodbye to someone you are going to meet again soon
dictionary_examples: I'll see you soon!
learner_examples: See you soon. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: after a short period of time
dictionary_examples: She'll soon be here./She'll be here soon.
The sooner we leave, the sooner we'll get there.
Soon after agreeing to go, she realized she'd made a mistake.
How soon can we sign the contract?
I couldn't get out of that place soon enough.
learner_examples: Please tell me soon. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If you do something as soon as possible, you do it as quickly as you can
dictionary_examples: We need the repairs done as soon as possible.
learner_examples: Please call me as soon as possible! (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: at the same time or a very short time after
dictionary_examples: As soon as I saw her, I knew there was something wrong.
learner_examples: As soon as the rain stopped, I called my friend and we all continued walking in the park, and we all enjoyed ourselves. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you do not know exactly when something will happen, but you are certain that it will happen
dictionary_examples: Sooner or later she's going to realize what a mistake she's made.
learner_examples: Anyway I think that sooner or later you will have problems with your heart or stomach. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show that something happens immediately after something else
dictionary_examples: No sooner had we got home than the phone rang.
learner_examples: No sooner had I entered a pub than the waitress smiled warmly at me. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: would prefer
dictionary_examples: I'd sooner spend a bit more money than take chances with safety.
learner_examples: However, with many living examples of unemploye[d] [people] getting by on benefits, some young people have been influenced to think that they would sooner live on benefits than work all week and receive moderate wages. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: the direction which goes towards the part of the Earth below the equator, opposite to the north, or the part of an area or country which is in this direction
dictionary_examples: The points of the compass are North, South, East and West.
The best beaches are in the south (of the island).
We usually spend our holidays in the South of France.
Canberra is/lies to the south of Sydney.
learner_examples: I am in Toulon, in the south of France. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: the part of an area that is further towards the south than the rest
dictionary_examples: We live in the south of the city.
learner_examples: The best place in Poland to spend [a] holiday is the south of the country. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in or forming the south part of something
dictionary_examples: South Africa
the South China Sea
These plants grow well on a south-facing wall.
learner_examples: I'm in South Africa, it is a beautiful place to have [a] holiday. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: towards the south
dictionary_examples: The Mississippi river flows south.
They drove south towards the coast.
learner_examples: There is a large window facing south so that it's bright and warm. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is continuing to happen now or that someone is continuing to do something now
dictionary_examples: I'm still hungry.
I still haven't finished my essay.
There is still no news about the hostages.
Do you still work for the government?
There's still time for us to get to the cinema before the film starts.
learner_examples: So, I think my bag [is] still in my room. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: despite that
dictionary_examples: You may not approve of what he did, but he's still your brother.
I know you don't like her, but you still don't have to be so rude to her.
Even though she hasn't really got the time, she still offered to help.
learner_examples: I was sure that it was not in my house but I still wanted to check. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: even better/worse
dictionary_examples: I'll meet you at the theatre. No, better still, let's meet in a pub and have a drink first.
I'm worried that his car has broken down, or worse still, that he's had an accident.
learner_examples: To my mind, the best place to do the painting is my bedroom, because you'll have plenty of space to work, and, better still, we won't bother anybody. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: A still drink does not have any bubbles in it.
dictionary_examples: Would you like still or sparkling water?
learner_examples: The still water is the best but don't drink it too cold because you[r] stomach [will] not like it. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: not moving
dictionary_examples: Children find it difficult to sit/stand/stay still for very long.
I can't brush your hair if you don't keep/hold still.
learner_examples: I'd like to have my dog painted, too, but I'm afraid that'll be impossible because it won't stay still! (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: Still water or air does not have waves or wind.
dictionary_examples: She dived into the still water of the lake.
The air was so still that not even the leaves on the trees were moving.
learner_examples: At the foot of the monastery's ruins was a pool, wide and still, and smooth in the sunlight, surrounded by flowers and tall trees, wonderfully bloomed. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: not curved or bent
dictionary_examples: a straight line
She's got straight blonde hair.
learner_examples: She has straight [blond] hair and blue eyes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: honest
dictionary_examples: a straight answer
learner_examples: I'm asking you to give us a reasonable and straight reply. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a position that is level or vertical
dictionary_examples: That shelf's not straight.

pos_items.definition: to make sure that you completely understand a situation
dictionary_examples: Let me get this straight - am I paying for this?
learner_examples: Next time you should try to get your facts straight. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to tell people the true facts about a situation
dictionary_examples: I know they thought Alex was lying, and I wanted to put the record straight.
learner_examples: I hope that my letter will set the record straight and that the public shall be informed about the true events of that day. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: to manage to stop yourself from smiling or laughing
dictionary_examples: I can never play jokes on people because I can't keep a straight face.

pos_items.definition: in a straight line
dictionary_examples: Go straight on (along this road) and turn left at the traffic lights.
He was looking straight at me.
Can't you see it? - it's straight ahead (of you)!
learner_examples: Go straight on until you see the castle. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: without pausing or delaying
dictionary_examples: I got home and went straight to bed.
Shall we go straight to the party or stop off at a pub first?
learner_examples: When I came back home at 11.30, I went straight to bed. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: I knew straight away what you were thinking.
We don't need to go straight away - we can stay for a little while.
learner_examples: We met on Tuesday for the first time and went skating straight away, without even discussing where we were going. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: to sit or stand with your body vertical
dictionary_examples: Stand up straight and put your shoulders back!
learner_examples: She tried to sit up straight and quickly realised all her mus[c]les were stiff from non activity. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: to say what you want to immediately and directly
dictionary_examples: I'll come straight to the point, we've run out of money.
Can you get straight to the point? We need to go home!
learner_examples: I will come straight to the point, Mark. I think you're just killing yourself with your work. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If you cannot think straight, you are not thinking clearly about something.
dictionary_examples: I was so tired, I couldn't think straight.
learner_examples: My stress wouldn't let me think straight. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: at that time
dictionary_examples: I was working in the city then.
I'm having a day off on Friday - I could meet you then.
Give it to me next week - I won't have time to read it before/until then.
I'll phone you tomorrow - I should have the details by then.
I saw her at Annie's but I haven't seen her since then.
learner_examples: See you then. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Panjabi)

pos_items.definition: next, or after something has happened
dictionary_examples: She trained as a teacher and then became a lawyer.
Let me finish this job, then we'll go.
learner_examples: I finish work at 7 o'clock, and then I want to have a bath. [A]fter that I will come. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: so or because of that
dictionary_examples: Have a rest now, then you won't be so tired this evening.
"My interview's at 9 o'clock." "You'll be catching an early train, then?"
learner_examples: You can read the text from a song on [screen] and then you can sing the song. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

dictionary_examples: I've got two essays to write and then my science project to finish.
This is the standard model, then there's the luxury version which costs more.

learner_examples: If you really love to have a snack now and then, try to eat fruit and vegetables, instead of sweets. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in a way or by some means which is not known or not stated
dictionary_examples: It won't be easy, but we'll get across the river somehow.
Somehow or other, we'll get the money.
learner_examples: I don't know exactly what happened but somehow I managed not to fall in [the lake]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: for a reason which is not clear
dictionary_examples: I know what we're doing is legal, but somehow it doesn't feel right.
learner_examples: I did not know who was talking to me but somehow I knew that it must be an urgent matter. Why else [w]ould a stranger wake me in the middle of the night? (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is continuing to happen now or that someone is continuing to do something now
dictionary_examples: I'm still hungry.
I still haven't finished my essay.
There is still no news about the hostages.
Do you still work for the government?
There's still time for us to get to the cinema before the film starts.
learner_examples: So, I think my bag [is] still in my room. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: despite that
dictionary_examples: You may not approve of what he did, but he's still your brother.
I know you don't like her, but you still don't have to be so rude to her.
Even though she hasn't really got the time, she still offered to help.
learner_examples: I was sure that it was not in my house but I still wanted to check. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: even better/worse
dictionary_examples: I'll meet you at the theatre. No, better still, let's meet in a pub and have a drink first.

learner_examples: To my mind, the best place to do the painting is my bedroom, because you'll have plenty of space to work, and, better still, we won't bother anybody. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: A still drink does not have any bubbles in it.
dictionary_examples: Would you like still or sparkling water?
learner_examples: The still water is the best but don't drink it too cold because you[r] stomach [will] not like it. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: not moving
dictionary_examples: Children find it difficult to sit/stand/stay still for very long.
I can't brush your hair if you don't keep/hold still.
learner_examples: I'd like to have my dog painted, too, but I'm afraid that'll be impossible because it won't stay still! (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: Still water or air does not have waves or wind.
dictionary_examples: She dived into the still water of the lake.
The air was so still that not even the leaves on the trees were moving.
learner_examples: At the foot of the monastery's ruins was a pool, wide and still, and smooth in the sunlight, surrounded by flowers and tall trees, wonderfully bloomed. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: not curved or bent
dictionary_examples: a straight line

learner_examples: She has straight [blond] hair and blue eyes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: honest
dictionary_examples: a straight answer
learner_examples: I'm asking you to give us a reasonable and straight reply. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in a position that is level or vertical
dictionary_examples: That shelf's not straight.

pos_items.definition: to make sure that you completely understand a situation
dictionary_examples: Let me get this straight - am I paying for this?

pos_items.definition: to tell people the true facts about a situation
dictionary_examples: I know they thought Alex was lying, and I wanted to put the record straight.

pos_items.definition: to manage to stop yourself from smiling or laughing
dictionary_examples: I can never play jokes on people because I can't keep a straight face.

pos_items.definition: in a straight line
dictionary_examples: Go straight on (along this road) and turn left at the traffic lights.

Can't you see it? - it's straight ahead (of you)!
learner_examples: Go straight on until you see the castle. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: without pausing or delaying

pos_items.definition: immediately

pos_items.definition: to sit or stand with your body vertical

pos_items.definition: to say what you want to immediately and directly

pos_items.definition: If you cannot think straight, you are not thinking clearly about something.

pos_items.definition: with each other or doing something with each other

pos_items.definition: at the same time

pos_items.definition: used to say that two or more things are joined to each other, mixed with each other, etc.

I like both flavours separately but I don't like them together.

pos_items.definition: in one place
dictionary_examples: I'll just gather my things together and then we can go.

pos_items.definition: combined
dictionary_examples: Together they must earn over ninety thousand dollars a year.

pos_items.definition: from a time in the past until a later time or until now

pos_items.definition: from a time in the past until a later time or until now

pos_items.definition: from a time in the past until a later time or until now

He started working for the company when he left school, and has been there ever since.
I've long since forgotten any Latin I ever learned.
learner_examples: It was my grandmother who introduced me to teddy bears and she wanted me to love them as she did. When she died, I got all her bears and have been taking care of them ever since. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: in a way or by some means which is not known or not stated
dictionary_examples: It won't be easy, but we'll get across the river somehow.
Somehow or other, we'll get the money.

pos_items.definition: for a reason which is not clear

pos_items.definition: at the same time
dictionary_examples: Everyone seemed to arrive together.

learner_examples: He came to my house early in the morning and then we left together. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to say that two or more things are joined to each other, mixed with each other, etc.
