Could you add these figures together for me?
You mix all the dry ingredients together before you add the milk.
You could stick that back together with a bit of glue.
I like both flavours separately but I don't like them together.

pos_items.definition: in one place
dictionary_examples: I'll just gather my things together and then we can go.

pos_items.definition: combined
dictionary_examples: Together they must earn over ninety thousand dollars a year.
The money that I owe you for the telephone together with the rent equals £300.
learner_examples: When you ride a bike on the main road, it's very dangerous to breath[e] the dirty air - together with the gases from the cars. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to agree with something, or to give a positive answer
dictionary_examples: "Would you like a glass of wine?" "Yes, please."
"Do you like Thai food?" "Yes, I love it."
"He's a really nice guy." "Yes, he is."
"Report to me at nine o'clock tomorrow morning." "Yes, sir."
"Have you had enough to eat?" "Yes, thank you."
learner_examples: Yes, I can come tomorrow for dinner. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you are listening to someone, or that you are ready to listen and to give them an answer or information
dictionary_examples: "Dad." "Yes, what do you want, honey?"
"Yes, can I help you?"

pos_items.definition: used when you are disagreeing with a negative statement
dictionary_examples: "I'm not a very good cook, though." "Yes, you are - you make wonderful food!"

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that something is true
dictionary_examples: Stress has undoubtedly contributed to her illness.
learner_examples: This trip will undoubtedly be a wonderful experience. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a way or at a time that is not expected
dictionary_examples: Retail sales unexpectedly fell last month.
He called in quite unexpectedly last week.
learner_examples: He called me really unexpectedly at work, and told me to go [to] his office at once. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not fair
dictionary_examples: I thought the prices were unreasonably high.
He acted unreasonably.
learner_examples: Informing students and residents about the means of transport and reducing the unreasonably high ticket price are the keys to incite more people use such means. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a way that shows that you do not want to do something
dictionary_examples: He unwillingly agreed to take her home.
learner_examples: What was worse, ours broke down on our way to the safari park, so we had to give it a miss unwillingly. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: almost
dictionary_examples: I've virtually finished.
Their twins are virtually identical.
That wine stain on my shirt has virtually disappeared.
learner_examples: Virtually everyone today can go out and buy their own personal computer. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that uses computer images and sounds that make you think an imagined situation is real
dictionary_examples: Nowadays all these things can be experienced virtually.
learner_examples: I also have the possibility of making new friends: I can connect to a special site which will enable me to [meet people] virtually. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in a way that involves violence
dictionary_examples: He often behaved violently and they were terrified of him.

learner_examples: Sometimes they behave violently because of their [imprison]ment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that keeps you warm
dictionary_examples: You're not dressed warmly enough - put a sweater on.

pos_items.definition: in a friendly or loving way
dictionary_examples: He shook my hand warmly.
learner_examples: He embraced me warmly and whispered 'You wouldn't have believed me.' (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in a willing way
dictionary_examples: He would willingly risk his life for her.
I would willingly help you if I weren't going away tomorrow.
learner_examples: Of course, I'll willingly help you, even though I'm going to stay there only for a couple of weeks. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

Think about it very carefully before deciding.
learner_examples: My teacher is very nice. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: not good, tall, happy, etc.
dictionary_examples: The film wasn't very good.
He doesn't sing very well.
learner_examples: My college is not very big. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to a large amount or degree
dictionary_examples: Thank you very much for the flowers!
I like her very much.
learner_examples: I like Bradford very much. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize a noun
dictionary_examples: This is the very book I've been looking for all month.

The letter was sent on Monday from Manchester and arrived in London the very same/next day.
learner_examples: You cannot infringe individual liberties and ban the purchase of cars - it would go against the very fabric of modern society. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: in a successful or satisfactory way
dictionary_examples: I thought the team played well.
He's doing very well at school.
The shop sells well-made clothes.
They took two hours to discuss the plans and considered it time well spent.
learner_examples: I play guitar very well and I love rock! (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to tell someone how pleased you are about something they have done
dictionary_examples: "I passed my exam." "Well done!"

pos_items.definition: also
dictionary_examples: Are you going to invite Steve as well?
learner_examples: Dylma goes to school every day and work[s] as well. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to
dictionary_examples: There are soft drinks as well as coffee and tea.

learner_examples: I like pop as well as country music. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a complete way or as much as possible
dictionary_examples: Stir the mixture well.
I know him quite well.
learner_examples: I live in the capital city. [...] I know it very well and it will be [a] pleasure to guide you around. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used to suggest doing something, often when there is nothing better to do
dictionary_examples: We might as well walk there.
As you already know so much about the subject, you might as well skip this lecture.
learner_examples: In my opinion, you might as well ask your neighbours if they can look after your flat for one day. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is likely to be true
dictionary_examples: She might well be the best person to ask.
He could well be at Michelle's house.
learner_examples: Laura could well imagine [that] she would stand opposite the examiners and not answer any question in the right way. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize some prepositions
dictionary_examples: The results are well above/below what we expected.
Keep well away from the edge of the cliff.
It cost well over £100.
learner_examples: The hospital received well over 80% of the profits, and that as you can see is much more than just 60%. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize some adjectives
dictionary_examples: The police are well aware of the situation.
The museum is well worth a visit.
learner_examples: Finally I would like to recommend a visit to Lampton Castle; in addition to the paintings and furniture there is now a new collection of musical instruments, which is well worth seeing. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: If you may/might as well do something, it will not spoil the situation if you do that thing.
dictionary_examples: If we're not waiting for Karen, we might as well go now.

pos_items.definition: used to say that it is lucky that something happened
dictionary_examples: It's just as well we brought an umbrella.

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is not a suitable or practical thing to do
dictionary_examples: I couldn't very well tell her while he was there.

pos_items.definition: to intend to behave in a kind way

dictionary_examples: He is undeniably the best student we have ever had.
learner_examples: Sport has undeniably become part of contemporary popular culture. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: in the way that most often happens
dictionary_examples: He usually gets home about 6 o'clock.
I usually just have a sandwich for lunch.
Is he usually so rude?
"Does this shop open on Sundays?" "Usually."
learner_examples: Hungarian people usually eat breakfast at 6 or 7 o'clock. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used for saying what usually happens
dictionary_examples: Typically, a doctor will see about thirty patients a day.
Tickets for such events will typically cost around thirty dollars.
learner_examples: The climate of Brazil is typically tropical so the weather is gorgeous. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a way that shows all the characteristics that you would expect from the stated person, thing or group
dictionary_examples: She has that reserve and slight coldness of manner which is typically English.
Paul, in typically rude fashion, told him he was talking rubbish.
learner_examples: Your wife really made an effort to cook me typically English dishes. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is urgent
dictionary_examples: Help is urgently needed.
learner_examples: I have e-mailed you to tell you that I need your bicycle urgently. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Nepali)

pos_items.definition: used for saying what usually happens
dictionary_examples: Typically, a doctor will see about thirty patients a day.
Tickets for such events will typically cost around thirty dollars.
learner_examples: The climate of Brazil is typically tropical so the weather is gorgeous. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a way that shows all the characteristics that you would expect from the stated person, thing or group
dictionary_examples: She has that reserve and slight coldness of manner which is typically English.
Paul, in typically rude fashion, told him he was talking rubbish.
learner_examples: Your wife really made an effort to cook me typically English dishes. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in a vivid way
dictionary_examples: I vividly remember my first day at school.
learner_examples: She could vividly remember the last time he hurt her, only then it was with a razor. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that keeps you warm
dictionary_examples: You're not dressed warmly enough - put a sweater on.

pos_items.definition: in a friendly or loving way
dictionary_examples: He shook my hand warmly.
learner_examples: He embraced me warmly and whispered 'You wouldn't have believed me.' (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: including a lot of different places, people, subjects, etc.
dictionary_examples: They have both travelled widely.
English is widely spoken around the world.
His work is widely known/accepted.
learner_examples: It is widely known that the Japanes[e] and Chines[e] people are often very healthy. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to be very different
dictionary_examples: Prices vary widely from shop to shop.
learner_examples: People's opinions on the protection of the environment differ widely. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: in a very energetic way and without control
dictionary_examples: He was dancing wildly.
They cheered wildly.
learner_examples: When I arrived at the party, I knew immediately that something was wrong ... people were sleeping on the floor, the house furniture was all torn apart, [and] people with beverages were dancing wildly. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: extremely
dictionary_examples: I must say I'm not wildly keen on the idea.
The product has been wildly successful.
learner_examples: Funding field trips would mean increased resources for our wildly successful guest appearances, as well as the budget needed to foster our skilled debaters. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: not correctly
dictionary_examples: It has been said - wrongly - that Americans hate government.
learner_examples: Equally, the point about 'staying' is erroneous: we stayed at Riverside Hotel instead of Hotel Astrid, [which] closed last year, [and] Hotel Royal [was] wrongly [described as having] 'special rates' for students. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: accused or punished unfairly or illegally
dictionary_examples: She was wrongly convicted of drug smuggling.
learner_examples: You have also wrongly accused the organisers of spending too much money on organising the event. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: finally, after a series of things have happened
dictionary_examples: Everything will ultimately depend on what is said at the meeting with the directors next week.
Ultimately, of course, he'd like to have his own business but that won't be for some time.
learner_examples: Ultimately, it leads to a lot of d[i]seases and early death. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the most important fact in a situation
dictionary_examples: Ultimately, he'll have to decide.
learner_examples: Ultimately, that is why we are influenced by other people's personalities. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is expected in a particular situation
dictionary_examples: She's understandably upset.
learner_examples: Furthermore, the use of the computer system caused long waiting times because everyone wanted - understandably - to find out more about suitable working opportunities. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: in a way that involves everyone in the world, or everyone in a particular group
dictionary_examples: She is universally adored.
Water is one of the most common and universally known substances.
learner_examples: Furthermore fame can [give] people the feeling that they are universally loved. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: completely
dictionary_examples: It's utterly ridiculous.
learner_examples: The information provided in your report about the final goal was utterly wrong. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a wise way
dictionary_examples: She wisely advised me to wait.
learner_examples: In my opinion, computer learning offers very interesting opportunities, especially to learn new languages, but such a powerful medium as the computer should be used wisely. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: finally, after a series of things have happened
dictionary_examples: Everything will ultimately depend on what is said at the meeting with the directors next week.
Ultimately, of course, he'd like to have his own business but that won't be for some time.
learner_examples: Ultimately, it leads to a lot of d[i]seases and early death. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the most important fact in a situation
dictionary_examples: Ultimately, he'll have to decide.
learner_examples: Ultimately, that is why we are influenced by other people's personalities. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: with agreement from everyone
dictionary_examples: We agreed unanimously that he was the best candidate.
learner_examples: While it is true that there are quite a few opposing theories about losing weight, doctors unanimously agree that a hedonistic approach to eating can lead to unpleasant health issues like obesity. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not clear or certain
dictionary_examples: I vaguely remember meeting him at Lionel's house.
learner_examples: I can vaguely remember the decor, and if I tried harder maybe I could remember the taste of the ice-cream. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a way that can be seen
dictionary_examples: He was visibly upset.
learner_examples: However, it is my firm conviction that if the authority reconsiders some of its regulations and take urgent steps, [the number of] unemployed people will be visibly reduced. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a very important way
dictionary_examples: Safety at work is vitally important.
learner_examples: Being able to use the computer and the Internet successfully is vitally important in today's society but it will be even more important in the future. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: If you do something voluntarily, nobody has forced you to do it.
dictionary_examples: She left voluntarily.
learner_examples: After he had himself discharged voluntarily from the hospital, he drove up to the cliff, [and] left his car there. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in a completely enthusiastic way
dictionary_examples: I agreed wholeheartedly with what she said.
learner_examples: First of all, I have to say that I agree with you wholeheartedly. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: completely
dictionary_examples: His behaviour is wholly unacceptable.
learner_examples: As far as money is concerned, I think that people who only care about earning lots of money do not wholly understand the question. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: in a very energetic way and without control
dictionary_examples: He was dancing wildly.
They cheered wildly.
learner_examples: When I arrived at the party, I knew immediately that something was wrong ... people were sleeping on the floor, the house furniture was all torn apart, [and] people with beverages were dancing wildly. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: extremely
dictionary_examples: I must say I'm not wildly keen on the idea.
The product has been wildly successful.
learner_examples: Funding field trips would mean increased resources for our wildly successful guest appearances, as well as the budget needed to foster our skilled debaters. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: vertical or as straight as possible
dictionary_examples: He stood up.
She opened her eyes and sat up.
learner_examples: [The whole] class stood up and sang "Imagine". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: towards or in a higher place or position
dictionary_examples: She looked up and smiled at me.
This road goes up into the Andes.
The water was up to the level of the windows.
learner_examples: As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name. I looked up and I saw my friend on the other side of the concert [hall]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: to walk directly towards someone or something until you are next to them
dictionary_examples: He came straight up to me and introduced himself.
learner_examples: She came up to him to help him with the luggage. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay)

pos_items.definition: not in bed
dictionary_examples: I stayed up all night finishing this report.
learner_examples: That night we were up until late talking and after a couple of days she left. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: If an action or decision is up to someone, they are responsible for doing or making it.
dictionary_examples: I can't decide for you, Jack, it's up to you.
It's up to Sophie to decide whether she wants to enter the competition.
learner_examples: This is my opinion but it's up to you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to be doing or planning something
dictionary_examples: What are you up to at the moment?
They're up to something - I can tell.
learner_examples: What have you been up to? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: to a greater degree, amount, volume, etc.
dictionary_examples: Please speak up, I can't hear you.
The fire heats the room up within minutes.
The cost of car insurance is up, but not very much.
learner_examples: Moreover the microphone suddenly wouldn't work anymore, and even though I desperately tried to speak up, people began to lose interest in both my speech and me and simply started to talk to each other instead. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that an action or process is complete
dictionary_examples: Come on, Maria, drink up your lemonade.
By the time we left, she had bought up half of the shop.
learner_examples: Anna, I broke one of your beautiful vase[s] accidentally when I was trying to clean up the house one evening. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: rising and falling
dictionary_examples: They were jumping up and down with impatience.
learner_examples: Well, you should be bouncing up and down with joy (just kidding)! (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to be of bad quality
dictionary_examples: Her latest novel isn't up to much.
learner_examples: But above all, she had this extraordinary dining table, w[h]ich didn't look up to much when you first walked in the room, but as you lifted the three layers of tablecloths protecting a huge piece of glass, you discovered an amazing display of objects from Alabama. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to or in a higher place or position
dictionary_examples: He ran up the steps.
We followed her up the stairs to a large meeting room.
learner_examples: We r[o]de up the mountain [on] our b[i]kes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: along or further along the street/road, etc.
dictionary_examples: They live just up the road.
learner_examples: Go up the street and turn left on the square. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: any amount or number under 10, 20, etc.
dictionary_examples: We can invite up to 65 people.
learner_examples: A wedding can cost up to 10,000 SFr. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: until a particular time
dictionary_examples: You can call me up until midnight.
learner_examples: The party will be in my house up to 1:00 a.m., then we will go to Jean's house. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: from one end to the other and back again
dictionary_examples: They were running up and down the corridors.
learner_examples: Almost a thousand people [were] running up and down the ballroom shouting in panic: "Who's got matches?" "Turn the lights on!" (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: having all the most recent information about a subject or activity
dictionary_examples: The course should bring you up to speed with the latest techniques.
learner_examples: Apart [from] this you can keep yourself up to speed with what's happening around the world on various fronts. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: in a successful or satisfactory way
dictionary_examples: I thought the team played well.
He's doing very well at school.
The shop sells well-made clothes.
They took two hours to discuss the plans and considered it time well spent.
learner_examples: I play guitar very well and I love rock! (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to tell someone how pleased you are about something they have done
dictionary_examples: "I passed my exam." "Well done!"

pos_items.definition: also
dictionary_examples: Are you going to invite Steve as well?
learner_examples: Dylma goes to school every day and work[s] as well. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to
dictionary_examples: There are soft drinks as well as coffee and tea.
They have lived in the United States as well as Britain.
learner_examples: I like pop as well as country music. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a complete way or as much as possible
dictionary_examples: Stir the mixture well.
I know him quite well.
learner_examples: I live in the capital city. [...] I know it very well and it will be [a] pleasure to guide you around. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used to suggest doing something, often when there is nothing better to do
dictionary_examples: We might as well walk there.
As you already know so much about the subject, you might as well skip this lecture.
learner_examples: In my opinion, you might as well ask your neighbours if they can look after your flat for one day. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is likely to be true
dictionary_examples: She might well be the best person to ask.
He could well be at Michelle's house.
learner_examples: Laura could well imagine [that] she would stand opposite the examiners and not answer any question in the right way. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize some prepositions
dictionary_examples: The results are well above/below what we expected.
Keep well away from the edge of the cliff.
It cost well over £100.
learner_examples: The hospital received well over 80% of the profits, and that as you can see is much more than just 60%. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize some adjectives
dictionary_examples: The police are well aware of the situation.
The museum is well worth a visit.
learner_examples: Finally I would like to recommend a visit to Lampton Castle; in addition to the paintings and furniture there is now a new collection of musical instruments, which is well worth seeing. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: If you may/might as well do something, it will not spoil the situation if you do that thing.
dictionary_examples: If we're not waiting for Karen, we might as well go now.
learner_examples: I might as well go with her and if you like, you can join us too. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that it is lucky that something happened
dictionary_examples: It's just as well we brought an umbrella.
learner_examples: It is just as well that my friends had cars to give me a lift to the school. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is not a suitable or practical thing to do
dictionary_examples: I couldn't very well tell her while he was there.
learner_examples: I couldn't very well tell her that without my diaries, I'd be lost and not know who I was. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to intend to behave in a kind way
dictionary_examples: I know my parents mean well, but I wish they wouldn't interfere.
learner_examples: Although these fans might mean well, in many cases they do not appear to realise that their 'heroes' perhaps would like to be left alone. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: healthy; not ill
dictionary_examples: You look well! - Thanks, I feel well.
He hasn't been too well lately.
When she came home from school she really didn't look well.
I'm sorry you're ill - I hope you get well soon.
learner_examples: How are you? I'm very well. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali)

pos_items.definition: everything is in a good or acceptable state
dictionary_examples: I hope all is well with Jack.
learner_examples: I hope all's well. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say that it is lucky that something happened
dictionary_examples: It's just as well we brought an umbrella.
learner_examples: It is just as well that my friends had cars to give me a lift to the school. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you do not agree with something or that you are annoyed about something
dictionary_examples: It's all very well for her to say everything's fine, she doesn't have to live here.
learner_examples: That's all very well for most of the people but according to my desires [i]t's not enough. I envisage a more sophisticated flat. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to pause slightly or to express doubt or disagreement
dictionary_examples: You'll go, won't you? - Well, I'm not sure.
Well, what shall we do now?
Who was that? - Well, I'm afraid I can't remember her name.
Well, after that we went camping in the mountains.
learner_examples: Well, my friend, I have just seen this film but I can see it again. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that a situation cannot be changed although it might be disappointing
dictionary_examples: Oh well, it doesn't matter, I can always buy another one.
learner_examples: I always dreamed [of going] sailing, but not even a little boat [is] left, some other people [have] already booked them! Oh well. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to ask at what time something happened or will happen
dictionary_examples: "I did tell you about it." "When? I don't remember."
When's your birthday?
When did he leave?
learner_examples: When are you coming [to] my house? (Key English Test; A2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used to say at what time something happened or will happen
dictionary_examples: I found it when I was cleaning out the cupboards.
We'll go when you're ready.
She was only twenty when she had her first baby.
He was quite shocked when I told him.
learner_examples: I'll ring you when I arrive. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say something that is surprising after what has already been said
dictionary_examples: He says he hasn't got any money when in fact he's got thousands of dollars in his account.
I don't understand how he can say that everything's fine when it's so obvious that it's not.
Why is she training to be a teacher when she doesn't even like children?
How can you say you don't like something when you've never even tried it!
learner_examples: In your advertisement it was said that I would find stars and artists from around the world, when, in fact, they were from only six countries. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: when it comes to sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: used to introduce a new idea that you want to say something about
dictionary_examples: When it comes to baking cakes, she's an expert.
learner_examples: But when it comes to computers, they just impose some knowledge on students, without any interaction. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to ask about the place or position of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Where does he live?
Where are my car keys?
"I put them on your desk." "Where? I can't see them."
Where did you put my umbrella?
learner_examples: Where is the college? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Akan)

pos_items.definition: what someone thinks about you, how they expect you to behave, and how they are likely to behave
dictionary_examples: She said she will never leave her husband, so now at least I know where I stand.

pos_items.definition: what your opinion is about something
dictionary_examples: We asked the head teacher where he stood on the wearing of jewellery in school.
learner_examples: From where I stand, some action must be taken urgently because the problems are constantly exacerbating. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: at, in or to a place or position
dictionary_examples: I've been meaning to ask you where you get your hair cut.
I like to have him next to me where I can keep an eye on him.
learner_examples: I need to know where I can study French. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used when referring to a particular stage in a process or activity
dictionary_examples: You reach a point in any project where you just want to get the thing finished.
I've reached the stage where I just don't care anymore.
learner_examples: We've come to a point where we have forgotten how to read or talk to each other. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to ask about the reason for something
dictionary_examples: "I'm going home." "Why?"
Why did you choose to live in London?
Why wait? Let's leave now.
learner_examples: Why couldn't you come? (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about the reason for something
dictionary_examples: I don't know why she isn't here.
Quite why he isn't here today is a mystery.
There is no reason why we shouldn't succeed.
learner_examples: Also, you didn't say why the photography and painting courses were so popular. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.sense_title: why don't you?/ why not do sth?
pos_items.definition: used to make a suggestion
dictionary_examples: Why don't you come with us?
Why not give it a try?
learner_examples: Why don't we play tennis? (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to agree with something that someone has suggested
dictionary_examples: "Let's have an ice cream." "Yes, why not?"
learner_examples: She said, I have two tickets for a new film [with] Tom Cruise - would you like to come with me? Well I said why not, so I went with her to see this film. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: on the day before today
dictionary_examples: He rang yesterday while you were out.
I saw her yesterday morning/afternoon/evening.
learner_examples: I got your letter yesterday. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Luganda)

pos_items.definition: two times
dictionary_examples: I've already asked him twice.
You need to take two tablets twice daily.
There are twice as many houses in this area as there used to be.
The state is at least twice as big as England.
He's twice her size.
learner_examples: I can write twice a week. (Key English Test; A2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: to carefully consider whether what you are planning is a good idea
dictionary_examples: I'd think twice about spending so much money on one thing, if I were you.
learner_examples: Now I will think twice before I buy your paper again. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to do something immediately, without considering whether it is a good idea
dictionary_examples: When he asked me out, I didn't think twice!
learner_examples: Your advertisement seemed very convincing and as I intended to travel to exotic locations I did not think twice. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

learner_examples: Apart [from] this you can keep yourself up to speed with what's happening around the world on various fronts. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: the direction that you face to see the sun go down
dictionary_examples: The points of the compass are North, South, East and West.
The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.

pos_items.definition: the part of an area that is further towards the west than the rest
dictionary_examples: We live in the west of the city.
Most of the country will be dry tomorrow, but the west will have some rain.
learner_examples: It [is] situated in the west of [the] town and it is near the sea. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: the countries of North America and western Europe
dictionary_examples: There has been concern in/throughout the West about the effects of this measure.
East-West relations

pos_items.definition: in or forming the west part of something
dictionary_examples: the west coast of Ireland
They come from west London.
learner_examples: I most enjoyed Bergen, which is [o]n the west coast of Norway. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: towards the west
dictionary_examples: We travelled west.
They live in a village four miles west of Oxford.

pos_items.definition: not correct
dictionary_examples: Three of your answers were wrong.
That clock is wrong - it's 12.30, not 12.15.
I'm sorry, you've got the wrong number.
We're going the wrong way.
learner_examples: We [listen to a] tape somet[ime]s, and mark wrong letters. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to think or say something that is not correct
dictionary_examples: I was wrong about the time - the shop closed at 7, not 8.
You're wrong in thinking that Matt is from the States - he's Canadian.
learner_examples: If I'm not wrong, it is in the living room. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to produce an answer or result that is not correct, or to say or write something that is not correct
dictionary_examples: I got most of the answers wrong.
The newspapers got the story completely wrong.

pos_items.definition: If something is wrong, there is a problem.
dictionary_examples: You've been quiet all evening. Is there anything wrong?
What's wrong?
There's something wrong with my computer.
learner_examples: I didn't kn[o]w him, so I thought that there was something wrong. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: not considered morally acceptable by most people
dictionary_examples: Children should be taught that violence is wrong.
It is wrong to tell lies.
What's wrong with having a bit of fun?
learner_examples: To sum up, I think it is wrong to keep animals in zoos. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not suitable or correct, or not as it should be
dictionary_examples: She's the wrong person for the job.
She got in with the wrong crowd at university.
learner_examples: Personally I prefer to think that you gave the job to the wrong person. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: get off/start on the wrong foot
pos_items.definition: to start a relationship or activity badly
dictionary_examples: He got off on the wrong foot with my parents by arriving late.
learner_examples: One of the greatest pleasure[s] of reading "The Remains of the Day" would be to see the gradual development of the relationship between Stevens and Miss Kenton. From the beginning, they get off on the wrong foot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: in a way that is not correct
dictionary_examples: You've spelt my name wrong.

pos_items.definition: to develop problems
dictionary_examples: Something's gone wrong with my computer.
learner_examples: Despite all that went wrong, there was something I really enjoyed. It was visiting the Diamond Cave. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used when you do not want someone to think that you do not like someone or something
dictionary_examples: Don't get me wrong, I like her, but she can be very annoying.
learner_examples: Don't get me wrong, I love my aunts, I really do, but not as houseguests. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: up until now
dictionary_examples: I haven't spoken to her yet.
He hasn't finished yet.
"Are you ready?" "Not yet - wait a moment."
learner_examples: I haven't seen the sea yet. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: now or as early as this time
dictionary_examples: I don't want to go home yet.
learner_examples: I don't need it yet because my parents gave me a new computer for my birthday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: the best or worst, etc. until now
dictionary_examples: Of all the songs I've heard tonight, that's the best yet.
That was my worst exam yet.
learner_examples: And that was my worst experience yet. (First Certificate in English; B2; Lithuanian)

pos_items.definition: again after something has happened or been done many times before
dictionary_examples: The bus was late yet again.
learner_examples: Tom, thank you so much yet again for your interest. This talk is very important to me and to count on you is an honour for our college. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: from now and for a particular period of time in the future
dictionary_examples: She won't be back for a long time yet.
Our holiday isn't for weeks yet.
learner_examples: It's a fact that everybody knows that living in Poland is not easy now and it won't be for a long time yet. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you are surprised or annoyed that something is being repeated or increased
dictionary_examples: He's given us yet more work to do.
learner_examples: The awe-inspiring view of the park must not be destroyed for yet another building. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to say there is still a possibility that something will happen
dictionary_examples: He may win yet.
learner_examples: Weakened, the tunnel could yet crumble and fall at any time. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to not have done something that was expected before this time
dictionary_examples: They have yet to make a decision.
learner_examples: But she had yet to inform her fiancé. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: until and including this time
dictionary_examples: We haven't needed extra staff as yet, but may do in the future.
No ambulances had as yet managed to get across the river.
learner_examples: I would like to do something about it, but as I can't imagine building anything near my beautiful house (because I'm afraid it would destroy its wonderful harmony), I have no idea as yet how to solve this problem. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to connect two words, phrases, or clauses when the second part adds something surprising to the first part
dictionary_examples: simple yet effective
I agree it's unlikely, yet she knows what she's talking about.
learner_examples: It was huge and yet gracious. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

He hasn't finished yet.

learner_examples: I haven't seen the sea yet. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

learner_examples: It was huge and yet gracious. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: vertical or as straight as possible
dictionary_examples: He stood up.
She opened her eyes and sat up.
learner_examples: [The whole] class stood up and sang "Imagine". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: towards or in a higher place or position
dictionary_examples: She looked up and smiled at me.
This road goes up into the Andes.
The water was up to the level of the windows.
learner_examples: As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name. I looked up and I saw my friend on the other side of the concert [hall]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: to walk directly towards someone or something until you are next to them
dictionary_examples: He came straight up to me and introduced himself.
learner_examples: She came up to him to help him with the luggage. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay)

pos_items.definition: not in bed
dictionary_examples: I stayed up all night finishing this report.
learner_examples: That night we were up until late talking and after a couple of days she left. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: If an action or decision is up to someone, they are responsible for doing or making it.
dictionary_examples: I can't decide for you, Jack, it's up to you.
It's up to Sophie to decide whether she wants to enter the competition.
learner_examples: This is my opinion but it's up to you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to be doing or planning something
dictionary_examples: What are you up to at the moment?
They're up to something - I can tell.
learner_examples: What have you been up to? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: to a greater degree, amount, volume, etc.
dictionary_examples: Please speak up, I can't hear you.
The fire heats the room up within minutes.
The cost of car insurance is up, but not very much.
learner_examples: Moreover the microphone suddenly wouldn't work anymore, and even though I desperately tried to speak up, people began to lose interest in both my speech and me and simply started to talk to each other instead. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that an action or process is complete
dictionary_examples: Come on, Maria, drink up your lemonade.
By the time we left, she had bought up half of the shop.
learner_examples: Anna, I broke one of your beautiful vase[s] accidentally when I was trying to clean up the house one evening. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: rising and falling
dictionary_examples: They were jumping up and down with impatience.
learner_examples: Well, you should be bouncing up and down with joy (just kidding)! (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to be of bad quality
dictionary_examples: Her latest novel isn't up to much.
learner_examples: But above all, she had this extraordinary dining table, w[h]ich didn't look up to much when you first walked in the room, but as you lifted the three layers of tablecloths protecting a huge piece of glass, you discovered an amazing display of objects from Alabama. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to or in a higher place or position
dictionary_examples: He ran up the steps.
We followed her up the stairs to a large meeting room.
learner_examples: We r[o]de up the mountain [on] our b[i]kes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: along or further along the street/road, etc.
dictionary_examples: They live just up the road.
learner_examples: Go up the street and turn left on the square. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: any amount or number under 10, 20, etc.
dictionary_examples: We can invite up to 65 people.
learner_examples: A wedding can cost up to 10,000 SFr. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: until a particular time
dictionary_examples: You can call me up until midnight.
learner_examples: The party will be in my house up to 1:00 a.m., then we will go to Jean's house. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: from one end to the other and back again
dictionary_examples: They were running up and down the corridors.
learner_examples: Almost a thousand people [were] running up and down the ballroom shouting in panic: "Who's got matches?" "Turn the lights on!" (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: having all the most recent information about a subject or activity
dictionary_examples: The course should bring you up to speed with the latest techniques.
learner_examples: Apart [from] this you can keep yourself up to speed with what's happening around the world on various fronts. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: used to ask about the reason for something
dictionary_examples: "I'm going home." "Why?"
Why did you choose to live in London?
Why wait? Let's leave now.
learner_examples: Why couldn't you come? (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about the reason for something
dictionary_examples: I don't know why she isn't here.
Quite why he isn't here today is a mystery.
There is no reason why we shouldn't succeed.
learner_examples: Also, you didn't say why the photography and painting courses were so popular. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.sense_title: why don't you?/ why not do sth?
pos_items.definition: used to make a suggestion
dictionary_examples: Why don't you come with us?
Why not give it a try?
learner_examples: Why don't we play tennis? (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to agree with something that someone has suggested
dictionary_examples: "Let's have an ice cream." "Yes, why not?"
learner_examples: She said, I have two tickets for a new film [with] Tom Cruise - would you like to come with me? Well I said why not, so I went with her to see this film. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: (comparative of bad) more unpleasant or difficult than something else that is also bad
dictionary_examples: The exam was worse than I expected.
His behaviour is even worse than his sister's.
The heat is much worse in the daytime.
learner_examples: It takes me more than one hour to get to work every day. In the evening it is even worse. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to become more ill, unpleasant, difficult, severe, etc. than before
dictionary_examples: My cold seems to be getting worse.
If the rain gets any worse, we'll have to stop walking.
learner_examples: I thought, it couldn't get worse. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize how unpleasant, difficult, severe, etc. something is becoming
dictionary_examples: The economic climate is getting worse and worse.
learner_examples: The traffic situation in all big towns is getting worse and worse, so that bicycles or public transport must become more attractive. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: something that is more unpleasant or difficult
dictionary_examples: By the third month of the expedition they had endured many hardships, but worse was to follow.
"What about the bride's dress - wasn't it appalling?" "I don't know, I've seen worse."
learner_examples: But worse was to come at 19:30 when we went to see one of London's musicals. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: comparative of badly
dictionary_examples: He did worse than he was expecting in the exams.
He was treated much worse than I was.

pos_items.definition: to make a situation more difficult, unpleasant, etc.
dictionary_examples: To make matters worse, our car broke down!
learner_examples: To make matters worse, the newspaper said they only played for thirty-five minutes. (First Certificate in English; B2; Thai)

dictionary_examples: The course should bring you up to speed with the latest techniques.
learner_examples: Apart [from] this you can keep yourself up to speed with what's happening around the world on various fronts. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: having a larger distance from one side to the other than is usual or expected
dictionary_examples: a wide river/road
learner_examples: I'm going to stay here two weeks in a big hotel near a wide river. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: having a distance of 5 miles/10 metres, etc. from one side to the other
dictionary_examples: The swimming pool is five metres wide.
learner_examples: From the two metres wide window I can overlook the city and the lake. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: a lot of different types of thing
dictionary_examples: The library has a wide range of information.
They sell a wide selection of chocolates.
learner_examples: There is a very wide choice of activities! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: farther than usual or as far as possible
dictionary_examples: She ran towards me, her arms open wide.
learner_examples: She came into the living room and saw me standing on the stairs with my eyes opened wide. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to be completely awake
dictionary_examples: "Is Oliver awake yet?" "Yes, he's wide awake and running around his bedroom."
learner_examples: Sometimes, when I have put my children to bed, half an hour later an aircraft flies over and my two-year old daughter is wide awake again. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: (superlative of bad) the most unpleasant, difficult or severe
dictionary_examples: That was the worst meal I've ever eaten.
"It was the worst moment of my life," she admitted.
learner_examples: And you, what is your worst gift? (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: the most unpleasant or difficult thing, person, or situation
dictionary_examples: That was the worst I've seen him play in several years.
learner_examples: This situation was the worst I have lived [through]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the worst thing, situation, etc.
dictionary_examples: We had no food or light, but worst of all, we had no water.
learner_examples: And worst of all, her mother had been always against that relationship and had given her advice many times. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: (superlative of badly) the most badly
dictionary_examples: Small businesses have been worst hit by the recession.
Roads in the Tayside region were worst affected by the snow.

pos_items.definition: to worry that something very bad will happen or that something very bad has happened
dictionary_examples: When there was no sign of the children, the rescuers feared the worst.
learner_examples: Her parents had been quar[re]lling constantly now for almost half [a] year, and she feared the worst. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: towards a higher position, level or value
dictionary_examples: The cost of completion has been revised upwards again due to inflation.
learner_examples: In evaporation the water drops from seas are carried upwards and form clouds. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Telugu)

pos_items.definition: more than a particular amount
dictionary_examples: Double rooms cost upwards of £70 a night.
learner_examples: Once home to upwards of 50,000 people, Gaza was occupied by anti-gover[n]ment forces for over two years. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used for referring to the opposite of what you have just said
dictionary_examples: Never use indoor lights outside and vice versa.
learner_examples: The piles of cash are not far away from any celebrity and we all know that time equals money and vice versa. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: up until now
dictionary_examples: I haven't spoken to her yet.
He hasn't finished yet.
"Are you ready?" "Not yet - wait a moment."
learner_examples: I haven't seen the sea yet. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: now or as early as this time
dictionary_examples: I don't want to go home yet.
learner_examples: I don't need it yet because my parents gave me a new computer for my birthday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: the best or worst, etc. until now
dictionary_examples: Of all the songs I've heard tonight, that's the best yet.
That was my worst exam yet.
learner_examples: And that was my worst experience yet. (First Certificate in English; B2; Lithuanian)

pos_items.definition: again after something has happened or been done many times before
dictionary_examples: The bus was late yet again.
learner_examples: Tom, thank you so much yet again for your interest. This talk is very important to me and to count on you is an honour for our college. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: from now and for a particular period of time in the future
dictionary_examples: She won't be back for a long time yet.
Our holiday isn't for weeks yet.
learner_examples: It's a fact that everybody knows that living in Poland is not easy now and it won't be for a long time yet. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you are surprised or annoyed that something is being repeated or increased
dictionary_examples: He's given us yet more work to do.
learner_examples: The awe-inspiring view of the park must not be destroyed for yet another building. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to say there is still a possibility that something will happen
dictionary_examples: He may win yet.
learner_examples: Weakened, the tunnel could yet crumble and fall at any time. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to not have done something that was expected before this time
dictionary_examples: They have yet to make a decision.
learner_examples: But she had yet to inform her fiancé. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: until and including this time
dictionary_examples: We haven't needed extra staff as yet, but may do in the future.
No ambulances had as yet managed to get across the river.
learner_examples: I would like to do something about it, but as I can't imagine building anything near my beautiful house (because I'm afraid it would destroy its wonderful harmony), I have no idea as yet how to solve this problem. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to connect two words, phrases, or clauses when the second part adds something surprising to the first part
dictionary_examples: simple yet effective
I agree it's unlikely, yet she knows what she's talking about.
learner_examples: It was huge and yet gracious. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: something that is difficult to do and needs a lot of effort
dictionary_examples: I can lose weight but it's a real uphill struggle.
learner_examples: When this is the case, the families caring for them are faced with an uphill struggle, as it is difficult to reconcile the need for earning a living with the care of their relatives. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: towards the top of a hill
dictionary_examples: We'd walked half a mile uphill.
learner_examples: She had not seen the lorry that made [its] way uphill and when she realized that she would crash right into it, it had been to[o] late to do something. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: every time or any time
dictionary_examples: Whenever I go there they seem to be out.
learner_examples: I read whenever I can, specially at night. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: every time it is possible
dictionary_examples: I try to use olive oil whenever possible.
learner_examples: My friends have always regarded me as a cheerful, active girl, who is glad to help out whenever possible. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: every time or any time
dictionary_examples: "Will it be okay if I do it tomorrow?" "Sure, whenever."
Do it in a spare moment at the weekend or whenever - it really doesn't matter.

pos_items.definition: used to ask in what place or area someone or something is
dictionary_examples: Whereabouts does he live?

pos_items.definition: the place where someone or something is
dictionary_examples: His whereabouts are unknown.
learner_examples: However, his whereabouts have been unknown for 6 years. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: complete, including every part
dictionary_examples: I spent the whole day cleaning.
There's still a whole month till my birthday.
After my exercise class, my whole body ached.
The whole town was destroyed by the earthquake.
This whole thing is ridiculous.
Bill does nothing but complain the whole time .
learner_examples: Did you know that almost the whole class came to my party. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: all of something
dictionary_examples: I'll be on holiday the whole of next week.
His behaviour affects the whole of the class.
The whole of the village had come out for the party.
learner_examples: Moreover, you can see the whole of Hong Kong from the Peak. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: generally
dictionary_examples: We've had a few problems, but on the whole we're very happy.
learner_examples: On the whole I don't like watching television. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: when considered as a group and not in parts
dictionary_examples: The population as a whole is getting healthier.
learner_examples: To sum up, I can say that the greatest ever invention is the invention of computers, that has affected both indivi[d]uals and society as a whole. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: as a single object and not in pieces
dictionary_examples: The baby bird swallowed the worm whole.
